Title: The role of brightness differences in figure-ground: is darker figure?
Affiliations: Dept. of Geography, 302 Walker, Penn State Univ., University Park, PA 16802, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maceachren, A.M., Dept. of Geography, 302 Walker, Penn State Univ., University Park, PA 16802, USA, United States; Mistrick, T.A., Dept. of Geography, 302 Walker, Penn State Univ., University Park, PA 16802, USA, United States
Abstract: Separating figure from ground is a fundamental map design objective in all but the simplest maps. Psychological principles underlying the figure-ground relationship are presented as a basis from which to examine the role of value contrast in establishing figure-ground separation between land and water on maps. An experiment is described that comes to the conclusion that neither light nor dark areas are seen as figure if all other things are equal, and that knowledge of which area is land does not dictate that land will be seen as figure. -from Authors
Index Keywords: educational policy; figure-ground; map design; nation building; national integration; visualisation tool; Nigeria

Title: The ordnance and the ordnance survey— offspring or foundling?
Affiliations: Sundale, Reeth, Richmond, N. Yorks, DL11 6TX, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davey, A.B.T., Sundale, Reeth, Richmond, N. Yorks, DL11 6TX, United Kingdom
Abstract: No statement appears to have been made at the time of why the national survey was put in hand in 1791. How far the Ordnance launched it in furtherance of its own responsibilities for the defence of the realm, and was therefore right to confer on the ordnance survey the prestige of its name, is a question which this article considers. The Board of Ordnance was a department of state which was already by then two and a half centuries old. Furnishing the ordnance survey with scientific and administrative skills and Ordnance also lumbered it with the political difficulties which led to its own demise. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Board of Ordnance; historical study; OS

Title: The enduring image of early british townscapes
Affiliations: Erith College of Technology, Tower Road, Belvedere, Kent, DA17 6JA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D., Erith College of Technology, Tower Road, Belvedere, Kent, DA17 6JA, United Kingdom
Abstract: It has long been recognised that the earliest cartographic images of British towns enjoyed a long life through the re-use and adaptation of copper plates and through plagiarism. However, the precise nature of the complex relationship between various images has remained unclear and it is, therefore, necessary to try to unravel exactly which plates were adapted and re-used and who copied who and when. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: cartographic image; copper plate; townscape; UK

Authors with affiliations: Nicholson, T.

Title: The role of the ordnance survey of Great Britain
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Birkbeck College, University of London, 7-15 Gresse Street, London, W1P 1PA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rhind, D.W., Department of Geography, Birkbeck College, University of London, 7-15 Gresse Street, London, W1P 1PA, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the future of the British national mapping agency in a society which is markedly different from that in which the Ordnance Survey Review Committee of 1979 worked. The objective is to ascertain which topographic information is needed, who should provide it, on what terms and through which mechanisms. Prior to making an attempt to answer these questions, the essential characteristics of Ordnance Survey (OS) are summarised as deduced from available documentary evidence1; the changing attitudes to information as a commodity, the growing competition in British mapping and the government’s stringent requirements from the Survey are also outlined as just three of the many complexities which affect OS. Building upon Smith’s classic 1979 paper and subsequent experience, the rationale for government involvement in mapping is examined. It is concluded that the Survey has a continuing vital role though there are a number of steps which the OS should take in order to adapt to changing circumstances. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: government involvement; national mapping; OS; topographic information

Title: Representing of contour lines by turning point preserving quadratic splines
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, R3T 2N2, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Walton, D.J., Department of Computer Science, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, R3T 2N2, Canada; Xu, R., Department of Computer Science, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, R3T 2N2, Canada
Abstract: Terrain data obtained from satellite imagery or by scanning existing contour maps is in raster mode. Such data may be compressed by detecting and storing the critical points of contour lines. When hand digitising a contour map, a trained digitiser operator would usually select points which visually appear to be critical points. Existing interpolation techniques often fail to restore the critical points, including turning points, to their original positions. This article illus¬trates the use ofsplines composed of quadratic Bézier curves with monotone curvature for rendering contour lines which are represented only by their turning and end points, such that the positions of the turning points are preserved. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Bezier curve; contour line; interpolation; quadratic spline; turning point

Title: The origins of that definition
Affiliations: Tredustan Hall, Defynnog, Brecon, Powys, LD3 8YH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mating, D.H., Tredustan Hall, Defynnog, Brecon, Powys, LD3 8YH, United Kingdom
Abstract: For the last two or three years there has been some debate and discussion about the modern validity of the definition of Cartography, which has now been used by the International Cartographic Association since the early nineteen seventies. This definition has its origins in an investigation made by the author in 1963 and 1964, though any credit (or blamej for the final wording must be given to the original Council of the British Cartographic Society. The present paper traces the evolution of this definition and reproduces the original, unpublished document which I produced for the Council in February 1964.1 make no attempt to redefine the word in 1991. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: cartography definition; International Cartographic Association

Title: The effects of map projections and map distance on emotional involvement with places
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, 29208, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gilmartin, P., Department of Geography, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, 29208, United States; Lloyd, R., Department of Geography, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, 29208, United States
Abstract: Previous research has shown that people are less concerned with events that occur in distant places than with nearby happenings. World maps show the locations of and relative distances between places, but the cartographer’s choice of map projection system and geographic origin for the projection can significantly affect the apparent distances between places on the map. The study reported here was designed to investigate the relationship between the emotional involve-ment of a sample student population with hypothetical events in a number of world locations and the distance between ‘home’ and those locations as shown on different map projections. Results showed a consistent inverse relationship between interest and distance, with the interest level for the same cities changing as distances (projections) were changed. Other variables also influenced people’s responses. Overall, women expressed significantly higher emotional involvement with places than men, and certain regions produced a higher or lower level of response than would have been predicted by distance alone. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: distance-interest relationships; emotional involvement; gender difference; map projection; perception; place

Title: Some current issues in cartographic distribution and future prospects
Affiliations: Cartographic Information and Distribution Centre, Energy Mines and Resources, Ottawa, K1A 0E9, Canada; Department of Geography, Queen’s University, Kingston, K7L 3N6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: McArthur, J.A., Cartographic Information and Distribution Centre, Energy Mines and Resources, Ottawa, K1A 0E9, Canada; McGrath, G., Department of Geography, Queen’s University, Kingston, K7L 3N6, Canada

Title: The role of maps in spatial knowledge acquisition
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Penn State University, 302 Walker Building, University Park, PA, 19802, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacEachren, A.M., Department of Geography, Penn State University, 302 Walker Building, University Park, PA, 19802, United States
Abstract: One goal of cartographic research is to improve the usefulness of maps. To do so, we must consider the process of spatial knowledge acquisition, the role of maps in that process, and the content of cognitive representations derived. Research from psychology, geography, and other disciplines related to these issues is reviewed. This review is used to suggest potential new directions for research with particular attention to spatial problem solving and geographic instruction. A classroom experiment related to these issues is then described. The experiment highlights some of the implications that a concern for the process of spatial knowledge acquisition will have on questions and methods of cartographic research as well as on the use of maps in geographic instruction. It also provides evidence of independent but interrelated verbal and spatial components of regional images that can be altered by directed map work. © 1991 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: classroom experiment; cognitive representation; knowledge acquisition; map; map usage; spatial awareness; spatial knowledge

Title: GIS and simple systems for visual, interactive, spatial analysis
Affiliations: Department of Mathematical Statistics and Operational Research, University of Exeter, Streatham Court, Rennes Drive, Exeter, EX4 4PU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, T.C., Department of Mathematical Statistics and Operational Research, University of Exeter, Streatham Court, Rennes Drive, Exeter, EX4 4PU, United Kingdom
Abstract: In much the same way as a spreadsheet is more appropriate to some needs than a fully relational DBMS, many users interested in analysis of spatially referenced data have fairly unsophisticated requirements for extensive data storage or complex retrieval functions, and limited needs for topographic detail, cartographic accuracy or advanced map editing; however, they do require access to a wide range of statistical functions for data transformation, reduction and smoothing, multivariate analysis, and the modelling of spatial relationships. This paper argues that the needs of such users are poorly met by the ‘mainstream’ model for GIS that is often presented in the literature. A PC-based system, equivalent in GIS terms to the spreadsheet, is described. It integrates simple data structures, limited map creation and editing, a powerful range of standard and spatially orientated statistical functions, and the ability to interactively present results through chloropleth, contour, proportionate symbol, or proximally shaded maps. It is par-ticularly designed to be easily accessible and to encourage visual interactive analysis. For some users such a system has acted as an adequate solution in its own right and for others it has provided a useful educational transition to more extensive and powerful systems. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: data structure; spatial analysis; visual analysis

Authors: Gerber R., Burden P., Stanton G.
Title: Development of public information symbols for tourism and recreational mapping
Affiliations: Social Studies Department, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, 4059, Australia; Division of Geographic Information, Department of Lands, P.O. Box 40, Woolloongabba, Brisbane, 4102, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gerber, R., Social Studies Department, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, 4059, Australia; Burden, P., Division of Geographic Information, Department of Lands, P.O. Box 40, Woolloongabba, Brisbane, 4102, Australia; Stanton, G., Division of Geographic Information, Department of Lands, P.O. Box 40, Woolloongabba, Brisbane, 4102, Australia
Abstract: Tourists and recreators have an increasing need for useful graphic products. Investigations have revealed that there is a lack of uniformity in the public information symbols used on tourist and recreational maps around the world. It is perceived that a need exists to develop a set of standardised public information symbols for this large group of map users. A range of theoretical and practical influences on the development of such symbols are examined to provide a sound basis for their design. As a result, a systematic pro-cedure is proposed for designing public information symbols. To test this procedure, a study was completed to develop a prototype set of public information symbols for use with computer (raster-based) generated tourist and recreational maps. This set of symbols is organised around the following classification: accommodation, cultural features, entertainment, facilities, recreation, services, transport, uniques features and warnings. This prototype of symbols could form the basis of a standardised set of com-puterised public information symbols. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: computer-generated map; mapping technique; public information symbol; recreation; recreational mapping; symbol standardisation; tourism; tourism mapping

Title: Landscapes on Pluto: Improving computer-aided visualisation
Affiliations: Cheltenham and Gloucester College of Higher Education, Gloucester, GL2 9HW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Moore, R., Cheltenham and Gloucester College of Higher Education, Gloucester, GL2 9HW, United Kingdom
Abstract: While the landscape architectural profession has for some time recognised the importance of computer technology particularly in the field of design (CAD), its genuine application has been restricted, on the one hand, by a shortage of appropriate software and, on the other, by a widespread hostility to the ‘artificiality’ of computer graphics when attempting visualisations of landscapes complete with plants. The advent of reasonably-priced colour processors, such as the Pluto controller, has allowed the development of programs that produce images more acceptable to the landscape designer. This article describes briefly the nature of landscape design and discusses the part terrain modelling and perspective drawing plans in the design process. There then follows an evaluation of the methods by which computers depict living plant material. The article concludes with a description of a system that tries to reproduce more closely the type of graphics generally expected or sought by landscape architects. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: colour processor; computer technology; computer visualisation; design process; graphics reproduction; landscape architecture; perspective drawing; planning tool; Pluto Controller Colour Processor; technological application; terrain modelling; visualisation

Title: The geographical name in modern school atlases: A study of the reasons for the persistence of exonyms despite the increasing worldwide adoption of standardised names
Affiliations: College of St. Mark, St. John Foundation, Derriford Road, Derriford, Plymouth, PL6 8BH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sandford, H.A., College of St. Mark, St. John Foundation, Derriford Road, Derriford, Plymouth, PL6 8BH, United Kingdom
Abstract: The names of geographical entities in school atlases present a mixture of standardised names and exonyms (conventional names), and the former are only slowly replacing the latter. An examination is made of the rate of replacement and of the factors involved in this replacement. A solution to the problem is offered. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: atlas; exonym; school atlas; standardised name

Title: Horton’s ordering scheme and the generalisation of river networks
Affiliations: Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mazur, E.R., Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada; Castner, H.W., Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Abstract: Horton’s system of stream ordering is examined as a way of generalising rivers for reference maps at a variety of small scales. The manipulation of classes of ordered streams provides a way of answering the questions “How many?” and “Which ones?”. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: drainage area; generalisation scheme; river network generalisation

Title: Comparison of complexity measures for choropleth maps
Affiliations: The Winand Staring Centre for Integrated Land, Soil and Water Research, P.O. Box 125, Wageningen, 6700, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bregt, A.K., The Winand Staring Centre for Integrated Land, Soil and Water Research, P.O. Box 125, Wageningen, 6700, Netherlands; Wopereis, M.C.S., The Winand Staring Centre for Integrated Land, Soil and Water Research, P.O. Box 125, Wageningen, 6700, Netherlands
Abstract: The complexity of a choropleth map has an important influence on its readability. Six map complexity measures (aggregation index, compactness index, boundary contrast index, fragmentation index, boundary index, size disparity index) described in literature are presented in this study. Correlation coefficients between these indices are calculated, using 90 different maps. It is shown that most of the measures are highly correlated and therefore redundant. Visual judgement of 13 maps by 28 subjects shows that four indices (aggregation index, compactness index, fragmentation index, boundary index) can serve as reliable indicators of map complexity. As a result, each of these measures can be used to compare pattern complexity among different maps. The fragmentation index seems to be the best choice in view of its simplicity and calculation ease. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: choropleth map; complexity measure; map

Title: Orienteering mapping and higher education
Affiliations: Department of Surveying, University of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fairbairn, D.J., Department of Surveying, University of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom
Abstract: The sport of orienteering relies on good quality accurate mapping which reflects the intricate detail of landscapes which are navigated across, on foot, by enthusiastic and experienced competitors of all ages. As a central component of the sport, therefore, mapping has assumed a prominent role in the thinking behind ‘The Forward Plan’, a study promoted by the British Orienteering Federation (BOF) and sponsored by the English Sports Council. The mapping component of ‘The Forward Plan’ suggests that extending awareness of mapping and encouraging technical skills are vital steps. The role of institutes of higher education (universities, polytechnics, colleges) in these areas is examined in this paper. The objective is to determine to what extent tertiary educational establishments can assist, in a non-commercial manner, in increasing production and improving standards of orienteering mapping. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: education; higher education; mapping; UK

Title: Developments in digital map production and data integration within the British geological survey
Affiliations: British Geological Survey, Keyworth, Nottingham, NG12 5GG, United Kingdom; Mining Journal, 60 Worship Street, London, EC2A 2HD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Becken, K., British Geological Survey, Keyworth, Nottingham, NG12 5GG, United Kingdom; Forrest, M.D., Mining Journal, 60 Worship Street, London, EC2A 2HD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Digital techniques for cartographie data capture and high quality map production have been developed and applied over some 18 years to the mapping of the geoscientific datasets of the British Geological Survey, in particular to the geochemical dataset. Over this period, technological advances and developments in both vector and raster data processing techniques havefacilitated high quality map production and the integration and display of multiple datasets. This paper reviews the developments in high quality map production and interpretation of survey information, with particular regard to the Regional Geochemical A tlas Series, through the application of image processing techniques on the display and analysis of multiple datasets. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: British Geological Survey; data integration; data processing; digital map; geohemistry; map production; UK

Title: Map conservation project at Trinity College Library Dublin
Affiliations: Trinity College Library Dublin, College Street, Dublin, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Cains, M., Trinity College Library Dublin, College Street, Dublin, Ireland; Ferguson, P., Trinity College Library Dublin, College Street, Dublin, Ireland
Abstract: This paper describes the conservation of the first edition of the six-inches-to-one-mile Ordnance Survey maps of Ireland. It outlines the general problem of the acidity of paper on which nineteenth-century Ordnance Survey maps are printed and the peculiar problems of conserving a hand- coloured presentation set. Each stage in the process is described up to the final encapsulation of the maps in Melinex polyester film. © 1990 Maney Publishing.

Title: A vector and raster graphic mapping tool on micro-computers
Affiliations: Water Systems Research Group, University of the Witwatersrand, PO, Wits, 2050, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Lambourne, J.J., Water Systems Research Group, University of the Witwatersrand, PO, Wits, 2050, South Africa; Sutherland, F.R., Water Systems Research Group, University of the Witwatersrand, PO, Wits, 2050, South Africa
Abstract: The rapid development of physically-based hydrological information and modelling systems has necessitated enhanced data entry and display systems. A ‘mapping tool’ is developed for the manipulation and display of spatial information, which is a cost-efficient, self-contained utility system that is suitable for use on micro-computers. It has the ability to be integrated as part of any modelling or information system. Diverse applications using the ‘mapping tool’ are briefly described including resource management systems for planners, mass balance studies in urban catchments and data entry systems for physically based models. © 1990 Maney Publishing.

Title: An examination of the difference between the interpretation of screen based and printed maps
Affiliations: The Welcome Mission, Leytonstone, London, E11, United Kingdom; Department of Geography, Portsmouth Polytechnic, Portsmouth, PO1 3HE, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gooding, K., The Welcome Mission, Leytonstone, London, E11, United Kingdom; Forrest, D., Department of Geography, Portsmouth Polytechnic, Portsmouth, PO1 3HE, United Kingdom
Abstract: The development of the video disc and similar devices for storing pictures for subsequent display on computer screens has led to video images of conventional printed maps being used in a number of systems. Little consideration appears to have been given to the factors influencing the visual processing of such images. An experiment was carried out to determine if subjects’ map reading ability is affected by this change of media. Results show that there was significantly better performance obtained when using conventional paper maps in comparison to their video images as displayed by the Domesday system. © 1990 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: printed map; screen based map; video disc

Abstract: The perspective projection of the Earth onto a tilted plane is useful in simulating photographs taken from Earth orbiting space vehicles. A new approach to the calculation of projection coordinates is demonstrated by using vector geometry. © 1990 Maney Publishing.

Authors: Cauvin C., Schneider C., Cherrier G.
Title: Cartographic transformations and the piezopleth maps method
Affiliations: U.E.R. de Géographie, Université Louis Pasteur, Strasbourg, France; C.N.R.S. - U.A., Strasbourg, 902, United States; University of Technology of Sevenans, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cauvin, C., U.E.R. de Géographie, Université Louis Pasteur, Strasbourg, France; Schneider, C., C.N.R.S. - U.A., Strasbourg, 902, United States; Cherrier, G., University of Technology of Sevenans, United States
Abstract: Numerous types of anamorphoses, or cartographic transformations, have been perfected, leading to a distorted picture as compared to the usual map representations. Piezopleth maps are a particular case; their construction rests on a physical model used for strength resistance calculations and structures resolution in civil engineering. Locations and thematic variables are combined in the same process; their interrelations point out the differences in potential and are expressed by distortions of surfaces of the structure and shifting of locations. This process, which requires the elaboration of a geographical background with a mesh structure, gives unusual but very expressive maps, whether in comparing phenomenons on a given date or the same phenomenon through time. © 1989 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: piezopleth map; transformation

Title: ITE and digital mapping since 1973
Affiliations: Environmental Information Centre, Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Monks Wood Experimental Station, Abbots Ripton, PE17 2LS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brown, N., Environmental Information Centre, Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Monks Wood Experimental Station, Abbots Ripton, PE17 2LS, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) has created a new group within the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology (1TE) called The Environmental Information Centre (EIC). Amongst its other functions this centre is responsible for digital mapping and Geographical Information Systems(GIS) within the ITE. This is the latest organisational change to effect NERC digital mapping and is particularly significant because it marks the beginning of a ‘new era as digital mapping metamorphoses into G/S. At this point it seems appropriate to recall the previous sixteen years of digital mapping in ITE. © 1989 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: digital mapping; environmental mapping; GIS; Natural Environmental Research Council; UK

Title: Problems with experimental research in map design - A case study
Affiliations: Department of Surveying and Cartography, Curtin University of Technology, Perth, WA, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Worth, C., Department of Surveying and Cartography, Curtin University of Technology, Perth, WA, Australia
Abstract: The various problems involved with scientific map evaluation are examined with the aid of an example from experimental cartography. Point symbols from two Australian city street directories are compared experimentally. The objective results give us information about the design characteristics of the maps and indicate where improvements could be made. However limitations in experimental design and subjective elements in the experimental process are exposed and examined in the context of the search for the general theoretical principles of map design. © 1989 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: design; map; theoretical principle

Title: An experimental investigation of the communicative efficiency of point symbols on tourist maps
Affiliations: Geography Department, Nottingham Polytechnic, Clifton Lane, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clarke, L.M., Geography Department, Nottingham Polytechnic, Clifton Lane, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This study analyses the efficiency of symbols in the legends of two comparable published tourist maps using a symbol comprehension method. Relative effectiveness is assessed with respect to the ease and accuracy with which the symbols were understood by subjects. The results highlight those point symbols that are inefficient. These were found to be mainly abstract, geometric or pictorial symbols that bear a poor resemblance to the object they are attempting to depict. © 1989 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: communicative effectiveness; point; symbol; tourist map

Affiliations: Shell Centre for Mathematical Education, University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, R.J., Shell Centre for Mathematical Education, University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
Abstract: This article considers the similarities and differences between maps and other types of graphic information such as graphs and diagrams. It is argued that all types of graphic information are different solutions to a common problem: the brain’s limited capacity to store unprocessed information. © 1989 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: diagram; graph; graphic information; map

Title: Numerical treatment of conformal map projections
Affiliations: Department of Geodesy and Surveying, University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Kaltsikis, C.J., Department of Geodesy and Surveying, University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: The paper presents a numerically convenient general solution in establishing mapping equations for conformal projections of areas on the earth-ellipsoid, to the plane using so called harmonic polynomials. The application to a projection of Gauss-Krüger type for the regions of Greece and West Germany yielded a satisfactory solution with polynomials of 6th degree. © 1989 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: conformal projection; Gauss-Kruger; numerical solution

Title: The representation of non-extractive industry on large-scale county maps of England and Walesl 700 -c. 1840
Affiliations: Erith College of Technology, Tower Road, Belvedere, Kent, DA17 6JA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D., Erith College of Technology, Tower Road, Belvedere, Kent, DA17 6JA, United Kingdom
Abstract: The nature of the ‘Industrial Revolution’ between 1700 and c. 1840 isfrequently misunderstood, creating a picture of dynamic multi-faceted industrial growth which is far from the truth. Most industry remained rural, dispersed and powered by wind or water. Cartographic sources have largely been ignored in studies of industrial location, yet they have much to offer, illuminating the subject in ways which documentary sources cannot. The most comprehensive cartographic source of information on industrial location in England and Wales during the ‘Industrial Revolution’ is the family of large-scale county maps produced between 1700 and about 1840. Their worth as a source of industrial information has generally been underrated. However, if they are to be of value to the industrial historian, it is necessary to understand what they show and why, and equally what they fail to show. © 1989 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: cartography; county; county map; documentary source; industrial location; industry; map; non-extractive industry; UK, England; UK, Wales

Title: The National Atlas of Wales
Affiliations: University College of Wales, Aberystwyth, SY23 2AX, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Griffiths, H.M., University College of Wales, Aberystwyth, SY23 2AX, United Kingdom
Abstract: Spring 1989 saw the publication of the fourth and final instalment of the National Atlas of Wales. This paper traces its origins and the factors influencing its development and outlines aspects of its design, compilation and production. © 1989 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: compilation; design; national atlas; production; UK, Wales

Title: The archaeological and historical maps of the Ordnance Survey
Affiliations: Stratford on Avon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hellyer, R., Stratford on Avon, United Kingdom
Abstract: A map overprinted with the known information relevant to one specific archaeological or historical period rather than a general survey was a concept developed by O. G. S. Crawford during his period of tenure as the Ordnance Survey Archaeology Officer, and, after the war, by his successor, C. W. Phillips. This paper discusses the making of these maps, and cites the known cartographical, bibliographical and manuscript sources relevant both to the published maps and to those which failed to reach publication. © 1989 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: archaeological map; cartography; documentary source; historical map; map; Ordnance Survey; UK

Title: A computer aided geometric design approach to contour map editing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, The University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, R3T 2N2, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Walton, D.J., Department of Computer Science, The University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, R3T 2N2, Canada
Abstract: A contour map is a convenient representation of threedimensional data. Although, when displayed, it does not provide an immediate visual three-dimensional image, it is useful in practical applications. It is tedious to manually draw or extract data from a contour map. The ability to store contour maps for computer processing is thus desirable. A contour map is conventionally stored in a computer as a set of polygons. This method unfortunately requires a large amount of storage and is not convenient for subsequent editing of contour maps. More recent techniques use cubic splines with mathematical continuity. Although such techniques require less storage than the conventional method, they do not provide a convenient means for subsequent editing. From recent reports on research in Computer Aided Geometric Design as well as in Computer Aided Design and Computer Aided Manufacturing, it seems that cubic splines with geometric continuity rather than mathematical continuity are more appropriate for computer graphics applications. This article examines the appropriateness of geometric continuity in the development of software for contour map editing. © 1989 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: CAD; contour map; cubic spline; map editing

Title: The case against rectangular world maps
Abstract: We strongly urge book and map publishers, the media, and government agencies to cease using rectangular world maps for general purposes or artistic displays. Such maps promote serious, erroneous conceptions by severely distorting large sections of the world, by showing the round earth as having straight edges and sharp corners, by representing most distances and direct routes incorrectly, and by portraying the circular coordinate system as a squared grid. -from Authors
Index Keywords: coordinate system; distortion; rectangular map; world map

Title: Graphic database exchange: Direct translators versus universal translators
Affiliations: School of Civil and Structural Engineering, Nanyang Technological Institute, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Koo, T.K., School of Civil and Structural Engineering, Nanyang Technological Institute, Singapore
Abstract: Computer-Aided-Design (CAD) is the emerging force to be reckoned with in the world of surveying and mapping. CAD provides the technology for mapmakers to integrate, at different degrees of sophistication, the many facets of map making into a linked information chain so that maps are easy to make, revise, view, understand and communicate. Implicit in the CAD concept is the recognition that maps, which represent the end products of the mapping cycle, are shared graphic databases to be used in other information cycles. The uses to which these graphic databases can be applied are only limited by the imagination of man. To harness the full power of CAD technology, standards for graphic interchange formats must be firmly established. This paper examines the problems of graphic database interchange standards from across the CAD spectrum: from microCAD to mainframe CAD, and looks at some solutions to these problems. © 1988 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: computer aided design; database exchange; graphic database

Title: Optimal mapping and the determination of cartographic design principles
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sorrell, P., Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: As it becomes increasingly possible for a ‘non cartographer1 to easily produce maps by means of digital systems, whether they use a ‘mapping package’ or Geographical Information System, concern is expressed over the quality of the resultant level of communication achieved by the map. It is suggested that all potential ‘mapmakers’ should be aware of the basic principles governing both ‘optimal mapping1 and ‘cartographic design’. This paper outlines these objectives. © 1988 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: education; mapping design; principle awareness

Title: Maps for mountaineers
Affiliations: Formerly Department of Geography, University College, Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Maling, D., Formerly Department of Geography, University College, Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: A light-hearted account of the kinds of maps used, and required by British mountaineers. A background paper for the Working Group of “Mountain Maps” held in Glasgow in September 1987. © 1988 Maney Publishing.

Title: The application of videodisc technology to mapping
Authors with affiliations: Greenwell, J.C.
Abstract: An assessment is made of the commercially available videodisc systems and technical aspects of their use are outlined. The design issues which must be considered before applying such technology to a mapping system are then detailed. These include the area of the map sheet for each frame, which map series to store, the hardware configuration used and updating of the system. © 1988 Maney Publishing.

Title: ‘Skeletons’ at Ugbrooke Park, Devon
Affiliations: Geography Department, Amory Building, Rennes Drive, Exeter, EX4 4RJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ravenhill, W., Geography Department, Amory Building, Rennes Drive, Exeter, EX4 4RJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: As in the physical, so in the figurative sense, ‘skeletons’ are difficult to identify. Cartographic skeletons, 95 in number, and divisible into four distinct groups, survive in the muniment room of the Clifford family at Ugbrooke Park, Devon. This article attempts to identify them and to place them into their historical and contemporary mapping contexts thus revealing Robert Edward Clifford as a military analyst and valued consultant to the map-publishing firm of John Carey. © 1988 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Carey; cartographic skeletons; Devon

Title: Institutional and individual influences on scottish geological maps, 1804-1847: A cornucopia of publication or a mere trickle?
Affiliations: Department of Earth Sciences, The University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boud, R.C., Department of Earth Sciences, The University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: The shape, form and pace of the development of Scottish geological cartography during the first half of the nineteenth century are described. The part played by Scottish scientific societies in publishing geological maps is assessed, comparison being made with that of the Geological Society of London. The attempts made to devise graphic representations of the strata, and the problems encountered in publishing the results, are also discussed. © 1988 Maney Publishing.

Title: Maps for the physically disabled
Affiliations: Mapping and Charting Establishment (RE), Elmwood Avenue, Feltham, TW13 7AF, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fry, C.M., Mapping and Charting Establishment (RE), Elmwood Avenue, Feltham, TW13 7AF, United Kingdom
Abstract: Maps are generally used for territorial interpretation by the able-bodied population. The same principle has been used in this study to improve the mobility of the physically disabled population. The use of specialised symbols superimposed on a base map enables safe, quick and independent mobility. The physical barriers can be broken down, but does a pictorial representation of disability become psychologically demoralis¬ing to the user? The success of the map under discussion depends on whether the social barriers can be broken down too. © 1988 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic sources for the study of jaffa: From the Napoleonic siege to the british conquest
Affiliations: The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kark, R., The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: The development of mapping in Palestine paralleled increasing interest by Western nations in the area. By concentrating on the city of Jaffa, the growth of a range of maps for an important area of the Holy Land is exemplified. Cartography by nations, armies, companies and individuals was undertaken for political/military, religious, survey and legal and economic purposes. A bibliography of maps is given. © 1988 Maney Publishing.

Title: Critical points detection and automatic line generalisation in raster data using zero-crossings
Affiliations: Department of Geodetic Science and Surveying, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210-1247, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thapa, K., Department of Geodetic Science and Surveying, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210-1247, United States
Abstract: The problem of critical points detection is important not only in the field of cartography but also in pattern recognition, image processing, computer vision, and artificial intelligence. In this paper, a new algorithm for critical points detection in raster data is given. The algorithm is based on finding the zero-crossings of the convoluted values of the second derivative of the Gaussian with the signal derived from the raster data. In addition, the results of the critical points detected by this algorithm are compared with those selected by humans. Moreover, the importance and usefulness of critical points detection in digital curves is outlined. © 1988 Maney Publishing.

Title: Defining a minimum area rectangle circumscribing given information
Affiliations: Technion - Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32 000, Israel, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Doytsher, Y., Technion - Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32 000, Israel, Israel
Abstract: A method of defining a rectangular zone which circumscribes given measured data is discussed in the paper. The computed zone is orientated in an arbitrary direction, determining a rectangle with a minimum area. The method is composed of several phases leading up to a solution of the rectangle, a solution which does not depend on the quantity of information to be covered. Defining a perimeter - closed polygon - which circumscribes the area to be mapped and altering it to a polygon of a convex shape, enables the identification of the required rectangle by an iterative process of a few stages. -Author
Index Keywords: minimum area rectangle; polygon

Title: The south carolina coastline on historical maps: A cartometric analysis
Affiliations: University of South Carolina, Columbia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lloyd, R., University of South Carolina, Columbia, United States; Gilmartin, P., University of South Carolina, Columbia, United States
Abstract: Historical maps of the South Carolina coastline were examined to determine their accuracy. Length and direction of error vectors were analyzed for statistically significant differences between individual maps and among regions within maps. Accuracy generally improved over time, but one map was found to be less accurate than expected, given its date. The direction of the error vectors tended to be aligned more with longitude than latitude. Segments of the coast with larger populations were generally more accurate than less populated areas. The northern portion of the coastline had significantly more error associated with it than other parts of the coast. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: The directorate of overseas surveys and mapping in Nigeria
Affiliations: University of Lagos, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Balogun, O.Y., University of Lagos, Nigeria
Abstract: The Directorate of Overseas Surveys is the giant-tasked but small-establishment central mapping organisation that eventually salvaged British colonies from their state of maplessness. Its contribution to mapping in Nigeria is discussed in this paper. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: Unit-vector density mapping
Affiliations: Universities of Nebraska, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lavin, S.J., Universities of Nebraska, AZ, United States; Cerveny, R.S., Universities of Nebraska, AZ, United States
Abstract: An automated mapping technique, termed unit-vector density mapping, is introduced as a new method of displaying continuous surface vector quantities. With this graphic procedure, the density of short standard-length line segments (unit-vectors) with, or without, arrowheads represents geographical magnitudes and unit-vector orientation shows direction or movement. This paper describes the plotting algorithms for producing unit-vector density maps and demons-trates the versatility of this technique in a number of geoscientific applications. © 1987 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: automated mapping; density mapping; vector

Title: Digital urban mapping
Affiliations: Technion - Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Doytsher, Y., Technion - Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Shmutter, B., Technion - Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: Mapping is gradually passing from the domain of graphics to the domain of numbers. Whereas in the traditional mapping process the aerial photography has been transformed directly into a line map, the new approach to mapping yields primarily a digital representation of the area, the plotted map becoming but one of the possible output forms. The digital approach is of paramount importance in mapping at large scales, for it can easily be combined with other sources of information, also presented in digital forms, to produce a data base for managing the area. © 1987 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: digital mapping; urban mapping

Title: Statistical determination of class intervals for maps
Affiliations: Department of Cartography, Eötvös University, Budapest Kun Béla tér 2, H-1083, Hungary; Research Institute for Soil Science, Budapest Herman Ottö utca 15, H-1022, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Stegena, L., Department of Cartography, Eötvös University, Budapest Kun Béla tér 2, H-1083, Hungary; Csillag, F., Research Institute for Soil Science, Budapest Herman Ottö utca 15, H-1022, Hungary
Abstract: There are several practical rules for determining categories (class intervals) for maps representing statistical data, like arithmetic, geometric or equal steps etc. In this paper, however a coherent method is proposed to provide statistically separable classes on a map with minimum redundancy in terms of information content. The number of class intervals can be directly computed by means of appropriate statistical methods if the widths of classes are determined by t-test, i.e. when their difference is significant at a high level of confidence. A class narrower than this width would represent data in different categories due only to variance, however, the selection of wider classes leads to a certain loss of information. The class intervals determined this way should be positioned on the statistical data-set so that each category contains approximately equal number of data providing maximum information content of the output map. At the final step the class intervals derived this way should be rounded, if necessary, to provide user-friendly maps. © 1987 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: map class interval; statistical determination

Title: Continental shapes on world projections: The design of a poly-centred oblique orthographic world projection
Affiliations: Georgia State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dent, B.D., Georgia State University, United States
Abstract: The map projection is considered an important variable among map design elements. In some instances cartographers need to consider projections on which continental shapes are closely preserved. The proposition offered here is that continental shapes are best preserved on the familiar orthographic projection. A world projection is devised by developing a composite of several orthographic views, each of which best illustrates the five major continents. Subjects were tested for judgments of continental centres, and these are used for orienting the oblique projections. The final composite world projection is new. This process demonstrates how the map projection and its selection is a dynamic part of overall map design. © 1987 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: oblique orthographic projection; projection

Title: The evolution, application and implications of strip format travel maps
Affiliations: The Pennsylvania State University, United States; Ferguson Map Company Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: MacEachren, A.M., The Pennsylvania State University, United States; Johnson, G.B., Ferguson Map Company Inc., United States
Abstract: Strip format maps have been used as an aid in travel throughout recorded history. The evolution of this map format from Roman times to the present is examined with emphasis on the interaction of map form and function. Particular attention is given to the range in abstractness of strip maps when used with different travel modes or applied to different kinds of travel and the relationship of strip map popularity to restrictions on travel at various points in time. The use of strip maps as spatial process descriptions of the environment is also considered in relation to a variety of travel contexts. © 1987 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: strip format map; travel map

Title: Some observations on map and book publishing in early America
Affiliations: University of Waterloo, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Brannon, G., University of Waterloo, ON, Canada
Abstract: Before printing was brought from England to Colonial America in 1638 the mapping of North America was conducted chiefly by the great European powers of the time. Ai colonization took root the craft of printing flourished, and a fledgling publishing industry emerged in the New World. This formative period of American publishing was beset by problems both technical and ethical until the end of the nineteenth century and is noted more for its prolific outpouring of printed material than for quality. © 1987 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: book publishing; map publishing; USA

Title: The mental image in cartographic communication
Affiliations: University of Nebraska, Omaha, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, M.P., University of Nebraska, Omaha, United States
Abstract: There has been considerable interest within cartography in the cognitive processes associated with cartographic communication. Mental imagery is thought to be an important part of cognition. It has been determined that such internal images have structural and functional properties similar to maps and may be used in answering questions based on information derived from maps. The long term function of maps in the process of cartographic communication is modelled in the form of a human geographic information system - analogous to similar computer systems. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: The search problem in automated map design
Affiliations: University College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wilkinson, G.G., University College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper examines the principal features of the classical mathematical search problem and considers this as a model for intelligent map design. Transformation of map design into search terms reveals where the primary difficulties lie in automating map design and elucidates deficiencies both in cartographic knowledge and in methods of spatial dataset abstraction. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: Using computers to catalogue map collections ‐ (Part 2)
Affiliations: University of Sussex, Brighton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Watt, I., University of Sussex, Brighton, United Kingdom; Browne, T.J., University of Sussex, Brighton, United Kingdom
Abstract: In December 1985 the authors published an article in The Cartographic Journal (Watt and Browne, 1985) describing the use of the proprietory database package called Datatrieve for cataloguing maps. This current article outlines the development and presentation of a ‘front-end” which effec-tively hides Datatrieve and turns the facility into a very flexible menu-driven system for map cataloguing. Attention is concentrated on how to use the catalogue rather than the methods used to establish and update the collection of maps, which would primarily be the responsibility of the Map Curator. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: Recent development and future trends in geo-information systems
Affiliations: Kingston Polytechnic, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wilkinson, G.G., Kingston Polytechnic, Canada; Fisher, P.F., Kingston Polytechnic, Canada
Abstract: Geographic information systems which store, manipulate and display spatially-referenced datasets have been in existence for many years. These systems have traditionally been used to handle digital map data in vector form, but more recently they have been used to handle raster-based imagery of the Earth’s surface. There is now a need to establish integrated geo-information systems (IGIS) based on major environmental databases with intelligent front-ends, and knowledge- based systems for data management, selection, integration and display. This paper reviews the developments in these areas and assesses the potential impact of advanced informa-tion technology in the IGIS field. © 1987 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: information technology; integrated geo information systems; map data

Title: CARTRIPS ‐ A cartographic route information presentation system
Affiliations: Norwegian Computing Centre, Oslo, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Robb, M.C., Norwegian Computing Centre, Oslo, Norway
Abstract: CARTRIPS is a computer system which produces personalised maps for motorists. The system allows motorists to select routes between towns or to find out where sites of interest and other travel facilities are located. This paper describes how the system operates, and shows how simple, low-cost maps can be produced quickly according to the motorist’s requirements. Results from testing of the system are also described. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: Automation in cartography - revolution or evolution?
Affiliations: National Mapping Division, U.S. Geological Survey, United States
Authors with affiliations: Southard, R.B., National Mapping Division, U.S. Geological Survey, United States
Abstract: The increasing sophistication in computer hardware, software, and data base development as applied to spatial data contains elements that are both revolutionary and evolutionary in nature. Capabilities in these areas continue to grow and improve but often are limited by comprehension on the part of producers and users, by lack of prudent planning, and by insufficient funds to accomplish identified objectives. In this complex situation, an important role is developing for cartographers with different skills than their predecessors, but with some similar functions: interpreting and representing spatial data for users, maintaining the spatial integrity of data and bringing expertise to the effective development of data bases responsive to a broad array of users. This paper describes aspects of the growth and development of this new role, based on experience at the U.S. Geological Survey. © 1987 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: computer hardware; sophistication; spatial data; USGS

Title: Fractal and automated line generalization
Affiliations: The University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Muller, J.C., The University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Abstract: The preservation of fractal dimension is proposed as a guiding standard for the automated generalization of statistically self-similar geographical lines. Testings on two different types of such lines show that none of the current generalization algorithms most frequently cited in the literature preserves fractal dimension and statistical self-similarity in a consistent fashion. The walking algorithm used to measure fractal dimension is suggested as an alternative method for generalization. The method not only preserves fractal dimension, it also produces generalized lines whose average angularity and overall displacement are very much in line with the best results provided by other generalization algorithms. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: CARTO-NET: A relational database approach to automated map cataloguing
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Healey, R., Department of Geography, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Morris, B., Department of Geography, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: Conventional automated cataloguing systems are efficient as general purpose systems, but have limitations for map holdings. Such systems are based on MARC records which nevertheless represent a national standard for bibliographic information interchange. However, the flexibility and im¬provement in efficiency of relational database systems offer enormous potential for new approaches to information management, including graphics-based data retrieval and automated graphic indexing. If they are to be widely used, and their potential realised however, it must be possible for them to store data in such a way that standardised records can be generated when required. The first stages in the implementation of a full-scale system of this kind for map cataloguing of sheets and their various editions within map series are described and the problems encountered discussed. The results of user-trials with the National Library of Scotland Map Room are assessed' and the place of such a system within a larger scheme of automated infonnation management for geographical enquiry is elaborated. © 1987 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic activities in the United Kingdom, 1984-1987
Abstract: A report to the eighth general assembly of the International Cartographic Association, 1987, prepared by the British Cartography sub-committee of the Royal Society National subcommittee for Geography. Seven main sections cover: 1. A general overview. 2. Cartographic organisations and interest groups. 3. Cartographic production. 4. Research Organisations. 5. Education, training and research. 6. Map storage and information about maps. 7. Publications about cartography. -after Author
Index Keywords: British Cartography Sub-committee; cartographic activity; UK

Title: The Directorate of Overseas Surveys and mapping in Nigeria.
Affiliations: Univ of Lagos, Nigeria., Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Balogun, O.Y., Univ of Lagos, Nigeria., Nigeria
Abstract: The Directorate of Overseas Surveys is the giant-tasked but small-establishment central mapping organisation that eventually salvaged British colonies from their state of maplessness. Its contribution to mapping in Nigeria is discussed in this paper.- Author

Title: The highland and agricultural society of scotland and the ordnance survey of scotland, 1837-1875
Affiliations: Department of Earth Sciences, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boud, R.C., Department of Earth Sciences, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: In a period, of economic and social change, the prestigious Highland and Agricultural Society adopted a national role inurging Government to improve the discontinuous and tardyprogress of the Ordnance Survey of Scotland. The story of theSociety’s forty-year struggle to obtain, for Scotland, surveyssuch as those of England and Ireland, is related against abackground of diverse and changing views regarding the scaleat which Scotland’s variable terrain was to be mapped. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Map data requirements for civil land vehicle navigation and location
Affiliations: Terrafix Ltd., Welwyn, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stratton, A., Terrafix Ltd., Welwyn, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The differing requirements of producers and users and the design of topographic/cartographic databases
Authors with affiliations: Haywood, P.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The benefits of improving the quality of information given to drivers
Affiliations: Wooton Jeffreys Ltd., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wooton, J., Wooton Jeffreys Ltd., United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Traffic-data-maps
Affiliations: Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kern, H.F., Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: To digitise or not to digitise?
Affiliations: Automobile Association, Basingstoke, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Robbins, R., Automobile Association, Basingstoke, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Inertial survey and the collection of data base information
Affiliations: Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davidson, J., Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Chart engraving at the hydrographic department 1951-1981
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cooney, R.J.L., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: This paper attempts to briefly explain and record the production methods of copper-plate based navigational charts, during the last thirty years of the craft, as practiced at the Department. It also describes the tools and how they were used, how corrections were made, the contribution of hand and photo-etching and copper-plate printing. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Jansson versus blaeu: A study in competitive response in the production of english county maps
Affiliations: 132 Joydens Wood Road, Bexley, Kent, DA5 2HT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D., 132 Joydens Wood Road, Bexley, Kent, DA5 2HT, United Kingdom
Abstract: Amsterdam was the centre of atlas production in the first half of the seventeenth century. A highly competitive situation developed between rival map-producing houses; specifically between those of Blaeu and Jansson. The course of this competition in the production of English county maps is charted in this paper; the decoration of the maps is analysed in an attempt to deduce who developed what and who plagiarised whom. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: The human scope of cartography-towards a new national atlas of the Netherlands
Affiliations: University of Ultrecht, United States
Authors with affiliations: De Smidt, M., University of Ultrecht, United States
Abstract: Twenty volumes of a new Atlas of the Netherlands, for which a problem-oriented approach is chosen, are published. In this article the chairman of the editorial committee deals with the scope and selection of themes for such a project. Preparing an atlas for a broad public without losing the firm foundation of modem cartographic information handling and scientific geographic analysis presents a challenge. This paper was delivered at the 25th International Geographical Congress in Paris 1984. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Map use and map making education: Attention to sources of geographic information
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacEachren, A.M., Pennsylvania State University, United States
Abstract: Due to changes in the nature of cartography and its role in geographic study, we must carefully evaluate our approach to cartographic instruction. Emphasized here is the need in both map making and map use education to direct attention to selection and organization of geographic information. Specifically, three objectives are addressed: 1) to present an overview of data selection and organization implications in map making and use, 2) to provide examples for use in the classroom as illustrations of concepts presented, and 3) to suggest student activities that emphasize potential effects of data selection and organization when making and using maps. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: The commonality of computer-assisted procedures for constructing choropleth and isarithmic maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT, 06268, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cromley, R.G., Department of Geography, University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT, 06268, United States
Abstract: In the transition from traditional forms of mapping to computer-assisted techniques, many manual tasks were converted directly into automated procedures. Focusing on the form of the final map product, cartographers developed totally distinct algorithms for the display of choroplethic and isarithmic maps. However, both types of maps can be stored as a digital image using a triangular data structure. A more general display algorithm is presented to transform the digital images into their respective graphic forms. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A method of assessing the accuracy of cartographic digitising tables
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rollin, J.R., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Ordnance Survey currently operates over fifty digitising tables in its programme of converting large-scale plans into digital form for computer storage and manipulation. In order to maintain the accuracy of the archive, only high quality digitising tables are used. This paper describes a simple method of testing the accuracy of digitising tables to ensure that they meet the required standard prior to purchase and that they continue to perform to this standard in normal production. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: digitising tables; large scale plans; Ordnance Survey

Title: Thematic contents of maps: Some theoretical approaches in the development of modelling methods
Affiliations: Moscow State University, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Tikunov, V.S., Moscow State University, Russian Federation
Abstract: Perspective approaches in the development of methods for modelling thematic contents of maps are described. The necessity of contents analysis of the data base, mathematical models and presentation techniques is emphasised. Problems of multivariant approach and reliability assessment in the modelling of maps’ thematic contents are outlined. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Mapping sciences at north east london polytechnic
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sorrell, P.E., Department of Land Surveying, United States
Abstract: What is now the Department of Land Surveying at the North East London Polytechnic offered its first course, in land surveying, in 1949. Since that date the Department has achieved a world wide reputation in Land Surveying. In addition various specialist areas such as photogrammetry, cartography, sea surveying and cadastre, and more recently land information management and digital mapping, have developed to the extent that the Department of Land Surveying is recognised as a major centre for education in the Mapping Sciences. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A human-performance based evaluation of topographic maps and map symbols with novice map users
Affiliations: University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shurtleff, M., University of California, Los Angeles, United States; Edward Geiselman, R., University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: Experiment 1 was designed to determine which terrain map symbols commonly used on topographic maps are viewed as most representative of their referents by novice map users. Subjects were asked to rank alternative symbols for 17 topographic map features. In addition, every subject was required to construct their own symbol for each feature. For all but three of the features, certain symbol choices were unambiguously better than other choices. Equally desirable symbols were found to vary from being very simple to being quite complex for a number of the features. A symbology was derived from these results and was evaluated in a second human-performance based experiment. Subjects viewed both monochromatic or chromatic maps that were constructed from either the derived symbology or a control symbology consisting of geometric shapes. The subjects were asked to identify (interpret) or locate (search) specified map symbols. It was found that performance with the derived symbology was better than with the geometric symbology for both dependent measures, regardless of whether colour coding was used. Thus, the derived symbology is a promising alternative to color topographic maps, such that color coding could be used to portray important dimensions of overlaid foreground information. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Fractal dimension and inconsistencies in cartographic line representations
Affiliations: The University of Alberta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Muller, J.-C., The University of Alberta, Canada
Abstract: The effect of cartographic generalization on the fractal dimension of geographic lines is investigated. Fractal dimension of lines represented at various map scales is measured using an empirical approach. It is found that line dimensionality is altered through the process of generaliza-tion, an indication that some of the basic generic features which determine the geomorphology of a line are being distorted. The preservation of fractal dimension is proposed as a guiding standard for future implementation of generalization algorithms in automated cartography. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: automated cartography; generalization; geomorphology of a line; map scales

Title: Road data bases
Authors with affiliations: Bickmore, D.
Abstract: At the Euro Carto IV meeting held in Frankfurt in October 1985 one session was devoted to discussion of Road Data Bases and contributions were subsequently published. Further ad hoc meetings of interested persons have been held in April and June 1986 at King’s College, London and at the Automobile Association, Basingstoke. Notes on the meetings, summaries and longer extracts from some papers are provided. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Hill-shading and half-tone reproduction
Affiliations: University of the West Indies, Trinidad, Jamaica
Authors with affiliations: Cape, M.R., University of the West Indies, Trinidad, Jamaica
Abstract: Various factors affect the design, construction and reproduction of hill-shading as an element of relief representation. Although the principles and function of hill-shading may he widely understood, the practice is less well appreciated. As with most aspects of map making, the cartographer normally has a choice of methods and materials. The skills of the cartographer are put to best use if the half-tone process is discussed with the photographer before and during the creation of a hill-shading image. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Wiltshire S.E., Morris D.G., Beran M.A.
Title: Digital data capture and automated overlay analysis for basin characteristic calculation
Affiliations: Geomorphological Services Limited, 16 Bassett Court Newport Pagnell Buckinghamshire, United Kingdom; Institute of Hydrology, Oxfordshire, Wallingford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wiltshire, S.E., Geomorphological Services Limited, 16 Bassett Court Newport Pagnell Buckinghamshire, United Kingdom; Morris, D.G., Institute of Hydrology, Oxfordshire, Wallingford, United Kingdom; Beran, M.A., Institute of Hydrology, Oxfordshire, Wallingford, United Kingdom
Abstract: An extensive flood study of European territories prompted the development of an automatic procedure for computing catchment average indices of climate and physiography. A variety of digitising schemes have been employed to collect map-based thematic data, which have been reduced to square gridded format and stored on data rasters registered with the UTM co-ordinate system. Catchment boundaries have been digitised and the catchment areas have been similarly gridded and stored. The resulting ‘bit-maps’ of catchments can be efficiently overlaid onto a grid of thematic data to yield a set of node values contained by the catchment boundaries which provides the basis for the calculation of basin characteristics. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: bit maps; catchment areas; European; flood

Title: Strain analysis for geometric comparisons of maps
Affiliations: Ministry of Environment, Planning and Public Works, Athens, United States; Department of Geodesy and Surveying, University of Thessaloniki, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Boutoura, C., Ministry of Environment, Planning and Public Works, Athens, United States; Livieratos, E., Department of Geodesy and Surveying, University of Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: Based on the plane theory of elasticity a method is described due to which scalar invariant quantities are derived, useful as criteria for the geometric comparison of two maps representing the same area in common scale. A finite element type method is applied in order to compute strain parameters using translational-, rotation¬al- and scale-free coordinate differences of common points on the two maps under comparison. The interest of such a method in comparative map analyses is discussed and an actual example illustrates the whole procedure. © 1986 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The “dinomic” world map projection
Affiliations: Ely, Cambs, CB6 3DY, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baker, J.G.P., Ely, Cambs, CB6 3DY, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The Highland and Agricultural Society of Scotland and the Ordnance Survey of Scotland.
Affiliations: Dept of Earth Sciences, Univ of Leeds, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boud, R.C., Dept of Earth Sciences, Univ of Leeds, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: In a period of economic and social change, the prestigious Highland and Agricultural Society adopted a national role in urging Government to improve the discontinuous and tardy progress of the Ordnance Survey of Scotland. The story of the Society's forty-year struggle to obtain, for Scotland, surveys such as those of England and Ireland, is related against a background of diverse and changing views regarding the scale at which Scotland's variable terrain was to be mapped. -Author

Authors: Chang K.-T., Lenzen T., Antes J.
Title: The effect of experience on reading topographic relief information: Analyses of performance and eye movements
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of North Dakota, United States; Defense Mapping Agency, Aerospace Center, United States; Department of Psychology, University of North Dakota, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang, K.-T., Department of Geography, University of North Dakota, United States; Lenzen, T., Defense Mapping Agency, Aerospace Center, United States; Antes, J., Department of Psychology, University of North Dakota, United States
Abstract: Cartographers believe that experience plays a central role in high-order map reading tasks. The effect of experience on topographic map reading was tested in an experiment in which subjects viewed ten maps while their eye movements were recorded, and answered questions on absolute and relative heights. Experienced readers performed better on the questionnaire test, especially for the relative height portion. For maps that had distinctive relief features, experienced readers had shorter fixation durations (indicating less processing difficulty) and higher numbers of fixations (indicating greater attention) to areas containing absolute heights. Visual search by experienced readers was apparently guided by familiar patterns of contour lines that they had developed through experience. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Using computers to catalogue map collections
Affiliations: Geography Laboratory, University of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QN, United Kingdom; Computing Centre, University of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Watt, I., Geography Laboratory, University of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QN, United Kingdom; Browne, T.J., Computing Centre, University of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QH, United Kingdom
Abstract: This article encourages Map Curators to seriously consider the use of computers in cataloguing their map collections. The merits of such an approach compared with manual systems are assessed. Also, the preparation of such a computerised catalogue and the ways in which it can be used to search and retrieve relevant information are fully described. Many readers will not be particularly familiar with the use of computers and so technical details have been kept to a minimum. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Mapping the population census of Scotland
Affiliations: University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carruthers, A.W., University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Department of Geography at the University of Edinburgh has been contracted by the Scottish Development Department to produce a series of computer maps based on the 1981 Population Census of Scotland. A brief overview of the project will be delivered together with an outline of the problems and limitations encountered in designing maps for specific customers, who have little or no knowledge of computer cartography. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Moving towards an interactive tactual mapping environment
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lai, P.-C., Department of Geography, University of Maryland, United States
Abstract: The American Foundation for the Blind (AFB) has recently demonstrated at various professional meetings the first prototype Graphic Braille Display (GBD) unit, that is capable of generating graphics for the blind.
