The prototype GBD involves a low production cost and it has many undesirable features at this infant stage. However, it will open a whole new world of communicating graphics to the blind. This paper explores the adaptability of the GBD device in an interactive tactual mapping environment. The GBD display mode is compared with the raster mode of processing geographic map data. Current shortcomings, possible solutions, and research directions are suggested. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Maps on postage stamps as propaganda
Affiliations: MRLG, MCE RE, Tolworth, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davis, B., MRLG, MCE RE, Tolworth, United Kingdom
Abstract: Effective propaganda can be very useful in a war situation and one avenue open to governments is the postage stamp: this article shows how a propaganda war on territorial disputes can be sustained by means of maps on stamps. Examples chosen include the recent Falkland Islands conflict and the lesser known Chaco War between Bolivia and Paraguay pending up in Europe with two interesting cases. © 1985 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Bolivia; Europe; Falkland Islands; Paraquay; propaganda; stamps

Title: The peters phenomenon
Authors with affiliations: Loxton, J.
Abstract: In 1967 Dr Amo Peters made his first public claim to have designed a world map superior to Mercator and all others. Although professional cartographers have pointed out that the projection is not original or unique, the map has gained a not inconsiderable measure of political acceptance. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cognitive models and cartographic design research
Affiliations: Clark University, Worcester, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eastman, J.R., Clark University, Worcester, MA, United States
Abstract: System and processing models of visual/cognitive behaviour are examined for their potential contribution to cartographic design research. System models attempt to describe the cognitive system by a set of functional components, while processing models are concerned with the sequence of activities by which a cognitive act is performed. Through an examination of their application to discussions of cartography as a natural language and the problems of map learning and map complexity, it is concluded that current models have strong explanatory power. Of particular importance is the stress they place on the organisational nature of map reading and the active role of the reader in the cartographic process. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Some draft estate maps of the early seventeenth century
Affiliations: University of Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Woolgar, C.M., University of Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: Draft estate maps by Matthew Nelson and Thomas Langdon demonstrate the process of map-making in the early seventeenth century. The drafts result from plane table and theodolite surveys, with score marks indicating sighting or protraction lines. Further scoring transferred the drafts to parchment for engrossment, creating a clear distinction between field observations and the rich imagery of the completed map. © 1985 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Langdon; map making in the early 17th century; Nelson; plane table and theodolite surveys

Title: A difference in scale? Two digital mapping projects
Affiliations: Thematic Information Service, NERC, United States; Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, NERC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, N.J., Thematic Information Service, NERC, United States; Fuller, R.M., Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, NERC, United States
Abstract: The Thematic Information Service of NERC has been active in the field of automated cartography for a number of years (originally as the Experimental Cartography Unit) involving many types of map and map-based output. This process has led to the development of many different methods of production, manipulation and display techniques. In describing the progress of two large and very different projects the authors hope to illustrate some of the many possibilities and, perhaps, pitfalls of digital cartography. It will be shown that digital map output can actually be put to a useful purpose and not become simply an exercise in collecting digital data. © 1985 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: automated cartography; digital data; NERC; Thematic Information Service

Title: Topographical relief depiction by hachures with computer and plotter
Authors with affiliations: Yoeli, P.
Abstract: The introduction of lithographic reproduction methods for printing of maps instead of copper engraving techniques almost 150 years ago, has supplanted the use of hachures for cartographic relief depictions. The article explains how computers and plotters can he used to produce hachures based on an initial input of digital terrain models. Instead of using hachures, as in the past, as a possible means of topographic relief presentation only, it is suggested to utilise them as a source for the computer assisted treatment of morphometric topics. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: The so-called peters projection
Abstract: Readers of The Cartographic Journal will no doubt also be interested to read the considered view of the German Cartographic Society which has been translated for us in London by Mrs Jutta Müller and is reproduced below. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: John norden and his colleagues: Surveyors of crown lands
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence, H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Characteristic traits of the semiotic system ´map symbolism´
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Regina, Regina, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Schlichtmann, H., Department of Geography, University of Regina, Regina, Canada
Abstract: Map symbolism is a complex semiotic system with spatial and non-spatial components. Macrosigns (localized signs) are ultimately composed of minimal signs and in turn combine in texts. Accordingly, there are a local and a supra-local combinatorics (syntax), which are essentially different. Minimal expressions are jointly meaningful and distinctive, and distinction is differential or gradual. Signs are arbitrary or motivated, but motivation is a crucial trait of the system. Rules for linking expressions to contents are global or pertain to the individual map. Notwithstanding its semantic specialization, map symbolism is productive. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Nineteenth century maps: Some cartographical problems and solutions
Affiliations: Trent Polytechnic, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hunt, J., Trent Polytechnic, Nottingham, United Kingdom; Smith, R., Trent Polytechnic, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Those studying the growth patterns of nineteenth century settlements frequently need to consult a series of maps at different dates drawn to a common and manageable scale. This article discusses techniques for reproducing historical maps, which may be fragile or of large dimensions, to a common scale and so facilitate easier comparisons. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Innovative Cartography in palestine 1917-1918
Affiliations: The Hebrew University, Jerusalem, Israel; Tel Aviv University, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Gavish, D., The Hebrew University, Jerusalem, Israel; Biger, G., Tel Aviv University, Israel
Abstract: During the First World War a major turning-point in the history of cartography was made in Palestine. The British forces, which were marching toward Palestine, had no town maps of some of the key towns of Palestine. Towns situated beyond the front line, such as Gaza, Beer-Sheba, Ramleh and others were photographed by the Air Squadrons and maps of the towns were made. The first map, that of Gaza, was produced on 25 January, 1917 being probably the first town map ever made by the use of aerial photographs. Other maps, which were produced during 1918, like those of Nablus and El Kerak were maps which demonstrated a new solution to the problem of the use of aerial photographs for the purpose of mapping towns situated in hilly areas. Town maps for the Palestine Front were an immediate necessity, not an academic exercise and the war served as an immediate catalyst. The photographs and maps produced then are excellent historical documents, particularly because of their high quality and preservation. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: The design and perception of point symbols for tourist maps
Affiliations: Memorial University, St. John’s, Canada; Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Forrest, D., Memorial University, St. John’s, Canada; Castner, H.W., Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Abstract: The design of thematic point symbols involves encoding attributes of the object represented that will assist map users in (1) establishing the symbol’s meaning, but also (2) in finding it in visual search. Accepting experimental evidence that colour is the most useful sorting dimension, internal variations in per cent area inked and shape were examined ex¬perimentally in four types of tourist symbols, varying from abstract to pictographic. Results of a simple map reading experiment show that enclosing pictographic symbols with simple geometric frames’ significantly decreases their search time. The use of purely abstract symbols further reduces search times, but at the cost of significantly greater errors in identification. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Census planning and the recent improvements in aerial photographic imagery—the Nigerian example
Affiliations: University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Duru, R.C., University of Nigeria, Nsukka, Nigeria
Abstract: Aerial photo imagery has been suggested by recent writers on census cartography as the best source of new data depends on a number of technical factors. The factors include aerial camera lens and its focal length, film base, film emulsion and mounting, flight planning and operation, aerial survey platform and weather conditions. This paper discusses the parameters as they apply to the Nigerian situation. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: The future of the school pupils' desk Atlas
Affiliations: College of St. Mark and St. John Foundation, Plymouth, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sandford, H.A., College of St. Mark and St. John Foundation, Plymouth, United Kingdom
Abstract: The present nature, status and role of school pupils’ desk atlases in Britain are briefly described and placed in their global context. This reveals certain evolutionary tendencies which are discussed and evaluated, and it is concluded that some British examples are among the more progressive, especially those intended for younger children. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Map use in a small academic map library
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies, Sheffield University, United Kingdom; Department of Geography, Sheffield University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brack, E.V., Department of Information Studies, Sheffield University, United Kingdom; Chibnall, J., Department of Geography, Sheffield University, United Kingdom
Abstract: A record was made of map requests for one year in the Geography Department’s map library at Sheffield University. This is compared with other surveys of map use in university map libraries. The results show that the greatest use of the library is by students, mainly geography students, and that there was a relatively high use of thematic maps. The differences between the libraries compared are mainly due to the differing status and purposes of the libraries within their universities and thus their differing resources. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Title: Temperature and humidity variations in map storage areas
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pegg, R.K., Department of Geography, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom; Norris, G., Department of Geography, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Abstract: With the present cutbacks on educational expenditure some central heating systems are being switched off at weekends and during vacations. This paper examines the microclimatic characteristics in the Map Library of Liverpool University Geography Department during a weekend shutdown. The data collected showed a very wide range of temperature and humidity conditions, well outside that recommended for the safe storage and preservation of maps and documents. © 1985 Maney Publishing.

Authors: Chang K.-T., Antes J., Lenzen T.
Title: The effect of experience on reading topographic relief information: analyses of performance and eye movements.
Affiliations: Dept. Geog., Univ. of North Dakota, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang, K.-T., Dept. Geog., Univ. of North Dakota, USA., United States; Antes, J., Dept. Geog., Univ. of North Dakota, USA., United States; Lenzen, T., Dept. Geog., Univ. of North Dakota, USA., United States
Abstract: Cartographers believe that experience plays a central role in high-order map reading tasks. The effect of experience on topographic map reading was tested in an experiment in which subjects viewed 10 maps while their eye movements were recorded, and answered questions on absolute and relative heights. Experienced readers performed better on the questionnaire test, especially for the relative height portion. For maps that had distinctive relief features, experienced readers had shorter fixation durations (indicating less processing difficulty) and higher numbers of fixations (indicating greater attention) to areas containing absolute heights. Visual search by experienced readers was apparently guided by familiar patterns of contour lines that they had developed through experience.-Authors

Title: Cartographic activities in the United Kingdom, 1980-83.
Abstract: A report submitted to the 7th General Assembly of the International Cartographic Association, Perth, Western Australia, August 1984. Seven major headings are used: 1) general; 2) cartographic organisations and interest groups; 3) cartographic production; 4) research organisations; 5) education and training; 6) map storage and information about maps; 7) publications about cartography. Within these headings extensive details are provided of cartographic activities within agencies and institutions.- M.Blakemore

Title: Editorial
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence, G.R.P.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Letter
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The London School of Economics and Political Science, Houghton Street, London, WC2A 2AE, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Scolt, D.J., Department of Geography, The London School of Economics and Political Science, Houghton Street, London, WC2A 2AE, United Kingdom; Board, C., Department of Geography, The London School of Economics and Political Science, Houghton Street, London, WC2A 2AE, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Developments at the ordnance survey since 1981
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fraser, S., Ordnance Survey, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: data structuring; digital cartography; feature coding; new technology; OS

Title: Recognition of disoriented maps: The cognitive process
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, 29208, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lloyd, R., Department of Geography, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, 29208, United States; Steinke, T., Department of Geography, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, 29208, United States
Abstract: The focus of this research is on the cognitive process used by map readers to recognise disoriented maps. Results from reaction lime experiments suggested that map readers recognise maps that are not conventionally oriented by forming internal images of the maps and rotating them to familiar orientations. Because this process involves forming and comparing internal cognitive representations, maps with more information on them take longer to process. © 1984 Maney Publishing.

Title: Land registry maps in Palestine during the Ottoman period
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel; Department of Middle Eastern Studies, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kark, R., Department of Geography, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel; Gerber, H., Department of Middle Eastern Studies, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Polygon handling at the Experimental Cartography unit
Authors with affiliations: Drummond, J.E.
Abstract: Between 1979 and 1982 the Experimental Cartography Unit produced a series of crop suitability maps with the Land Resources Development Centre of the Overseas Development Administration using digital vector polygon generation and overlay techniques. This paper outlines ECU then current approach to digital polygon overlay, and those of some other organisations and briefly introduces the problems involved. © 1984 Maney Publishing.

Authors: Rhind D., Mounsey H., Hudson R., Lane A.
Title: Automated thematic mapping of the EEC
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Birkbeck College, University of London, United Kingdom; Department of Geography, University of Durham, United Kingdom; Computer Centre, Kings College, University of London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rhind, D., Department of Geography, Birkbeck College, University of London, United Kingdom; Mounsey, H., Department of Geography, Birkbeck College, University of London, United Kingdom; Hudson, R., Department of Geography, University of Durham, United Kingdom; Lane, A., Computer Centre, Kings College, University of London, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes the principles and practice of setting up a major statistical and cartographic data base for the EEC countries. Use of this for teaching and research purposes and in the construction of an atlas of the EEC is also described. The paper covers the need to cope with data at a variety of geographical resolutions and with hierarchical data structures. The problems arising from change of geographical boundaries through time is also addressed, as is that caused by ‘missing data’ for certain areas at certain moments of time. The software used is fully described. Some attention is devoted to the need to tailor the maps and other graphics to suit bureaucrats and decision-makers. © 1984 Maney Publishing.

Title: A triangulation data structure for choropleth base maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Connecticut, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cromley, R.G., Department of Geography, University of Connecticut, United States
Abstract: Most early methods for encoding choropleth maps have used the region or individual data zone as the organisational unit for storing the locational and topological properties of the map. This paper presents an alternative approach to encoding choropleth maps where the neighbourhood relationships are encoded using the node as the organisational unit. The direct relationship between choropleth base maps and a Thiessen diagram enables the same triangular data structures developed to store a Delauney triangulation to be used to store a choro¬pleth map. Individual polygons are retrieved by enumerating the sequence of nodes that comprise their outline in a clockwise manner. The commonality among the data structures for storing different types of maps should permit the development of general purpose display algorithms. © 1984 Maney Publishing.

Title: The map in schools: A key, a language and a set of skills
Affiliations: University of Leicester School of Education, Editor. Teaching Geography, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, P., University of Leicester School of Education, Editor. Teaching Geography, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Perceptions of variable similarity on bivariate choroplethic maps
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA, 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carstensen, L.W., Jr., Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA, 24061, United States
Abstract: The major function of a two-variable map is to depict the spatial variation in the relationship between the two variables mapped. This research studies the methods by which map readers interpret this relationship within each choropleth zone. Using two different map designs, the United States Bureau of the Census colour-coded map, and the continuous tone map, subjects were to form regions of contiguous zones based on perceived relationships between the variables. Both map reading groups performed the task satisfactorily; their methods of solution were similar, and the regions selected were very similar. Each map design produced reasonable results, and each showed some limitations. © 1984 Maney Publishing.

Title: Silk maps: The story of Mi9’s excursion into the world of cartography 1939-1945
Authors with affiliations: Bond, B.A.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Change of projection following readjustment
Affiliations: Survey of Israel and the Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Adler, R.K., Survey of Israel and the Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Israel; Papo, H.B., Survey of Israel and the Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Israel
Abstract: The readjustment of a major geodetic control network results in a new set of spheroidal coordinates for the network stations. Those new coordinates followed by an appropriate control densification serve as input for computing new plane coordinates. There are many surveying and mapping products which are based on the existing ‘old’ plane coordinates system. This paper deals with considerations and procedures aiming at the introduction of a new projection defined in such a way as to minimise the detrimental consequences of readjustment through the use of a synthetic point of origin for the new projection. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: geodetic control network; readjustment; spheroidal coordinates

Title: Minimum-error map projections bounded by polygons
Affiliations: U.S. Geological Survey, 521 National Center, Reston, VA, 22092, United States
Authors with affiliations: Snyder, J., U.S. Geological Survey, 521 National Center, Reston, VA, 22092, United States
Abstract: In 1856 Chebyshev stated that if a conformal map projection of a region is bounded by a line of constant scale, the projection has the minimum possible scale error for the region. It is possible to develop such lines which closely approximate ovals, regular polygons or rectangles, using the well-established complex-algebra transformation of the Stereographic projection. Since a map is usually bounded, by a rectangle, the use of appropriate transformation coefficients to achieve lines approaching this shape permits the design of conformal sheet maps with less distortion than that found on other projections. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: A cluster analysis model for predicting visual clusters
Affiliations: University of Kansas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Slocum, T.A., University of Kansas, United States
Abstract: The communication of spatial information is enhanced if geographers are able to predict the patterns that map readers perceive. By comparing predicted patterns with their own, geographers can decide whether or not a map will portray the intended message. One way to accomplish this goal is to model the way in which readers combine symbols to form patterns. For this purpose, the mathematical technique of cluster analysis is used to simulate how readers visually cluster circles on graduated symbol maps. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: The compilation map: A technique for topographic mapping by British Colonial Survey
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stone, J.C., Department of Geography, The University, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: Demand for topographic maps in the early decades of British colonial rule in Africa seemingly resulted in maps compiled from diverse sources of variable authority. Taking Northern Rhodesia as a case study, it is shown that compilation mapping continued almost to independence. Unless the territory was unusual, compilation mapping represents a distinctive phase in the history of British colonial topographic mapping. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: The science of cartography in China
Affiliations: Wuhan Technical University of Surveying and Mapping, China
Authors with affiliations: Daosheng, D., Wuhan Technical University of Surveying and Mapping, China
Abstract: The intention in presenting this paper is to portray the growth and current state of cartographic development in the People’s Republic of China. The depiction will take three main foci, namely, (i) Organisation, (ii) Cartographic Education, (Hi) General Mapping Activity. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Computer mapping using a highway design package
Affiliations: Dept. of Surveying, University of Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Survey Section, Dept. of Engineering, Tyne and Wear County Council, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fairbairn, D., Dept. of Surveying, University of Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Bradford, J., Survey Section, Dept. of Engineering, Tyne and Wear County Council, United Kingdom
Abstract: A general introduction to the state of computer assisted mapping is followed by a more specific look at the situation in local authorities. The MOSS package which is popular for highway design purposes in engineering and survey departments is shown to be suitable, also, for derived mapping in a local authority environment. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Problems of cartographic representation of patterns of population change
Affiliations: Department of Town and Regional Planning, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Forbes, J., Department of Town and Regional Planning, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: Distribution maps of social and economic data are frequently used to diagnose the location of “problem areas”, requiring public policy and action. The paper demonstrates, with population data, how mapped patterns can often be the products of the size and shape of the spatial and temporal units chosen by the map compiler. The problem is not appreciated by most policy makers. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartography in advertising
Affiliations: Hurst Land Surveys, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharkey, M.F., Hurst Land Surveys, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: This short paper attempts to pursue an analytical account of the cartography in present day advertising. Particular reference is made to the printed advertisements in newspapers, brochures and periodicals available in Britain. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Mapping across the high street
Authors with affiliations: Walters, A.J.
Abstract: The Ordnance Survey is now not only a major map producer but a publisher. Its product range includes material previously only supplied by the commercial map makers. Through the use of new technology even greater market opportunities will come the way of the Survey. It could transform the way we think of maps and the way in which we buy them. If the commercial sector are to prosper then they too will have to start planning for the future. © The British Cartographic Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Ordnance Survey; UK

Title: A little, round, fat, oily man of god": Rev patrick murdoch and his contributions to eighteenth-century cartography and geography
Authors with affiliations: Maling, D.H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Toward an understanding of scale and its relevance to cartographic communication
Affiliations: Alberta Bureau of Surveying and Mapping, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Henning, M.D., Alberta Bureau of Surveying and Mapping, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Abstract: The content of this paper is to express the concept of scale in a more precise mathematical statement rather than simply a ratio of dimensions on a map to the actual dimensions the map represents. While all cartographers can benefit from new perspectives on an old topic, the paper is directed to new students of cartography who need a methodology for their studies, of which scale will play a very important part. © 1983 Maney Publishing.

Title: The use of maps: The topographic and thematic traditions contrasted
Authors with affiliations: Barbour, M.
Abstract: This study of the maps used to illustrate printed hooks on geographical topics shows that the number of such maps per book has substantially increased between A.D. 1500 and 1920, with a shift from simple outlines of land and sea, often borrowed from other sources, to more sophisticated representations of statistics and other distributions, often specially drawn. The printing of maps side by side to illustrate either temporal changes or similarities between distributions is shown to be an ancient practice, recently revived, while differences between authors in temperament and intellectual tradition also influence the maps they use to illustrate their books. © 1983 Maney Publishing.

Title: Problem solving on maps-the importance of user strategies
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Adelaide, SA, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Griffin, T.L.C., Department of Geography, University of Adelaide, SA, Australia
Abstract: An increasing proportion of cartographic research is directed at the responses of the map user, but little is known of the methods employed to arrive at those responses. Reports from test subjects required to solve a cartographic problem indicate that they had evolved a variety of strategies to assist them in task solution. The varying nature of those strategies is shown to have a pronounced impact upon the level of subject performance. It is suggested that knowledge of the methods devised by relatively inexperienced subjects to solve map problems should be of concern both to those involved in map design and in the instruction of map users. © 1983 Maney Publishing.

Title: Photographic, polyfocal and polar-diagrammatic mapping of atmospheric pollution
Affiliations: Survey of Israel and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Survey of Israel and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: In order to display, predict and combat atmospheric pollution, suitable graphics should be employed. The author proposes some new methods of representation such as mapping air pollution on an air photograph which is printed through screens proportional to air purity, or using the Polyfocal Projection for mapping airport noise. Polar diagrams are used to depict atmospheric stability states. © 1983 Maney Publishing.

Title: Sources for relief representation techniques
Affiliations: Southwest Texas State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandes, D., Southwest Texas State University, United States
Abstract: A wide variety of cartographic procedures may he used to represent various aspects of the earth’s surface forms. Some of those procedures, however, are rarely used and apparently unfamiliar to many cartographers. The present compendium of techniques may he used as a resource document by which cartographers can quickly become aware of a wide variety of procedures and find references that may be used to obtain more information about them. © 1983 Maney Publishing.

Title: Aesthetic preferences for the proportions and forms of graticules
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Victoria, British Columbia, VIC, V8W 2Y2, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Gilmartin, P.P., Department of Geography, University of Victoria, British Columbia, VIC, V8W 2Y2, Canada
Abstract: In addition to their mathematical and cartographic charac¬teristics, earth graticules can be viewed as simple geometric forms having certain properties of shape, proportion, size, and texture. Results of many studies in experimental aesthetics suggest that the proportion of 1:1.6, the golden proportion, may have special universal appeal. A paired comparison experiment was conducted to determine whether people have any consistent preferences for the proportions and shapes of graticules. Elliptical and rectangular figures which ranged in proportion from 1:1.0 to 1:2.5 were used. A strong preference was found for ellipses over rectangles, but there was not evidence of a ‘golden graticule’ in the proportion of 1:1.6. Rather, more compact dimensions were preferred in both types of figures. © 1983 Maney Publishing.

Title: Editorial note
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence, G.R.P.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Map librarianship in the united states*: A personal view
Affiliations: University of Illinois, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cobb, D.A., University of Illinois, IL, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Ptolemy and the early image of the old world
Affiliations: Chief Cartographer, Survey of Israel, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Chief Cartographer, Survey of Israel, Israel
Abstract: A cartographic symposium held at Ulm in November 1982 was stimulated by the 500th anniversary of the printing of Ptolemy’s ‘Geographica’ in that city, and was attended by an international gathering of historical cartographers. © 1983 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Natural legend design for thematic maps
Affiliations: Department of Cartography, Warsaw University, Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Pasławski, J., Department of Cartography, Warsaw University, Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Satellite imagery as an aid to bathymetric charting in the red sea
Affiliations: Royal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, United Kingdom; Hydrographic Department, Taunton, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benny, A.H., Royal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, United Kingdom; Dawson, G.J., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, MA, United States
Abstract: Bathymetric (water depth) information may in some circumstances be obtained from Landsat MSS imagery, especially in bands 4 and 5. The techniques, described by others, normally make use of local information, such as the attenuation coefficient of light in sea water, obtained at the region being examined. This paper describes a relatively simple method for obtaining depth contours. For regions which have not been extensively surveyed but for which a small amount of depth information has been obtained by conventional means, these contours can provide a useful supplement, providing information economically over a wide area. The technique is applied here to a region at the northern end of the Red Sea. © 1983 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: depth contours; Landsat MSS

Title: Digital terrain models and their cartographic and cartometric utilisation
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Yoeli, P., Department of Geography, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel
Abstract: The article discusses the various types of surveyed digital terrain models the points of which are assumed to describe a surface approximating the true earth surface; these models being differentiated by the surveying process only. The suitability of the various model types as an input for computer assisted cartographic utilisation is discussed and judged from the point of view of a relief cartographer with a geodetic, photogrammetric and geomorphological background. The pure mathematical analysis of digital terrain models is rejected in principle and a spatially-geometrical approach recommended. The necessity for mathematical interpolation of secondary DTMs based on surveyed values as input for computer assisted cartographic products is doubted and the opinion is expressed that cartographic andlor cartometric evaluation should be based directly on the approximation surface described by the surveyed values irrespective of the geometric disposition. © 1983 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Stereoscopic coral maps from underwater photogrammetry
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering and Surveying, University of Newcastle, Newcastle, NSW, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Fryer, J.G., Department of Civil Engineering and Surveying, University of Newcastle, Newcastle, NSW, Australia
Abstract: A block of 360 overlapping photographs were taken underwater with a Nikonos III 35 mm camera fitted with a wide angle 15 mm Nikkor lens. The photographs cover a sloping area, 40 metres by 10 metres, on Broadhurst Reef (Queensland) from a depth of 2.1 metres to 26.2 metres. Ninety-nine steel pegs were surveyed and used as ground control stations for the subsequent photogrammetric adjustment. The collinearity equations of analytical photogram-metry were used to extract three-dimensional co-ordinates for the coral colonies. Two hundred of the coral colonies shown on the photographs were chosen for depiction in map form. Stereoscopic maps were constructed to illustrate the spatial relationship of the coral colonies. © 1983 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Computer-assisted cartography—the dilemma facing british producers of derived mapping in the 1980s
Affiliations: George Philip and Son Limited, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Poynter, A., George Philip and Son Limited, United Kingdom
Abstract: This article is based upon a paper given to a seminar of the Publisher’s Association’s Map and Guide Group in November 1981. It examines the dilemma facing British commercial mapping houses in considering computer-assisted cartography and suggests some solutions. The views expressed are the author's own and are not necessarily those of his employers. © 1983 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Computerised land use suitability mapping
Affiliations: California State Polytechnic University, United States; San Diego State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lyle, J., California State Polytechnic University, United States; Stutz, F.P., San Diego State University, United States
Abstract: Land use suitability mapping is a technique which can help find the best location for a variety of developmental actions given a set of goals and other criteria. The mapping technique is based on natural and human processes and analyses the interactions among three sets of factors: location, development actions, and environmental effects. The technique can yield three types of maps: a map showing what land use will cause the least change in environmental processes, a map showing qualitative predictions of environmental impacts of proposed developments, and given certain developmental actions to be carried out and specific environmental actions to be controlled, a map showing the most and least suitable locations for those actions. Two case studies are given in which suitability mapping was used as a tool to help local, state, and federal agencies formulate public policy regarding land use decisions in coastal Southern California. © 1983 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: California South; environmental impacts; land use suitability mapping

Title: An evaluation of the use of grid squares in computerised choropleth maps.
Affiliations: Computing Centre, Univ. of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QH, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Browne, T.J., Computing Centre, Univ. of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QH, UK., United Kingdom; Millington, A.C., Computing Centre, Univ. of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QH, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: There are numerous computer programs to produce choropleth maps and some work has also been published on the use of a grid matrix as a way of dividing an area into discrete units. The purpose of this paper is to combine the two approaches and evaluate the suitability of using a network of grid cells each containing a representative value of the variable being mapped, as a way of producing choropleth maps on a computer. -Authors

Title: International cartography
Authors with affiliations: Ormeling, F.J.; Lawrence, G.R.P.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The Ordnance Survey: The background to the secretary of state's proposals
Abstract: Recent editions of the Cartographic Journal have included references to the current Parliamentary activities in which there is a proposal to change the financing of the Ordnance Survey from its own Vote account to a Trading Fund status. A meeting at the Royal Geographical Society on 18th January 1982 was attended by a large number of cartographers, surveyors and others concerned at the proposal. An introductory background paper to the discussion was provided at that meeting and it is reproduced, with permission, below. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: Eyes right… map production in a military survey unit
Authors with affiliations: Shellswell, M.A.
Abstract: The peacetime technical role, capabilities and scope of work of 13 Map Production Squadron are presented in the context of the requirements for geographic products that are placed on the Director of Military Survey, United Kingdom. The TACIPRINT battlefield support system is described, a useful cartographic planning procedure is presented and the Unit’s approach to meeting rapid production tasks is reviewed. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: The dual axis Fourier shape analysis of closed cartographic forms
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Ohio State University, Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moellering, H., Department of Geography, Ohio State University, Columbus, United States; Rayner, J.N., Department of Geography, Ohio State University, Columbus, United States
Abstract: The authors have developed an approach to the harmonic analysis of closed cartographic forms in the complex domain called Dual Axis Fourier Shape Analysis (DAFSA) which is a significant improvement over earlier harmonic shape analysis techniques. DAFSA is based on the variance spectrum and modulus ratio spectrum as the fundamental Fourier shape descriptors for analysis and interpretation. Any closed cartographic form can be decomposed into its respective harmonic frequency components which can be rationally interpreted in terms of the contribution that a specific frequency and related attributes of it are making to the shape in question. As such the DAFSA descriptors are independent of scale, translation, rotation and starting point of the figure. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic production diagrams: A proposal for a standard notation system
Affiliations: University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Shearer, J.W., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: Cartographie production flow diagrams, which give a sequential representation of the various processes, operations and materials involved in the production of a map, are important in planning and organisation. They also are valuable in cartographic education. These aspects are discussed; then follows a proposal for a standard notation system for flow diagrams together with explanation and examples of its practical use. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: Natural legend design for thematic maps
Affiliations: The Cart-O-Graphics Laboratory, Department of Geography, University of Idaho, United States; Resource Inventory Section, Washington State Department of Natural Resources, United States
Authors with affiliations: DeLucia, A.A., The Cart-O-Graphics Laboratory, Department of Geography, University of Idaho, United States; Hiller, D.W., Resource Inventory Section, Washington State Department of Natural Resources, United States
Abstract: The legend of a thematic map is crucial to the map interpretation process because the reader depends upon it to decode and comprehend the map symbols used. The symbol dimensions and patterns in the legend should be as identical as possible with those used on the map to avoid confusion and reduce inefficiency in the information communication process. Re-designing standard legend formats so that legend symbols are seen in a visual context more closely resembling their actual situations within the body of the map may significantly improve the efficiency of map information processing. An experiment was conducted to determine whether map reading performance efficiency could be improved using a ‘natural’ legend design versus a standard or conventional legend design. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: The effect of map orientation on human spatial orientation performance
Affiliations: University of Ife, Ife, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Adeyemi, E.O., University of Ife, Ife, Nigeria
Abstract: The focus in this research is on the problem that map users have in using maps which are not conventionally oriented and the exploration of the effect of showing some compass directions as marginal information. Performances of map users who face geographic north were compared with their performances when they face other directions. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic materials and MARC
Affiliations: MRLG, MCE RE, Tolworth, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Webster, G., MRLG, MCE RE, Tolworth, United Kingdom
Abstract: The paper discusses the MARC (Machine Readable Catalogue) format, its inception by the Library of Congress and their adaptation of the format for the exchange of records of bibliographic descriptions of maps. Other national libraries have developed similar formats for their map records, encouraged by international developments in both cataloguing and exchange format standards; UNIMARC for cartographic materials is particularly described. UK developments have started only recently with the possible enchancement of the UK MARC format the objectives of which are discussed. © 1982 Maney Publishing.

Title: Recreational map design and map use: An experiment
Affiliations: Simon Fraser University, Canada; The University of Calgary, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Yarnal, C.M.M., Simon Fraser University, Canada; Coulson, M.R.C., The University of Calgary, Canada
Abstract: The paper examines the influence of map use and map design upon trail use in a recreational area, the Lake O’Hara area, Yoho National Park, Canada. Three test map designs were used and a questionnaire conducted on both map users and non-map users. Map users in general were found to make more use of the trails than those not using maps. Particularly noticeable was the effect of colour; this appeared to be a positive enhancement to both map use and trail use. © 1982 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Canada; colour map design; Lake O'Hara; trail use; Yoho National Park

Authors: Gordon D., Kellerman A., Waterman S.
Title: On the computation of the cross of dispersion
Affiliations: Department of Computer Studies, United States; Department of Geography, United States; Department of Geography, University of Haifa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gordon, D., Department of Computer Studies, United States; Kellerman, A., Department of Geography, United States; Waterman, S., Department of Geography, University of Haifa, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Design of maps for military use
Authors with affiliations: Whittington, I.F.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: An investigation of visual clutter in the topographic base of a geological map
Affiliations: Shell Centre for Mathematical Education, Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom; 33 Downside Crescent, London, NW3 2AN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, R.J., Shell Centre for Mathematical Education, Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom; Noyes, L., 33 Downside Crescent, London, NW3 2AN, United Kingdom
Abstract: Visual clutter on maps is a familiar experience but its precise nature is only poorly understood. Clutter was investigated in an experiment using a 1:50 000 geological map. Twelve representative map reading tasks were used to compare map reading performance on maps which differed only in their topographic base. The aim was to assess the effect of removing topographic symbols which are of only minor importance to the map reader. This reduction in visual clutter significantly improved performance on a number of the questions. Some evidence was obtained to support the hypothesis that line symbols clutter other line symbols, and point symbols clutter other point symbols, but there is little effect between the two. In practical terms the removal of minor point symbols and type led to larger improvements than the removal of minor line symbols, even though more of the latter were deleted. The relevance of the experiment to other geological maps, and to maps in general, is discussed. © 1982 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The District map: An Episode in British Colonial cartography in Africa, with particular reference to Northern Rhodesia
Affiliations: University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stone, J.C., University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: Extant manuscript topographic maps of parts of former Northern Rhodesia are evidence of a little known episode in the history of colonial mapping in Africa. The district map is described, and the circumstances and methods of its construction is investigated. Early published maps may in part derive from manuscript district maps. The cartographic work of a former District Officer is reviewed. © 1982 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The directorate of overseas surveys: Colonial development and overseas aid
Affiliations: Queen’s University, Kingston, Canada
Authors with affiliations: McGrath, G., Queen’s University, Kingston, Canada
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: aerial photography; geodetic; Landsat imagery; mapping; topographic surveys; triangulation

Title: An international study of children's perception understanding of type used on atlas maps
Affiliations: Brisbane College of Advanced Education, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gerber, V., Brisbane College of Advanced Education, Australia
Abstract: Little empirical consideration has been given to the usefulness of type for place names on atlas maps for school children. Most previous studies have been concerned with older map users and the conclusions from such studies have generally been applied to younger map users. This study investigates the perceptions and understanding by 160 school children in Australia and England of three different typefaces presented individually or in combination in map form. The study aims to establish which of the selected typefaces is easiest to read and which is preferred by the school children. The children overwhelmingly preferred and understood best a combination of Univers Medium and Univers Bold Condensed typefaces. Children over fifteen years of age were more tolerant of a variety of typefaces. © 1982 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Multi-component quantitative mapping
Affiliations: University of North Dakota, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang, K.-T., University of North Dakota, United States
Abstract: Multi-component quantitative mapping refers to the mapping of two or more variables and is useful in depicting their spatial relationships. Recent developments in map perception, remote sensing, and computer mapping have encouraged cartographers to pay closer attention to multicomponent quantitative maps. Five different methods of multi-component mapping considerations are discussed: Conventional mapping method, classification method, map overlay/map series method, index mapping method, and bivariate!multivariate analysis method. Whenever applicable, map samples are also included. © 1982 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Copyright and the electronic map.
Authors with affiliations: Davies, J.
Abstract: A discussion of the implications of copyright and digital map data. The difficulties of enforcing copyright on geographical databases is discussed, and various possible answers evaluated. The author concludes that considerable cooperation will be required between map-makers and the geographical community particularly in respect to licensing of digital data and reimbursement for its use. -M.Blakemore

Title: Cartographic materials: a manual of interpretation for the Anglo- American cataloguing rules (edition 2).
Authors with affiliations: Tyacke, S.; Fairclough, R.
Abstract: An international meeting of map librarians determined that the second edition of the Anglo-American Cataloguing rules could usefully be supplemented by a specific user manual. The paper describes the decision making process and the eventual format of the manual to be published by the UK Library Association in 1982. -M.Blakemore

Authors: Gordon D., Kellerman A., Waterman S.
Title: On the computation of the cross of dispersion.
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Studies, Univ. of Haifa, Israel., Israel
Authors with affiliations: Gordon, D., Dept. of Computer Studies, Univ. of Haifa, Israel., Israel; Kellerman, A., Dept. of Computer Studies, Univ. of Haifa, Israel., Israel; Waterman, S., Dept. of Computer Studies, Univ. of Haifa, Israel., Israel
Abstract: Contribution detailing the computation of the cross of dispersion, or standard deviational ellipse. This useful cartographic symbol has been neglected, probably due to difficulties of calculation. Minicomputers can be used to automate the formulae. -M.Blakemore

Title: Cartography and the mind of man
Authors with affiliations: Gardiner, R.A.
Abstract: The paper is concerned with the channel of communication between the cartographer and the mind of the map-user: The human eye and the viewing environment. Of man's five senses, only two, sight and sound, are extensively used for communication. One major use of sight in the acquisition of knowledge is still the reading of text, in effect a substitute for speech. Cartography provides a means of communication, using sight directly. Its development as a means of transmitting spatial information is outlined, and the basic limitations are noted. The physical characteristics of the human eye and their influence on cartographic design in varying circumstances are examined, as are the problems and advantages in the use of colour. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: communication; information; map user; perception

Title: Land use mapping in the 1980s
Authors with affiliations: Balchin, W.G.V.
Abstract: The Land Decade Educational Council meeting in April 1980 was reported in the Cartographic Journal for June 1980 (17, 2, page 110). The introduction and three of the presented papers are given below. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: cartography; decision making processes; Land Decade Educational Council; Land Utilisation Surveys

Title: The signed Chi-score measure for the classification and mapping of polychotomous data
Affiliations: Geography Department, University of Hull, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Visvalingam, M., Geography Department, University of Hull, United Kingdom
Abstract: Several polychotomous characteristics, when expressed in chi-score form, exhibit distributions in property space which deviate from the inherent assumptions of the more commonly used methods of cluster analysis. This paper suggests a novel approach to classification which exploits the observed and inferred characteristics of categorised data. The concepts and methods are applied to data on household composition to extract a demographic typology from the one-kilometre grid square population census data for 1971. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: categorised data; census; demographic

Title: Is the British cartographic society in the Doldrums
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: Text of a speech made by the Author~ a Past President of the Society~ at the Annual Symposium at Liverpool~1980~ as a contribution to the session' Is Cartography in the Doldrums?'. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The history of land use mapping
Authors with affiliations: Wallis, H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Domesday Book; estate maps; military; surveys; topographical surveys

Title: Competence and performance in cartographic language
Affiliations: Social Studies Department, Kelvin Grove College of Advanced Education, Brisbane, 4059, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gerber, R.V., Social Studies Department, Kelvin Grove College of Advanced Education, Brisbane, 4059, Australia
Abstract: How do individuals develop an understanding (i.e. competence) and an ability to use (i.e .performance) the language of signs found on maps? An understanding of the concepts of competence and performance in cartographic language is derived from research into psycholinguistics and psychology. The concept of competence hinges on the individual's ability to comprehend cartographic signs. Competence and a range of individual attributes are important influences on an individual's development of performance in cartographic language. Emphasis is placed on children's development of competence and performance in cartographic language. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Using the department of transport's road network databank to produce route planning maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Morrison, A., Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Proofing and the cartographer
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dixon-Gough, R.W., Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: Proofing is one of the most important stages in multi colour map production, in which all components of a map are brought together in a single form for the first time. This stage may be considered to be the ultimate cartographic check. The requirements of an ideal cartographic proof are discussed and a number of proofing systems are examined. The equipment required for each proofing system is given together with the costs involved. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Patterns of map use
Affiliations: Edinburgh University Library, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ferro, D.P., Edinburgh University Library, United Kingdom
Abstract: The utility and limitations of surveys of map use in libraries are discussed in the light of a survey at Bd2'nburgh University Library. Although a cautious approach is urged, their value for administrative purposes, and their complementary role to other descriptions of map use, are demonstrated. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: An examination of various cartometric vertical accuracy tests
Affiliations: Mapping and Charting Establishment, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ley, R.G., Mapping and Charting Establishment, United Kingdom
Abstract: The various vertical map accuracy tests may be divided into cartometrically derived methods, in which the map is tested against more accurate material, and theoretically determined errors, in which accuracy is assumed to be a function of contour interval and planimetrie error. The theoretically derived values are outlined but the paper concentrates on five different cartometric techniques applied to the same large-scale German mapping. The methodology of each is discussed and the results assessed. It is concluded that the vertical systematic interpolation technique generates the most objective and comprehensive values of vertical accuracy of the cartometric tests analysed. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: contour interval; interpolation; map; planimetric error

Title: The problem of the shifted grid
Authors with affiliations: Himiyama, Y.
Abstract: The use of a regular sampling technique based on a grid is examined and the effect of grid displacement calculated. A simple distribution (binary) is used in the calculation which is compared with the effects of the occurrence of joins. It is concluded that statistically, the count of 'yes-cells' is a more reliable indicator than that of joins. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Hydrological data on large scale maps of the ordnance survey
Affiliations: Formerly Geography Department, Southampton University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Oven Den, J.C., Formerly Geography Department, Southampton University, United Kingdom
Abstract: The accuracy of hydrological data portrayed on present and past editions of Ordnance Survey 1:10560 and 1:2500 series maps is examined by reference to official instruction manuals issued to the Ordnance Surveyors. These manuals have enabled the ‘blue-line’ networks to be qualified and results indicate that comparison of drainage networks on maps of different dates is feasible. Editions suitable for drainage network analysis are selected and their drainage networks compared for an area within the New Forest perambulation. Substatztial changes in the drainage network are suggested over the last fifty years which appear to represent real changes in drainage network extent. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: accuracy; drainage networks; New Forest; UK

Title: Is cartography in the doldrums?—a personal view
Authors with affiliations: Collinson, A.S.
Abstract: This paper describes the 3 main aspects of cartography and concludes that while academic and manipulative cartography may be flourishing the essential force which gives meaning to the craft is a fast diminishing commodity. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Mapping semi-natural vegetation
Authors with affiliations: Sinclair, G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: boundary identification; description; ordering; remote sensing; semi natural vegetation; species identification

Title: Towns on maps
Affiliations: College of St Mark and St John Foundation, Plymouth, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sandford, H.A., College of St Mark and St John Foundation, Plymouth, United Kingdom
Abstract: The built-up area of towns and cities is the most significant of Man's environments and one of the most clearly defined on the ground, yet it is. inadequately portrayed and inaccurately delineated on small scale maps. The consequences of this are examined and some recommendations made. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Influencing the perception of contour lines
Affiliations: Matlock College of Higher Education, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Underwood, J.D.M., Matlock College of Higher Education, United Kingdom
Abstract: Two possible causes of take failure of map users to successfully interpret relief forms from contour maps are Gibson's texture gradient effect which may give false depth cues; and the expectancy or prior set developed from previous experience by the map reader. In the two experiments reported attempts were made to alter subjects' expectancy by providing cues or contextural information related to the task of interpreting a number of unquantified contour patterns. Although expectancy has proved to be a dominant influence on contour interpretation J successful priming in the experiments provided subjects with a number of conflicting but valid hypotheses which were often resolved in the direction of the texture gradient. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: expectancy; maps; relief forms; texture gradient effect

Title: Land use surveys for town and country planning
Authors with affiliations: Blake, R.N.E.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: agriculture; reclamation; survey; urban fringes; wasteland

Title: Cartography: A manufacturing industry concerned with the processing, transformation, packaging and transportation of spatial data
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sorrell, P.E., Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: The communication approach advocated by cartographers during the past decade appears to have provided direction but no route to improvement of the product. Much of the research in this area appears almost aimless and considerable danger is fore seen in that if a path is not quickly established and maintained the purpose of cartographic research will be lost behind ill conceived forays into‘no man’s land’. The map is considered within this article as primarily a ‘total product’ and interdependence between its various elements seen as its strength. The current obsession with component parts detached from their operating environment appears to provide nothing of use to the manufacturer. This paper certainly is not presented as either a research or review article, but rather as a contemplative essay in which the above topics are examined and comparisons made between the cartographic and other manufacturing industries. © 1981 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Cartographic activities in the United Kingdom. 1976-1979.
Abstract: Includes information on the many and varied cartographic activities in the UK during 1976-79 with special reference to 1) educational activities involving academic and professional programmes at Institutions of Higher Education. 2) technical developments, concentrating on Governmental Institutions, and involving digital mapping technology, remote sensing imagery and large data sources such as the Census and environmental data bases. The use of computer-aided map indexing is also mentioned. 3) production techniques at a wide variety of establishments, stressing the wide range of published work resulting from their work. -M.Blakemore
Index Keywords: Census; data bases; digital mapping; environmental; imagery; remote sensing; UK

Title: Correspondence-land use maps
Authors with affiliations: Willatts, E.C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The cartographic journal
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of London King’s College Strand, London, WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence, G.R.P., Department of Geography, University of London King’s College Strand, London, WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Delaunay triangulation of a random data set for isarithmic mapping
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Nottingham University, United Kingdom; Kansas Geological Survey, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCullagh, M.J., Department of Geography, Nottingham University, United Kingdom; Ross, C.G., Kansas Geological Survey, United States
Abstract: The problems of developing an efficient Delaunay triangulation algorithm are described and a number of modifications to existing algorithms suggested. The process of triangle creation is related to that of isarithmic mapping. Estimates of relative time savings are given using a grid versus a triangular data base. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: algorithms; data base; grid

Title: Computer-based enquiries in the map library: The MAPLIB system
Affiliations: Geography and Planning and Senior Cartographic Technician, Middlesex Polytechnic, London, NW4 4BT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Shepherd, I.D.H., Geography and Planning and Senior Cartographic Technician, Middlesex Polytechnic, London, NW4 4BT, United Kingdom; Chilton, S., Geography and Planning and Senior Cartographic Technician, Middlesex Polytechnic, London, NW4 4BT, United Kingdom
Abstract: The computer has become a versatile and widely used instrument for creating maps, but it is equally valuable in managing existing map collections. MAPLIB is a conversational computer system which has been developed to store standard information about maps on the computer, and to use this information to undertake rapid enquiries concerning maps. In this article, the major decisions that underlie the development of MAPLIB are discussed, and a brief overview is given of what the system can do for the map librarian and the map library user. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: information

Title: The artistic elements in map design
Affiliations: I.T.C. Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Karssen, A.J., I.T.C. Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: The role of art in the production of a map involves the concept of beauty in respect of various elements of cartography generalisation, symbolisation, colour, layout, typography. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: colour; generalisation; symbolisation; typography

Title: The seventeenth-century maps and surveys of william fowler
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Keele, Staffs., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, A.D.M., Department of Geography, University of Keele, Staffs., United Kingdom
Abstract: Despite the recent publication of several dictionaries of surveyors and cartographers, little is known of the professional and personal background of the majority of such practitioners. This lack of detailed biographical analysis is particularly applicable to the surveyor in the seventeenth century. This paper examines the activities of one of the most prolific west Midlands’ estate surveyors in that century, William Fowler. Present knowledge of surveying practice in that period is reviewed and Fowler’s work is compared to this pattern. An appendix details Fowler’s extant maps and surveys. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: cartographers; estate surveyors; surveyors

Title: Directed and free search of the school atlas map
Affiliations: College of St Mark and St John Foundation, Plymouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sandford, H.A., College of St Mark and St John Foundation, Plymouth, United States
Abstract: School pupils3 formal educational mapwork is compared with their voluntary use of the general atlas map. Doubts about the usefulness of atlases in teaching are not confirmed. Analysis of mapwork, and especially of scanning, suggest possible ways of improving atlas map design. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: design

Title: Existing and improved road classifications for british road maps, related to the speed of traffic
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Morrison, A., Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: Calculations showed that none of the existing road classifications on British road maps shows a useful correlation with the speeds at which one can expect to drive on the various classes of road. Criteria which take a subsidiary role in existing classifications have a better correlation than those which figure prominently. New classifications more closely related to speeds can be constructed using conventional criteria. They would not require any data collection, nor even measurements from maps. They would help the map reader to select not only the minimum time route but also the fuel-saving route or the scenic route. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Great Britain

Title: Cartographic writings in britain—the growth of Specialist Literature
Affiliations: King’s College London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence, G.R.P., King’s College London, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Ifla 45th congress report 27 august-1 september 1979, copenhagen
Authors with affiliations: Wallis, H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The content and role of the cartographic journal
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying N. E. London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Cole, G.E.D., Department of Land Surveying N. E. London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Computer mapping! ’i want to start… but how? ′
Affiliations: ITC, Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Aalders, H.J.G.L., ITC, Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: For many cartographers computer assisted cartography appears as a mysterious technique. The terminology used by experts makes it even less accessible for laymen. In this article an effort is made to develop a simple technique for the setting up of a multi-purpose data bank as the base for topographic and thematic mapping. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: computer assisted cartography

Title: The assessment of transient patterns on historic maps — A case study
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Polytechnic of North London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: James M, L., Department of Geography, Polytechnic of North London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The accuracy with which transient patterns are portrayed on historic maps cannot be directly checked cartometrically. When historical geographers wish to study such patterns other methods, inevitably subjective, must be used. This paper examines the value of one such method, the transfer of information to standardised base maps, and evaluates the degree of agreement among patterns produced by participants in a transfer project. It is concluded that the method has limited practical value, but that the study throws light on the importance of visual cues in the assessment of historic maps. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: accuracy; cartometrically

Title: Strategies of real-time cartography*
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Ohio State University, Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harold, M., Department of Geography, Ohio State University, Columbus, United States
Abstract: As the application of interactive computer graphic methods to cartographic tasks continues to develop and mature, it is useful and instructive to examine these developments in a deeper conceptual context. Possibilities for cartographic communication have been greatly expanded with such interactive cartographic computer systems. A key concept in the power and flexibility of such interactive systems is that of real and virtual maps and transformations that can be made between them. One can now look past current interactive cartographic systems for display, analysis and map production to the potential of more powerful and flexible real-time interactive cartographic systems which can deal with more complex forms of cartographic situations and include the manipulation of a number of aspects of spatiotemporal dynamics. These include cartographic object manipulation and surface exploration, the display of cartographic data as it changes through time, and combinations of the above. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: display; interactive computer graphic systems; map production; surface exploration; transformations

Authors: Adams T.A., Mounsey H.M., Rhind D.W.
Title: Topographic maps from computer output on microfilm
Affiliations: University of Durham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Adams, T.A., University of Durham, United Kingdom; Mounsey, H.M., University of Durham, United Kingdom; Rhind, D.W., University of Durham, United Kingdom
Abstract: In excess of 210, 1 map sheets constitute the basic scale coverage of topographic data in Great Britain. Photography based microfilm techniques have alleviated, to some extent, the problems associated with distribution and storage for such vast data quantities. With an increasing number of large scale plans being held in digital form, the use of computer output on microfilm could offer a more cost effective approach. This paper reports on research into the display of topographic information by COM and discusses the quality and usefulness of the results. It concludes that the initiation of a trial service should be integrated into the next phase of Ordnance Survey planning. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: Great Britain; Ordnance Survey

Title: The influence of the amount of graphic information on visual matching
Affiliations: Department of Geography, State University of New York at Albany, Albany, NY, 12222, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dobson, M.W., Department of Geography, State University of New York at Albany, Albany, NY, 12222, United States
Abstract: One measure of the effectiveness of map information for task solution lies in the reader’s ability to visually discriminate and process graphic information. Although literature from other disciplines suggests that less than massive amounts of information can overload the visual information processing system, there has been considerable debate in cartographic circles as to the applicability of these assertions. In the present study, a simple paradigm was utilised to investigate the relationship between amount of graphic information and the accuracy of processing-response during a map-like visual choice task. Four experiments are reported in which subjects had to quickly detect whether two circles at the ends of a row matched the size of a circle in the centre of that row. The presentation time was 100 milliseconds. Six sizes of circles ranging from 0.48 to 1.6 cm in diameter were used as stimuli. The end circles were presented at three different widths under four different conditions. In Experiment 1 the centre and end circles were the only stimuli presented. In Experiment 2 the same symbols were presented inside of 1.7 cm2 cells. In Experiment 3 the target symbols were presented as the end points of a row of boxes with additional information (other circles) between the central and exterior targets. In Experiment 4 these same rows were presented surrounded by 12, 20, or 28 cells containing some combination of circle sizes as extraneous information. The results of the experiment indicated that the introduction of additional graphic information (circles and cells) significantly decreased accuracy of response in respect to the performance recorded when no additional information was available. It is proposed that map readers are unable to ignore unwanted or irrelevant graphic information during a similarity task. © 1980 Maney Publishing.
Index Keywords: accuracy; map readers

Title: Modern mapping in the netherlands a reflection on the map exhibition kartorama 1979 presented to bcs on the occasion of a joint bcs—nvk meeting in september 1979
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Piket, J.J.C., Department of Geography, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands
Abstract: On the occasion of a joint meeting with BCS in September 1979, the Dutch Cartographic Society (NVK) presented a map exhibition ‘KARTORAMA 1979’. The paper below is a reflection on this exhibition; it consists of two parts, the first being a reflection on cartographic expression and the role of maps nowadays, and the second bringing an overall view of recent map production in the Netherlands. © 1980 Maney Publishing.

Authors: Rhind D.W., Evans I.S., Visvalingam M.
Title: Making a national atlas of population by computer.
Affiliations: Census Research Unit, Dept. Geography, University of Durham.
