Authors with affiliations: Rhind, D.W., Census Research Unit, Dept. Geography, University of Durham.; Evans, I.S., Census Research Unit, Dept. Geography, University of Durham.; Visvalingam, M., Census Research Unit, Dept. Geography, University of Durham.
Abstract: Describes the conceptual and practical problems encountered and solved in producing a multi-colour atlas of population characteristics in Great Britain. The atlas itself is in A4 format; it consists of some 34 maps of Great Britain in four colours and the same number of regional maps, together with descriptive text. All maps were plotted on a laser plotter with a resolution of 127 microns. The paper describes how mapping of ratios, such as percentages, was found to be highly misleading and describes the novel probability mapping solution adopted, based on the signed chi-square statistic. In addition, the rationale for selecting the class intervals and for selecting colour schemes is described. - Author
Index Keywords: chi square statistic; class intervals; colour; Great Britain; probability mapping

Title: The Ordnance Survey: a look to the future.
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Smith, W.P., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: A personal view by the Director General of the Ordnance Survey of some of the conclusions of the OS Review Committee Report published in October 1980. Main points covered are: map revision, digital mapping, finance, marketing OS products more effectively, avenues for progress. Concludes with 10 questions and answers concerning the OS, and a general report of the discussion. -R.Harris
Index Keywords: digital mapping; map revision

Title: The joint committee for national certificates in surveying, cartography and planning, 1968-1978
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The Queen’s University, Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, W., Department of Geography, The Queen’s University, Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom
Abstract: The ‘Joint Committee’ ceased operations in 1978 and this summary of its ten years of operations forms the Final Report which, together with details of Examination Statistics for 1971 to 1978, has been kindly provided to the Journal by the Committee's Chairman. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Letter to the editor
Affiliations: Ferring, West Sussex, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Darton, D.R., Ferring, West Sussex, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cartographic outlook? A postscript
Affiliations: North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sorrell, P.E., North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Modelling the effect of reproduction noise on continuous-tone area symbols
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Monmonier, M.S., Department of Geography, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, United States
Abstract: Rescaling grey-tone area symbols to compensate for visual under-estimation of data values does not address the problem of graphic stability. Line growth is a common graphic distortion of grey tones that can occur during the photographic, plateetching and printing stages of map reproduction. A simulation model can be used to predict the effects of reproduction noise on various continuous-tone area symbols. Graphs derived from simulation modelling can assist the map author in specifying an efficient, reduced range of grey tones so that visually indeterminate patterns are avoided. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: grey tone area; rescaling; symbols

Title: A map of population distribution in the Portsmouth area
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Portsmouth Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dixon, O., Department of Geography, Portsmouth Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: The dot map is a long-established method for representing population distribution. The preparation of dot maps by both manual and computer-assisted means is examined; together with the availability of suitable Census data for the compilation of a dot map at medium scale. A more detailed account is given of the methods used in compiling a dot map of population in 1971 in the Portsmouth area, as a supplement to the Atlas of Portsmouth. Some possibilities for using the dot map as a basis for computer-drawn density maps are considered. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: Atlas of Portsmouth (England); computer drawn density maps; dot maps

Title: Teaching and learning from landscape and map
Affiliations: University of Leicester School of Education, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, P., University of Leicester School of Education, United Kingdom
Abstract: Recent developments in academic geography have not diminished the importance of landscape and map studies in school geography, particularly as an introduction to the subject. The distinctive skills which geographers contribute to the school curriculum are those of landscape and map interpretation. Such interpretation presents the learner with conceptual difficulties, which are not always diagnosed. This paper discusses examples and suggests ways in which they may be overcome by the teacher. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: An experiment with contour lines
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, University College London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, R.J., Department of Psychology, University College London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Map readers are generally faster and more accurate in interpreting relief from layer tint maps than from contour maps. This paper discusses methods of improving contour maps and reports an experiment where conventional contours were compared with contour lines elaborated to produce a ‘wedding cake’ effect, but this elaboration did not improve performance. The main problem for adults when reading contour maps may be a difficulty in integrating small areas of relief in order to visualise a larger area. If this is correct, no simple elaboration of contour lines will help the map reader unless it gives contours the conspicuity which layer tint colours have in peripheral vision. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Visual information processing during cartographic communication
Affiliations: Department of Geography, State University of New York at Albany, Albany, NY, 12222, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dobson, M.W., Department of Geography, State University of New York at Albany, Albany, NY, 12222, United States
Abstract: Visual communication of cartographie displays requires that the reader attend to and extract information from a display during visual examination. The reader must process these visual inputs into concepts and also blend these fixation based inputs into a composite of the original image in order to come to some conception of the displayed message. The numerous information processing activities thought to accompany this visually induced synthesis are examined from a cartographic point of view with particular attention paid to the roles of Brief Visual Storage, Short Term Memory and Visual Conspicuity. The processes that occur during visual search reduce the efficiency of sensory information and influence the ability of the reader to correctly interpret the mapped message. Many of the limitations on the reader's perceptual abilities appear to be organismic rather than of a cognitive nature and, therefore, may suggest absolute limitations on the ability to communicate visual information. Finally, the implications of visual information processing for cartographic communication are explored. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: Brief Visual Storage; Short Term Memory; Visual Conspicuity; visual search

Title: Land use maps
Affiliations: King’s College, London, United Kingdom; University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Coleman, A., King’s College, London, United Kingdom; Balchin, W.G.V., University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: A summary of land use mapping in Britain and overseas leads to a consideration of the role of the Second Lane Utilisation Survey of Britain which was established in 1960. Additional research mapping in recent years has explored new techniques which could be applied to practical problems of urban mapping. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: Britain; Second Land Utilisation Survey; urban mapping

Title: The perceptual problem in contour interpretation
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Adelaide, SA, Australia; Department of Geography, Salisbury College of Advanced Education, SA, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Griffin, T.L.C., Department of Geography, University of Adelaide, SA, Australia; Lock, B.F., Department of Geography, Salisbury College of Advanced Education, SA, Australia
Abstract: Map-users often fail to obtain an accurate visual image of relief form from contour maps, though little is known about the specific problems experienced. A multiple-choice questionnaire given to 701 subjects concentrated upson the ability to identify different types of slope on contour diagrams. Conceptual difficulty existed, but the failure to judge the relative steepness of slope along convex profiles was best explained by recourse to perceptual error. It is concluded that this may be related to Gibson’s texture gradient effect. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: reading contour maps; slope on contour diagrams

Title: Contouring by use of a triangular mesh
Affiliations: University of Newcastle, NSW, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Elfick, M.H., University of Newcastle, NSW, Australia
Abstract: Most techniques which derive contours from spot heights, require an intermediate procedure whereby a surface represented by an array of data points spaced on a regular grid pattern, is first fitted to groups of points before the contours are determined.This article describes a process whereby contours may be derived directly from randomly distributed spot heights, by the use of an irregular triangular lattice of interpolation lines. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: contours; grid pattern; irregular triangular lattice

Title: Cartography in the round—the orthographic projection
Affiliations: University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ward, K., University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: Throughout its history the principal function of cartography has been the supply of maps for navigational, engineering or cadastral purposes to a clientele interested in the map primarily as a basis of mensuration. The interest of the map maker tended therefore to be restricted to projections whose properties facilitated accurate representation of direction, distance and area, to the neglect of other systems less well adapted to such purposes. The characteristics of the orthographic projection, formerly discounted, should now commend it for a greater role in cartographic communication especially in the space age. However, construction of the most frequently required oblique version by methods dependent on draughtsmanship, the camera or the computer may overtax either the patience or resources of the average cartographer. As an alternative, general mapping equations are derived and it is suggested that the pocket calculator can be used to evaluate these to provide sufficient co-ordinates for plotting useful graticules. Construction of some examples incorporating enlarged insets is discussed together with the plotting of great circle tracks and satellite orbits. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: cartographic communication; general mapping equations; great circle tracks; satellite orbits

Title: Re-assessing the role played by shaded relief in topographic scale maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, K7L 3N6, Canada; Department of Geography, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC, V8W 2Y2, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Castner, H.W., Department of Geography, Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, K7L 3N6, Canada; Wheate, R., Department of Geography, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC, V8W 2Y2, Canada
Abstract: Hill shading and contouring were examined in relation to how they affected the performance of several tasks of map reading and map interpretation. Evaluation of the experimental results revealed that elements which could be related to the terrain, or were aspects of it, could be located more rapidly when shading was present. Only when the target could not be perceived easily with peripheral vision, did the visual noise in the relief depiction appear to adversely affect performance scores. Thus, while the value of contours is recognised, the graphic continuity and imageability of shading may provide perceptual advantages to the map user in performing a wide variety of map reading tasks. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: contouring; hill shading; map interpretation

Title: Selection of towns on derived maps
Affiliations: 38 Willifield Way, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stenhouse, H., 38 Willifield Way, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Three different selections of towns in England and Wales, at three scales (1:4 000 000, 1:8 000 000 and 1:16 000 000) are made using Topfer's Radical Law and, Moser and Scott’s classification of towns. The results are compared with examples from atlases. Factors relevant to the selection of towns during the process of cartographic generalisation are considered. © 1979 The British Cartographic Society.
Index Keywords: classification of towns; England & Wales; generalization

Title: Harvard Computer Graphics Conference report.
Authors with affiliations: Shepherd, I.D.H.
Abstract: The main theme of the conference was the application of computer graphics in the academic planning and commercial fields. The author looks at the more succinct points under the headings of trends and developments and future tasks. Concludes that there is an underlying need for better education about computer mapping in all aspects of graphical presentation. -Nick Rigby

Title: Graduated circles
Affiliations: Boston University, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Olson, J.M., Boston University, MA, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Choropleth map production by facsimile
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Muller, J.-C., Department of Geography, The University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Honsaker, J.L., Department of Geography, The University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Abstract: A continuous tone image can be produced by facsimile to simulate the various shaded patterns of a choropleth map. The image can be subsequently screened for half-tone reproduction. Up to 255 hues of tone can be reproduced. The facsimile technique removes the need for finding manufactured tones whose visual intensity is closely proportional to the data value, thereby forcing the cartographer to debate the significance of class generalisation. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The development of the ordnance survey 1:25 000 scale derived digital map
Affiliations: ADCS, Ordnance Survey, Romsey Road, Maybush, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bell, J.F., ADCS, Ordnance Survey, Romsey Road, Maybush, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: German military mapping— an exploratory survey
Affiliations: Map Curator, University of London King’s College, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Tatham, A.F., Map Curator, University of London King’s College, United Kingdom
Abstract: ‘Captured. German’ maps at King’s College, London, are examined. The language, grid systems and units of measurement used, and types of revision and overprinted information displayed, are discussed and illustrated. The utility and interest of these maps is demonstrated, while their neglect is regretted. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Evaluating maps
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, University College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Noyes, E., Department of Psychology, University College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Reply: Graduated circles
Affiliations: Bureau of Social Science Research, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wainer, H., Bureau of Social Science Research, WA, United States; Biderman, A., Bureau of Social Science Research, WA, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Screenless lithography and orthophotomaps
Affiliations: University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: The development of photomaps and orthophotomaps has created renewed interest in methods of reproducing in print the continuous tone image of the aerial photograph without using a half-tone screen. The methods are briefly reviewed, and the development of screenless lithographic printing is outlined. Examples of orthophotomap images reproduced by a new screenless lithographic plate process accompany this article. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Visual aspects of class intervals in choroplethic mapping
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang, K.-T., Department of Geography, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States
Abstract: Visual aspects of class intervals in choroplethic mapping were studied in tests which involved a series of five choroplethic maps using the same data but different methods of classing. The subjects were asked to rank the maps in the order of preference for the final map production, and to provide explanations for their rankings. The study finds that the grouping of adjoining counties and the number of counties in each statistical class are the most important criteria to the subjects. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Erratum to Philip’s new world atlas (Cartographic Journal, June 1977, 59-60)
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: National qualifications in cartography—a review, september 1978
Affiliations: Oxford Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Anson, R.W., Oxford Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: An explanation of the governmental philosophy relating to the establishment of the Technician Education Council; its constitution, aims, objectives and logistics; and the necessary modification of existing schemes of technician education to comply with TEC guidelines for replacement courses leading to the award of nationally recognised qualifications in Cartography. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The signed Chi-square measure for mapping
Affiliations: Census Research Unit, Department of Geography, University of Durham, Durham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Visvalingam, M., Census Research Unit, Department of Geography, University of Durham, Durham, United Kingdom
Abstract: When interest extends beyond purely univariate considerations, there is no fixed rule governing the ordering of spatial samples for mapping and statistical analysis. Ratios and numerical differences have conventionally been the basis for comparing samples. As both these are known to be influenced by variations in sample size, they are unsuitable for the comparison of demographic samples which vary greatly in size. Where necessary, the effect of sample size can be accommodated by a modified form of the X2 test statistic which is described in this paper. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Determining a vertical scale for graphical representations of threedimensional surfaces
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Worth, C., Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: The selection of a vertical scale in the production of block diagrams or three-dimensional views is a decision which can have a great effect on the map reader's perception of the information presented. Advice available in the cartographic literature is extremely subjective and refers mainly to physical data. In the absence of suitable guidelines for statistical mapping, an experimental technique is presented which utilises the power of automated cartography in determining a scale which can be applied to all types of three-dimensional surfaces. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Authors: Phillips R.J., Noyes E., Audley R.J.
Title: Searching for names on maps
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, University College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, R.J., Department of Psychology, University College, London, United Kingdom; Noyes, E., Department of Psychology, University College, London, United Kingdom; Audley, R.J., Department of Psychology, University College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: It is argued that the best way to evaluate map typography is to measure the time taken to find names on a map. Eye movement recording demonstrates that this search time depends on two independent factors: The number of names fixated with the eyes and the mean fixation time. Changes in map design usually affect only one of these factors. For example, typographic coding can reduce the average number of fixations but an increase in point size reduces mean fixation time. This discussion leads to some recommendations on type legibility. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The decagraph: A substitute for the Pie Graph?
Affiliations: University of Lagos, Lagos, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Balogun, O.Y., University of Lagos, Lagos, Nigeria
Abstract: Various point symbols have been employed by cartographers to represent component parts of certain phenomena. The pie graph is obviously the most popular of these symbols. At the same time, it is widely condemned for its inability to afford estimations that are close to the latent information. To help overcome this problem, the decagraph is suggested in this paper, as a substitute for the pie graph. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A polyfocal projection for statistical surfaces
Affiliations: Tel-Aviv University and Survey of Israel, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Tel-Aviv University and Survey of Israel, Israel; Shlomi, E., Tel-Aviv University and Survey of Israel, Israel
Abstract: The evolution of a continuous projection for portraying the area of territorial units in proportion to a thematic variable has, in the past, eluded the cartographer. The present paper— resulting from postgraduate research in cartography by the second author under the supervision of the first—describes the development of such a projection and some of the possible applications. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Authors: Potash L.M., Farrell J.P., Jeffrey T.
Title: A technique for assessing map relief legibility
Affiliations: U.S. Army Research Institute for the Behavioral and Social Sciences, United States
Authors with affiliations: Potash, L.M., U.S. Army Research Institute for the Behavioral and Social Sciences, United States; Farrell, J.P., U.S. Army Research Institute for the Behavioral and Social Sciences, United States; Jeffrey, T., U.S. Army Research Institute for the Behavioral and Social Sciences, United States
Abstract: The test discussed in this report is designed to assess the effect of supplementing contour lines with other relief formats. It contains eight types of problems and a review of relevant aspects of map reading. It has been produced in three relief formats: contour lines, contour lines plus layer tints, and contour lines plus shading. Initial work indicates that addition of layer tints to contour lines can increase speed of reading some types of relief information; whereas, addition of shaded relief does not increase map reading speed more than use of layer tints and can cause a decrease in accuracy. © 1978 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Computer executed interpolation of contours into arrays of randomly distributed height-points
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Tel Aviv University, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Yoëli, P., Department of Geography, Tel Aviv University, Israel
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Use of the HRD-1 laser display for automated cartography
Affiliations: Experimental Cartography Unit, Natural Environment Research Council, London, SW7, United States; Laser-Scan Laboratories Ltd., Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bell, S.B.M., Experimental Cartography Unit, Natural Environment Research Council, London, SW7, United States; Woodsford, P.A., Laser-Scan Laboratories Ltd., Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: The HRD- 1 Laser-display uses innovative technology to allow accurate display of large amounts of data on a screen as large or larger than most maps. It provides facilities for interacting with the data on the screen, and also for creating accurate hard copy on microfiche. The plotting speed is fast, being more comparable to that of a small format storage display, than to that of a high-accuracy flat-bed plotter. Thus the Laser-display has many advantages over the more familiar storage and refresh displays or plotters. This paper describes the integration of such a display into a pre-existing system that produces maps by interactive graphics and other automated methods. Special emphasis is placed on its interactive use, although use as a plotter is also discussed. The display is evaluated as a cartographic tool. It is concluded that the display can be used to provide a faster and more efficient tool for interactive graphics in high-accuracy automated cartography. © 1977 Maney Publishing.

Title: Correspondence
Affiliations: Map Laboratory, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, R.L., Map Laboratory, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Design and production of 1:25 000 multicolour land use capability maps
Affiliations: Macaulay Institute for Soil Research, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Shirreffs, W.S., Macaulay Institute for Soil Research, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes a method for producing short runs of simple multicolour maps using a combination of lithographic and silk screen printing techniques. The advantages and limitations of the process are discussed. © 1977 Maney Publishing.

Title: On generalisations concerning generalisation
Affiliations: Geography Section, Lanchester Polytechnic, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gardiner, V., Geography Section, Lanchester Polytechnic, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The perception of hypsometric colours
Affiliations: Department of Geography and Meteorology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, 66045, United States; University of Kansas, Bowling Green State University, Bowling Green, OH, 43403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Patton, J.C., Department of Geography and Meteorology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, 66045, United States; Crawford, P.V., University of Kansas, Bowling Green State University, Bowling Green, OH, 43403, United States
Abstract: This study has a twofold purpose; first to determine if the standard sequence of colours used on many hypsometric maps transmits accurate data relative to topographic elevation, and second, to determine if information intended by the colour scheme is transmuted into other forms, or if additional incorrect information is consociate with elevation data transmitted by hypsometric tints. These questions are examined through the perception of children and young adults, ranging from the sixth grade to the college freshman level. The results indicate that hypsometric maps using spectrally ordered colours accurately transmit data concerning topographic elevation, but also transmit inaccurate unintended information concerning vegetation, rainfall, and temperature. Little variance in the results occurs between the different age levels. © 1977 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic transactions
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, G.B.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Some methodological comments on evaluating maps
Affiliations: Bureau of Social Science Research, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wainer, H., Bureau of Social Science Research, Washington, DC, United States; Biderman, A.D., Bureau of Social Science Research, Washington, DC, United States

Title: Samuel hibbert and the early geological mapping of the Shetland islands
Affiliations: Department of Earth Sciences, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boud, R.C., Department of Earth Sciences, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: In this paper, a brief review is made of the geological surveys and accounts of the Shetland Islands, made over a period of two hundred years, which culminated in the publication, by Samuel Hibbert, of the earliest geological maps of the islands in 1820-22. © 1977 Maney Publishing.

Title: Regression-based scaling to facilitate the cross-correlation of graduated circle maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Monmonier, M.S., Department of Geography, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, United States
Abstract: Most cartographic research on the communication effectiveness of graduated circles has been directed toward value estimation tasks. Apparent value rescaling of graduated circles has no inherent effect on visual cross-correlation, and another type of design modification is needed to improve judgments of similarity. Regression-based scaling is grounded in the linear regression model underlying the product-moment correlation coefficient and is a means for obtaining similar map patterns for highly correlated geographic distributions and dissimilar patterns for uncorrelated distributions. Although this design modification destroys the symbols’ ratio scale, value estimation tasks are not obstructed if legends contain representative ranges of circles sizes. © 1977 Maney Publishing.

Title: Ordnance survey map users’ conference-november 1976
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cadastres and cadastral maps
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dale, P.F., Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: Cadastres are concerned with recording certain information about parcels of land. The function of cadastral maps is to describe the boundaries of properties. In some systems, the information on cadastral maps is definitive whilst in others the map is only an indication of what may be found on the ground. The cadastre may be used for taxation purposes or for registering ownership but more recently there has been a trend towards the multipurpose cadastre in which a wider range of information may be recorded. © 1977 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Countries of latin america­research guide series
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cartographic generalisation
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Science, University of Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Beckett, P., Department of Agricultural Science, University of Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: The length of a line (in km) measured off a map of scale 1:R1 is approximately (R2/R1)g of its length in the same units measured off a map at scale 1:R2. For measurements by map measurer y may vary between 0 and 0.4 according to the sinuosity of the line, but for road length on maps of Britain it seems reasonable to assume: L1/L2=(R2/R1)017. © 1977 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Computer-automated digitisation

Authors: Smith T.F., Van Genderen J.L., Holland E.W.
Title: A land use survey of developed areas in england and wales
Affiliations: Department of the Environment, London, United Kingdom; Fairey Surveys Ltd., Maidenhead, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Smith, T.F., Department of the Environment, London, United Kingdom; Van Genderen, J.L., Fairey Surveys Ltd., Maidenhead, United Kingdom; Holland, E.W., Fairey Surveys Ltd., Maidenhead, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper was first given to The British Cartographic Society meeting in the Autumn of 1976. It discusses the project, its origins and development, and the close liaison between the Department of the Environment and Fairey Surveys Ltd. in its execution. © 1977 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Technical group

Title: An experiment in the comparative analysis of distortion on historical maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stone, J.C., Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Gemmell, A.M.D., Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom

Title: Photomechanical processes used in map production
Affiliations: Reproduction Division Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bramhall, C.W., Reproduction Division Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: Photomechanical processes play an increasing part in map production. This paper describes some of the processes which are available and the tasks on which they can be used. © 1977 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: European ethnological atlas
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Orienteering Maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Petrie, G., Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper was first presented at the Aberdeen Symposium of the British Cartographic Society in September, 1976. © 1977 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: On isopleths and continuous scanning isodensitometry
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Tel-Aviv University, Israel; Department of Geography, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Degani, A., Department of Geography, Tel-Aviv University, Israel; Porter, P.W., Department of Geography, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: Common isopleth mapping based on data for arbitrary areal units and linear interpolation procedures presents many cartographic problems which can be solved or circumvented by the use of continuous scanning isodensitometry. Optionally an optical or digital technique may be employed to create isopleths of uniform reliability from data recorded by coordinate position or as a photographic image. © 1977 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Provincial atlas of people’s republic of china—a review and some comments on the design of chinese atlases
Affiliations: Department of Geography and Geology, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Lo, C.P., Department of Geography and Geology, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: Provincial Atlas of People's Republic of China (Chung hua ien min kung wo kuo fên shêng di t'u chi). 190 x 265 mm. pp. 251 (84 pages of maps). Peking: Map Publishing Society (di t'u ch'u p'an shê), China, Oct., 1974. 6.30 Yuan. © 1976 Maney Publishing.

Title: Some aspects of the use of photography in map production in the ordnance survey
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Simmonds, M.C., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The present state of perceptual research in cartography
Affiliations: Gainesville, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandes, D., Gainesville, FL, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the current state of perceptual research concerning cartographic symbols. Initial discussion treats the theories and reasons behind the present popularity of perceptual studies in cartography. It is followed by a summary of the printed materials on this topic appearing in several prominent English language cartographic publications. A person who is newly entering the area of perceptual research in cartography may use this paper as a quick source for obtaining background in the area and thereby save valuable time from sifting through individual sources for information regarding what has already been done. Additional convenience is provided for the reader by the grouping of references according to the subject matter which they concern. © 1976 Maney Publishing.

Title: Society record
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Design and production of 1:25 000 single colour soil maps
Affiliations: The Macaulay Institute for Soil Research, Craigiebuckler, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Shirreffs, W.S., The Macaulay Institute for Soil Research, Craigiebuckler, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper presents an account of the factors involved in the design of 1:25 000 Soil Survey of Scotland maps together with a description of the procedures involved in their production. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: From hills to hotine
Affiliations: Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: McGrath, G., Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Printing inks in the seventies
Affiliations: Croda Inks Ltd., Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hutchinson, G.H., Croda Inks Ltd., Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: Two factors have influenced trends in printing ink manufacture, the need for inks to print on a wide variety of new papers, boards, films and foils and the demand for higher production rates on faster running printing presses. The object of this paper is to review progress over the past 10 years or so and to discuss some ideas on future developments. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The planimetrie accuracy of tithe maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Exeter, United Kingdom; Hunting Surveys Limited, Boreham Wood, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Perry, R.A., Department of Geography, University of Exeter, United Kingdom; Hooke, J., Hunting Surveys Limited, Boreham Wood, United Kingdom
Abstract: In this paper general problems of map accuracy and its measurement are discussed; methods of testing the planimetric accuracy of tithe maps are suggested. Sample measurements resulted in average absolute errors of less then five per cent on three-quarters of the maps tested. The tithe maps provide a valuable source of planimetric data which pre-dates other cartographic sources of comparable scale and coverage. © 1976 Maney Publishing.

Title: Measuring the coastline from maps: A study of the scottish mainland
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Computing Centre, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baugh, I.D.H., Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Boreham, J.R., Computing Centre, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: While attempting to devise a methodology for the assessment of the impact of planning decisions on the coastline of Scotland, it became apparent that a means of mapping information concerning the coastline and coastal zone was necessary. This meant that the maps had to be capable of being produced in bulk, they should be easy to alter and produce at different scales and with different information. It was therefore decided to investigate the potential of computational tech¬niques to produce the required maps. This was performed by employing a d-Mac digitising table to generate the required coordinates and by processing the information on the Univer¬sity of Aberdeen's ICL system 4/70 computer, the output being on drum plotter. © 1976 Maney Publishing.

Title: Some methodological issues in computer drawn maps
Affiliations: Building Research Establishment, Garston, Watford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baxter, R.S., Building Research Establishment, Garston, Watford, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Towards objectivity in the use of colour
Affiliations: School of Military Survey, Hermitage, Newbury, Berkshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Shellswell, M.M.A., School of Military Survey, Hermitage, Newbury, Berkshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: Procedures exist for evaluating colour in terms of a scientific specification which can be developed to quantify the visual impact of colour differences. In this paper the essential theory of colorimetry is outlined and discussed from a cartographic standpoint and one method of measuring a colour specification is described. The practical results are used to illustrate the ways in which colorimetry might help the cartographer and it is concluded that given further research the scientific measure-ment of colour could offer an objective basis for the analysis and use of colour in map design. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Objective and subjective comparison in choroplethic Mapping
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Muller, J.C., Department of Geography, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Abstract: Visual map comparison can supplement statistical analysis by providing information as to where and how spatial correspondence occurs. The associations that may be discovered are influenced by the nature of the map features being compared and the criteria used for making the comparisons. In this paper the author has tried to identify the elements of visual recognition that map readers use to associate or differentiate geographical distributions represented by choropleth maps. The main components of the multivariate map reading process are pointed out, including the perceptual interactions between the actual locations of map tones and the overall similarity between map patterns. © 1976 Maney Publishing.

Title: The design and preparation of maps for 35 mm projectors
Affiliations: Department of the Environment, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Flanders, D.W., Department of the Environment, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Whilst it can be fairly stated that the post war years have seen an upsurge of interest in the design of maps as printed material, the same cannot be said of the treatment of maps for projection, whether by 35 mm slides or overhead methods. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Optimum spatial design for thematic Maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Bowling Green State University, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crawford, P.V., Department of Geography, Bowling Green State University, OH, United States
Abstract: Reader perception of optimum spatial design for achromatic, small-scale thematic maps of page size format is shown to be a function of the figure-ground ratio. Acceptable ratios for optimum spatial structure fell between 1:2.18 and 1:3.56. © 1976 Maney Publishing.

Title: Symap: Its uses and abuses
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Liebenberg, E., Department of Geography, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: This paper was first presented at the Swansea Symposium, of The British Cartographic Society in September 1975. It illustrates some of the possibilities and limitations of the Synagraphic Mapping System. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The impact of inflation on cartography
Affiliations: George Philip and Son Ltd., London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fullard, H., George Philip and Son Ltd., London, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper is the substance of a talk on the Impact of Inflation on Cartography, given to the British Cartographic Society in January 1976. The difficulty of the subject is evident from the many causes of inflation and because of the speed at which inflation was and is affecting every aspect of life. However, the subject has a fascinating horror and is so pertinent that the contemporary value of such a paper is great. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Pioneer geodesy: The arc of the 30th meridian in the former northern rhodesia
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stone, J.C., Department of Geography, University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Quantisation error in area measurement
Affiliations: Mullard Research Laboratories, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lloyd, P.R., Mullard Research Laboratories, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom
Abstract: A method for measuring areas using Visual Scene Analysis techniques is described, and a comparison made with a point counting approach. The theoretical accuracy of such methods is discussed with reference to a previously published analysis, in the light of different randomness criteria. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The geodetic and topographical evaluation of english county maps, 1740-1840
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Laxton, P., Department of Geography, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Abstract: County surveying is by far the most difficult part of surveying; for the stations are so long and so many, that if the instrument to take the angles, be not very accurate, great errors will be committed; especially after so many repetitions of taking angles, at so many different stations. It seemethfit to some that in the deliniation of everie Shire, I should observe the variation of the Compas, some other therein are of a contrarie opinion. Others will have the degrees of Longitude, and Latitude, in everie particular description: Some think it frivolous. Some very curiously prie into the worke, augmenting (in conceite) their own credits by carping at everie fault, holding the smallest errour (yea the misterming of a place) verie criminous. John Norden, Nordens Preparative to his Speculum. © 1976 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Further comments on the maps of the Somersetshire Coal Canal
Affiliations: Department of Geology, Keele University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Torrens, H.S., Department of Geology, Keele University, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Reduction of linear cartographic data based on generation of Pseudo-Hyperbolae
Affiliations: Department of Surveying Engineering, University of New Brunswick, Fredericton, Canada; Alberta Environment, Edmonton, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Vanicek, P., Department of Surveying Engineering, University of New Brunswick, Fredericton, Canada; Woolnough, D.F., Alberta Environment, Edmonton, Canada
Abstract: This paper presents the mathematical basis of a method for generalising linear cartographic data. The method is based on the transformation of the parameters of a digitised curve into a set of pseudo-hyperbolae such that no point lies outside a tube of given error tolerance E. The method has been programmed in the Fortran IV language for test purposes, and examples of the programs’ results are given. The method should be of interest to those working in digital cartography who seek a method of data reduction which is both mathematically rigid and cartographically sensible. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: The ordnance survey 1:50 000 Map
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dear, J.R., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom; Reid, P.E., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: The One Inch to One Mile Map, first published by the Ordnance Survey 175 years ago has been superseded by the new metric 1:50 000 series. This account describes the carto­graphic production stages of the new series and is a sequel to the paper by J. G. Price—Cartographic Journal, June 1975. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: The automation of fishing charts at the white fish authority
Affiliations: White Fish Authority, Hull, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Richardson, J.B., White Fish Authority, Hull, United Kingdom
Abstract: The White Fish Authority has been producing specialised charts for the fishing industry for about twelve years. The paper describes the importance of these charts to the fisherman, and how chart production has been automated in recent years. A full description of the current computer systems is given, together with flow charts of each stage of the production cycle. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: Rapid digital mapping of coastal areas from LANDSAT
Affiliations: School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, A.C., School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom; Brimblecombe, P., School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom
Abstract: The value of repeated imagery from satellite platforms can only be realised if coupled to rapid mapping systems. Techniques for producing rapid, user oriented maps from LANDSAT data are discussed, and examples derived from the mapping of the coastal and off-shore areas of eastern England. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic employers: A survey of recruitment and attitudes
Affiliations: Department of Earth Sciences, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boud, R.C., Department of Earth Sciences, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a survey, made among cartographic employers, to examine the numbers, ages and qualifications of applicants for cartographic draughtsmen posts advertised in the national press. It also looks at the employers’ attitudes to cartographic factors when assessing applicants for posts in their organisations. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A correspondence course in cartography in the Netherlands
Affiliations: Geographical Institute of the State, University of Utrecht, Netherlands; ITC Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Ormeling, F.J., Jr., Geographical Institute of the State, University of Utrecht, Netherlands; Brown, A., ITC Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Orthophotography as a cartographie aid
Affiliations: Fairey Surveys Scotland Limited, Livingston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, W.A.S., Fairey Surveys Scotland Limited, Livingston, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the benefits which the technique of orthophotography can afford the cartographer and map user in terms of data compilation, assessment, selection and presentation. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The map as a communication system
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Atlas of Early American History Project, Newberry Library, Chicago, IL, 60610, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.H., Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Petchenik, B.B., Atlas of Early American History Project, Newberry Library, Chicago, IL, 60610, United States
Abstract: Only recently have cartographers devoted much attention to the study of the map as a communication system. It is now generally accepted that the study of how maps convey knowledge to a recipient, and therefore the study of the percipient as well as the process, are important areas of research. Various models of communication systems are analysed from the point of view of the inputs and transformations involved. The element of “noise”, characteristic of all systems, is examined as it relates to the map. The problem of assessing the amount of information included in a map and the efficiency with which geographical knowledge is evoked in a percipient is reviewed. Because a map is a two-dimensional presentation it is a very different form of communication from the one-dimensional linear forms that depend upon a temporal sequence, and consequently, the techniques of information theory are judged not to be directly applicable. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Interactive computer cartography
Affiliations: San Diego State University, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stutz, F.P., San Diego State University, CA, United States
Abstract: This paper describes interactive computer cartography which is a new approach in graphics construction. It briefly outlines some of the advantages of such a system. Both hardware configurations and software problems are identified and interactive output including shaded contour maps, two- and three-dimensional figures, world map projections, and three-dimensional surfaces are presented. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Choosing of colour sequences for reproduction in monochrome halftone
Affiliations: University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada; 810 N.W. 9th Avenue, Gainesville, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandes, D., University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada, 810 N.W. 9th Avenue, Gainesville, FL, United States
Abstract: Most coloured maps are not suitable for reproduction in black and white. If a map is to be used in both colour and monochrome, special attention must be given to the choice of colours so that they will still be distinguishable after being transformed into shades of a single colour. This problem is especially apparent in the representation of quantitative data, where the chosen area symbols must maintain their apparent relative value order in both colour and monochrome. This study was undertaken to establish several sets of colours that may be applied to maps which are intended to be used in both forms. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: Luton college of technology diploma in geographical techniques
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, A.D.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: A further study of the early maps of the Somersetshire Coal Canal
Affiliations: The Old Cottage, Great Rissington, Gloucestershire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Eyles, J.M., The Old Cottage, Great Rissington, Gloucestershire, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Phillips R.J., de Lucia A., Skelton N.
Title: Some objective tests of the legibility of relief maps
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, University College London, United Kingdom; Experimental Cartography Unit, London, United Kingdom; Experimental Cartography Unit, London, United Kingdom; Department of Geography-Geology, Illinois State University, Normal, IL, 61761, United States; 32 Sunderland Road, Ealing, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, R.J., Department of Psychology, University College London, United Kingdom; de Lucia, A., Experimental Cartography Unit, London, United Kingdom, Department of Geography-Geology, Illinois State University, Normal, IL, 61761, United States; Skelton, N., Experimental Cartography Unit, London, United Kingdom, 32 Sunderland Road, Ealing, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The legibility of four different types of relief map (contours, contours with hill shading, layer tints and digital or spot height maps) was compared using 13 different map reading test questions administered to 179 subjects. Many of the questions showed large and statistically significant differences between the four types of map, but no single type of map was best for all purposes. The results demonstrate that the choice of an appropriate relief map has a very real effect on the map reader's performance, and that this choice must depend on the way the map is to be used. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A kit for making raised maps
Affiliations: Blind Mobility Research Unit, Department of Psychology, University of Nottingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: James, G.A., Blind Mobility Research Unit, Department of Psychology, University of Nottingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This article describes the development of a map making kit from which raised maps may be produced to aid blind people during travel. The method may be implemented at a local level, cheaply and without complicated machinery and utilises standardised symbols and procedures. The kit may be used to produce single copy maps but is more likely to be used to produce map-masters from which copies may be vacuum- formed. It is suggested that symbols contained in the mapmaking kit should form a national standard in the United Kingdom. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Experience and the improvement of cartographic communication
Affiliations: Boston University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Olson, J.M., Boston University, United States
Abstract: Both reader training and improved map design can be used to increase the communicative effectiveness of maps. Tests with dot densities and circles indicate that either rescaling of symbols (design) or the allowance of some feedback (reader training) will result in more accurate median estimates. The feedback approach, however, is associated with a greater dispersion in estimates, i.e. estimates are less clustered about the median. When both the rescaling and feedback approaches are used, both the medians and dispersion are improved. A different experiment, involving map comparisons, shows that a small amount of reader training can clarify the concept involved in that task and such clarification increases accuracy. While both design modification and reader training induce improvements in map communication, these improvements are different in nature; the two approaches are not substitutes for one another but are complementary. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: A review of design and production factors for the ordnance survey 1:50 000 map series
Affiliations: Cartography Division, Ordnance Survey, United States
Authors with affiliations: Price, J.G., Cartography Division, Ordnance Survey, United States
Abstract: The publication by the Ordnance Survey of the first 103 map sheets covering the southern half of Great Britain at 1:50 000 scale on 7th March 1974 was a conspicuous land mark in British cartographic history; firstly, because the tradition of 170 years of the One-inch to One mile scale had been broken and secondly, because such a large number of sheets were published simultaneously. This paper is an attempt to review some of the factors and problems in the design and production of the new series. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A note on colour control in tri-colour printing
Affiliations: Shell de Venezuela, Maracaibo, Venezuela
Authors with affiliations: Fisher, A., Shell de Venezuela, Maracaibo, Venezuela
Abstract: This note discusses the principles of the tri-colour printing process (trico-printing) and its applications, and looks at a possible use of the process to enable forward planning of the final colours needed in making use of pre-printed visible dot screens. The three primary colours, magenta, cyan and yellow are used as a base for the system. The various subjects are considered with a bias towards mapping and preparation of material ready for offset printing. © 1975 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Society record
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: R. K. dawson’s proposal in 1836 for a cadastral survey of england and wales
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Exeter, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kain, R.J.P., Department of Geography, University of Exeter, Canada
Abstract: In 1836, Lieutenant Robert Kearsley Dawson, organiser of the tithe commutation surveys, suggested that tithe maps should form the basis of a general survey of England and Wales on the Irish and Continental models. His idea was supported by the Tithe Commissioners but was strongly opposed, particularly on grounds of cost, by representatives of the landowning interest. This article reviews the debate on the combination of tithe surveys with a full cadastral survey. It was a debate which lasted for almost a year and ended with parliament deciding against Dawson's proposal. It was truly an opportunity lost. © 1975 Maney Publishing.

Title: First honorary member
Authors with affiliations: Thackwell, B.D.E.O.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Exhibition of Chinese and Japanese maps at the british library: 1st February-31 st December 1974
Authors with affiliations: Wallis, H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Typographic size control for cartographers
Affiliations: Scottish Development Department, Scottish Office, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Copland, D.R., Scottish Development Department, Scottish Office, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: An investigation into the factors affecting type size is described and basic equations derived. These equations are used to construct nomograms, which forecast the basic size data needed for effective typographic design. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: National library of Scotland
Authors with affiliations: Wilkes, M.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The graphical construction of lambert’s Equal-Area conic projection with one standard parallel
Affiliations: Milford Haven Grammar School, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Watts, D.G., Milford Haven Grammar School, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Computer method for radar site selection
Affiliations: Redifon Flight Simulation Ltd., Formerly of Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bolton, M.J.P., Redifon Flight Simulation Ltd., Formerly of Imperial College, London, United Kingdom; Tam, C.C., Redifon Flight Simulation Ltd., Formerly of Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The purpose of the project described in this paper is to develop a computer program which aids the siting of radar stations. The existing manual method is time consuming and error prone. It involves visual inspection of contour maps to determine one or more possible sites. Each site is then examined in detail by drawing the profiles of the terrain along scan lines radiating from the site. From these profiles any possible obstructions to the radar beams by the surrounding area can be determined. This consideration together with other factors such as site accessibility, will allow the choice of the optimal location to be made. The work described in this paper was commissioned by the Experimental Cartography Unit of the Natural Environmental Research Council, Department of the Environment. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Testing the effectiveness of road speed maps and conventional road maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Morrison, A., Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper presents the results of two independent tests undertaken by a broad sample of motorists in the selection of minimum time routes using both the experimental road speed map and the traditional road map as the basic information. The tests are described, the results analysed, and certain conclusions drawn. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Comparative use of a picture, and written material in social studies
Affiliations: University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Carswell, R.J.B., University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada; Wescott, H.M., University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada
Abstract: This paper discusses the part played by graphic illustrations in enhancing the written word in the teaching of social science subjects. Data for the study were obtained from students within the Calgary School System. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Evaluating thematic maps—current trends in the United Kingdom
Affiliations: London School of Economics, United Kingdom; Department of the Environment, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Board, C., London School of Economics, United Kingdom; Buchanan, A., Department of the Environment, United Kingdom
Abstract: The setting up of Commission V ‘Cartographic Communication’ by the International Cartographic Association in Ottawa in 1972 reflected the growth of world-wide interest in the subject and has led to a stock-taking of, and given encouragement to research into the effectiveness of maps as devices for communicating information. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: At the crossroads
Affiliations: Contraves Industrial Products Ltd., Ruislip, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carpanini, E., Contraves Industrial Products Ltd., Ruislip, United Kingdom
Abstract: The time seems imminent when the British cartographic industry will take a major step into automation. European surveying and cartographic organisations have been supplied with Contraves automated drafting systems since 1962. This article is intended to introduce briefly the latest of these systems. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The Africa road map: Issues in conceptualisation, design, standardisation and rationalisation
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Nigeria, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Igbozurike, M.U., Department of Geography, University of Nigeria, Nigeria
Abstract: In general terms, the road map is simply a map which gives the location and, thereby, the distribution of roads, as well as the distance covered by each significant segment of every road. Cartographically and in terms of utilisation, however, the issues involved are not so simple. They extend well beyond mere location and mileage. In this paper, which deals specifically with Africa, the issues are briefly discussed under four principal headings; conceptualisation, design, standardisation, and rationalisation. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Orientation maps for the physically handicapped
Affiliations: University of Warwick, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gill, J.M., University of Warwick, United Kingdom
Abstract: Little is known about the concepts of the environment by congenitally and adventitiously blind people. Non-visual maps can help some blind people with orientation and mobility. Word maps can be made using tape recorders but verbal descriptions have serious limitations in some applications. The paper will concentrate on the design, production and evaluation of embossed maps; the main problem areas are: (i) Identification of useful landmarks to a blind pedestrian.(ii) Coding this information in an embossed notation so that it can be read by touch. (iii) Production of the embossed map. (iv) Reading and interpretation of the information on the map. The application of computer-aided design techniques has enabled high quality maps to be produced which are relatively inexpensive when compared to the traditional labour-intensive manual methods of production. Experiments have been undertaken to identify sets of discriminable symbols and to compare various formats. Finally the paper will try to identify the most useful directions for future research in this field. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Society of university cartographers, Summer School 1974
Authors with affiliations: Hodgkiss, A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Map design—with the young in mind
Affiliations: North East London Polytechnic, London, E.17, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sorrell, P., North East London Polytechnic, London, E.17, United Kingdom
Abstract: The creation of maps for the use of young children requires that the map designer he aware of the abilities, needs, and attitudes of the child. The making of such maps differs only in degree from the design principles applied by cartographers in general mapping. Map content and structure must however appeal to an audience of 9-11 year olds. It is this specialisation of design criteria applied to a study involving some 300 young children that provides focus for examining the provision of atlases for the young. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: An application of subjective scaling techniques to map evaluation
Affiliations: Senior Psychologist, RAF Institute of Aviation Medicine, Farnborough, Hants, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, R.M., Senior Psychologist, RAF Institute of Aviation Medicine, Farnborough, Hants, United Kingdom
Abstract: Subjective scaling techniques were used to obtain quantitative data from twenty-six pilots and ten navigators in order to determine the perceived dimensions of eighteen 1:250 000 scale maps and to assess the suitability of the maps for en route navigation of low altitude high speed aircraft. Comparisons were made between perceived dimensions and assessments of map efficacy and between pilots' and navigators' assessments. The perceived dimensions correspond to major known differences in cartographic content and coding and were associated with the assessments of map efficacy. None of the maps tested was ideal; and pilots tended to be more critical of the maps than navigators, perhaps because they have less time for map reading inflight. Pilots preferred maps with bold, distinctive layer tint colours for representing relief, and both groups preferred maps with reduced information content and less visual clutter. 1:250 000 scale maps for en route low altitude high speed flight should use smaller selection rates for features than on conventional 1:250 000 scale maps and should be designed to give a clear and unambiguous impression of features that are distinctive from the air. © 1974 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Society record
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The accuracy of early maps? Towards a computer aided method
Affiliations: Geography Department, University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ravenhill, W., Geography Department, University of Exeter, United Kingdom; Gilg, A., Geography Department, University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Abstract: A methodology for assessing the planimetric accuracy of old maps is suggested and the results of its application to a map of Devon prepared by Benjamin Donn in 1765 are shown. The technique suggests that in terms of map-making, Donris Map of Devon was justifiably rated highly. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Postgraduate cartography courses
Affiliations: Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, Forest Road, London, E17 4JB, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cole, G.E.D., Department of Land Surveying, North East London Polytechnic, Forest Road, London, E17 4JB, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Aspects of relief portrayal on 19th century British military maps
Affiliations: Map Room, British Library, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jones, Y., Map Room, British Library, United Kingdom
Abstract: Throughout the nineteenth century, the study of military topography formed an integral part of the curriculum at British military training establishments. Within the wider topographical theme, the problem of relief representation on manuscript maps and sketches remained insurmountable for at least eighty years. This paper examines some of the teaching methods employed in drawing relief, and traces the transition from the generalised, artistic styles of the early 1800s to the uniform adoption of contouring by the War Office in 1880. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The automatic production of weather maps
Affiliations: Meteorological Office, Bracknell, Berkshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Menmuir, P., Meteorological Office, Bracknell, Berkshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: Weather observations are exchanged internationally by means of a world-wide communications network. A method is described for the automatic plotting or display in symbolic form of the weather observations onto weather maps. An I.B.M. 360/195 high speed computer is used at the Meteorological Office, Bracknell to process weather observations and incorporate them into a complex physico-mathematical model which is designed to simulate and predict changes in weather over much of the Northern Hemisphere. This paper also describes, in some detail, how the arrays of data values which are produced by the mathematical model are presented graphically in the form of isopleth or line-drawn maps by means of a conventional Computer Output on Microfilm equipment. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Authors: Coleman A., Isbell J.E., Sinclair G.
Title: The comparative statics approach to British land-use trends
Authors with affiliations: Coleman, A.; Isbell, J.E.; Sinclair, G.
Abstract: The existence of two complete land utilisation surveys of England and Wales offers unprecedented scope for examining national land use trends by the method of comparative statics. If this method is to yield valid results, there are a number of cartographic pitfalls which must be avoided, and these are explained under four headings: map projection, scale, base map characteristcs and the nature of the land-use classifications employed. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Automation and education in cartography
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S., Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: At the present time, relatively few cartographic staff are directly involved in automation, and we are still in the phase mainly of research and development. Nevertheless, the educa­tional implications of automation are considerable, as major changes in the systems of map production are bound to affect the content and requirements of educational programmes. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: A photo-mechanical technique for the production of drainage density maps
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gardiner, V., Department of Geography, University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Abstract: The importance of drainage density has long been recognised, but no rapid and inexpensive method exists for mapping its spatial distribution. A method based upon photo-mechanical changes of line weight is suggested. This is based upon the use of a whirling illuminator, and offers an effective means of mapping density. Some of the problems inherent in the technique are outlined, and its use is illustrated by a map of the drainage density of the London region. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Early maps of the Somersetshire Coal Canal
Affiliations: Department of Geology, The University, Keele, Staffordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Torrens, H.S., Department of Geology, The University, Keele, Staffordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Somersetshire Coal Canal has special significance for geologists and cartographers because William Smith (1769- 1839)—the father of English geology and a founder of geological cartography—was in turn engineer and surveyor to the Canal Company from 1793 to 1799. Smith's work during these years, which was some of his most important, has been the least documented of his entire career. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Development of automated large scale mapping at the survey department, of “Rijkswaterstaat”.
Affiliations: Data Processing Department, Ministry of Transport and Waterstaat, The Hague, Netherlands; Survey Department, Ministry of Transport Waterstraat, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kubik, K., Data Processing Department, Ministry of Transport and Waterstaat, The Hague, Netherlands; Tienstra, M., Survey Department, Ministry of Transport Waterstraat, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: During the past four years a system for digital large scale mapping from the photogrammetric model has been developed. In the beginning only readily available equipment was used, but gradually new instruments have been acquired that are better fitted to the task. The necessary software was provided by programmers within the Department. The system has been developed, according to the special needs of the Survey Department, although it would be relatively easy to adapt to other types of mapping. Digital mapping is quite successful and now accounts for about 25 per cent of all mapping. As the principle of digital mapping has been fully accepted, extension of the method is mainly a matter of investment in equipment, training of personnel and organisation. © 1974 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The factor of awareness
Affiliations: John Bartholomew and Son Ltd., Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bartholomew, J.C., John Bartholomew and Son Ltd., Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Kinniburgh, I.A.G., John Bartholomew and Son Ltd., Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: The authors discuss the application of some recent ideas in cartographic communication to the compilation of a new city plan of Edinburgh. The one factor which seems to link the cartographer to the map user is that of ‘awareness’ and this paper studies the problems faced in the production of this map from this viewpoint. This paper was read at the Society’s Annual Technical Symposium held at the University of Cambridge in September 1972. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Computer maps from a nominal survey system
Affiliations: University of Iowa, United States; State University of New York, Binghampton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rushton, G., University of Iowa, United States; Velde, E.J.V., State University of New York, Binghampton, United States
Abstract: A major problem in constructing land use maps is that locally recorded land use data are not often locationally identified in a form compatible with the input requirements of computer mapping programs. In this paper, the logic of a computer program is described which transforms into explicit locational coordinates, descriptions of land areas recorded according to a cadastral survey system. Accurate and inexpensive land use maps consequently can be produced directly by computer without recourse to a costly process of locational re-coding of individual land units. The program is illustrated with an example from local land records in the states of Punjab and Haryana, India. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The publication of urban topographic surveys in great Britain
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Williams, B.E.P.J., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: With the rapid urban development of recent years there has arisen a need for a more rapid dissemination of survey information. The efficiency and economics of successive editions of the conventional printed map for this purpose is questioned and it is suggested that, given a system of continuous revision, computer compatible numerical mapping systems, together with microfilming techniques will provide a better and more economic service. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.
