Title: The changing profile of the map user in great Britain
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Drewitt, B., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper, presented at the Society’s Annual Technical Symposium held at Cambridge University in September 1972, summarises the results of a market survey conducted in 1970. Map ownership and usage are discussed and some conclusions are drawn as to possible future trends. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Cartog raphic education in britain in 1973
Authors with affiliations: Maling, D.H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: British military surveys of palestine and syria 1840-1841
Affiliations: Map Room, British Museum, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jones, Y., Map Room, British Museum, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper draws attention to a survey operation whIch has received little acknowledgement since 1870. The numerous references to the survey published in the two decades succeeding its completion are fragmentary and contradictory in nature. They fail to treat the subject as a whole, omitting to place it in the military context. Hitherto unexamined material is used to augment existing information in order to trace the history of the survey from inception to completion. This paper was read in a shorter form to the Annual Technical Symposium of the Society in September 1972, at the University of Cambridge. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: International cartographic association iv general assembly, ottawa 1972 presidential address
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Colour and base in urban planning maps
Affiliations: University College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stringer, P., University College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Four map formats, differing in chromatidty and extent of base are compared for readability in an urban planning context. To test readability a repertory grid procedure and derived measures were used. The composition of the samples was based on seven biographical variables by analysis of co-variance. Hypotheses with respect to the effect on readability of map colour, but not of amount of base, were supported. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The mapping of great haseley and latchford: An episode in the surveying career of joel Gascoyne
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Exeter University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ravenhill, W., Department of Geography, Exeter University, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes a survey carried out by Joel Gascoyne in an area outside his usual sphere of operations. The sequence of events leading up to Gascoyne's appointment as surveyor are briefly discussed, followed by a description of the survey methods employed and an assessment of their accurcy. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Erratum to Automated selection of settlements in map generalisation (The Cartographic Journal, 9, 2, December 1972, 93-98)
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The Map Curators’ group 1972-73
Authors with affiliations: Abbott, M.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Fluorescent map and chart development
Affiliations: U.S. Naval Oceanographic Office, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crandall, C.J., U.S. Naval Oceanographic Office, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: The problem of map reading during the night, yet without losing night vision, and without being seen, is by no means a new one. This paper describes recent developments in the production of fluorescent nautical charts in the United States. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The conformal tetrahedric projection with some practical applications
Affiliations: Department of Lands and Survey, Wellington, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Lee, L.P., Department of Lands and Survey, Wellington, New Zealand
Abstract: The conformal projection of the sphere up Qn a regular tetrahedron is described, with a full Mathematical theory and a technique for computation. Some practical applications of the projection for continental groupings are suggested. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.

Authors: Rhind D.W., Shaw M.A., Howarth R.J.
Title: Experimental geochemical maps-A case study in cartographic techniques for scientific research
Affiliations: Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom; Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rhind, D.W., Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom; Shaw, M.A., Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom; Howarth, R.J., Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: A joint experiment is described in which possible methods of representation of geochemical element distributions were examined. Data, consisting of sampling site locations and the concentrations of some thirty elements in active stream sediments in part of Northern Ireland, were written on to magnetic tape in the proposed standard exchange format before being transferred from the AGRG to the ECU. Research indicated that proportional “wind-rose” symbols seemed to be the best compromise solution. Test maps using “wind-rose” symbols produced at varying scales and with different backgrounds by automated means. Evaluation tests were then devised and geochemists and cartographers used as test subjects. The results of these tests were low levels of accuracy in counting and estimating values; in addition, the effects of varying the cartographic parameters, such as map scale, were minimal. Reasons for this are discussed in the text. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: British cartographic society: Technical seminar dillington house, ilminster, somerset
Authors with affiliations: Sorrell, P.E.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cartographic presentation of threedimensional urban information
Affiliations: Department of Geography and Geology, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Lo, C.P., Department of Geography and Geology, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper describes two methods whereby the three-dimensional information relating to the forms and functions of buildings in the dty can be presented cartographically. The first method involves the use of the parallel perspective projection produced by coupling a photogrammetric plotter with the Perspektomat P-40 for the construction of three dimensional urban maps directly from aerial photographs. The second method involves the mapping of land use for each floor of the building on separate, stable transparent plastic sheets by means of pre-printed stick-on geometric patterns. By overlapping one sheet on top of the other, a superimposed pattern map of urban land use is produced. The advantages and disadvantages of these two methods are discussed and the significance of these methods to urban geographers and town planners is examined. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The perception of graduated squares as cartographic symbols
Affiliations: Bowling Green State University, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crawford, P.V., Bowling Green State University, OH, United States
Abstract: This study is an analysis of the average map reader's perception of the relative magnitude of graduated square symbols designed for small scale thematic maps. Two hypotheses are tested. First, that the relative size (area) differences of graduated squares are judged on the basis of area, rather than on the basis of a linear dimension. Second, that the relative magnitudes are estimated accurately. The results of the research positively support the above assumptions. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Cartographic source material and its evaluation
Affiliations: Military Surveys, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bond, B.A., Military Surveys, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper, presented at the Society’s Annual Technical Symposium, held at Cambridge in September 1972 looks at the two main problems faced by the map analyst, namely the availability of source material and an assessment of its reliability. Examples of some of the many problems en­countered are given. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Gino-A general purpose graphics system for cartography
Affiliations: Centre for Land Use and Built Form Studies, University of Cambridge, United Kingdom; Computer Aided Design Centre, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baxter, R.S., Centre for Land Use and Built Form Studies, University of Cambridge, United Kingdom; Shah, B.B., Computer Aided Design Centre, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: One of the main features of much of the work on automated cartography to date is the dependence of much of the software on the available hardware. GINO consists of a library of sub-routines which enable the user to generate displays on a wide range of hardware. This paper illustrates some of the possibilities of the system in the field of digital mapping. © 1973 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Colour on temperature maps
Affiliations: Temple University, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cuff, D.J., Temple University, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Abstract: Students’ reactions to three, coloured, test maps portraying temperature regions provide information vital to design of such maps for atlases and textbooks. A map using progressively lighter shades of red waS most effective in conveying the concept of areas of greater and lesser temperatures to most students. A map similarly shaded in only blue colours was almost as effective, despite the supposed association of blue with coolness. The third map, using shades of both red and blue was least effective. These preliminary results demonstrate that the quantitative message inherent in a progression of darkness and saturation is far more potent than the warm and cool association known to reside in red and blue hues. Design of maps according to a general and quantitative approach is indicated, even for map themes which may be linked qualitatively to certain hues. © 1973 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Mineralogical maps as forerunners of modern geological maps
Affiliations: Great Rissington, Gloucestershire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Eyles, V.A., Great Rissington, Gloucestershire, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Automated selection of settlements in map generalisation
Affiliations: Survey of Israel, Tel-Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Survey of Israel, Tel-Aviv, Israel
Abstract: In the field, of automated cartography the cartographic data bank is occupying an increasingly more prominent position. Within such data banks settlements occupy an important position and this paper discusses ways in which the automated selection of settlements may be achieved according to a number of varying criteria, each of which may or may not be included in the selection program. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Authors: Beckett P.H.T., Tomlinson P.R., Bie S.W.
Title: Map quality: The second st. cross seminar, Oxford, 1971
Affiliations: University of Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Beckett, P.H.T., University of Oxford, United Kingdom; Tomlinson, P.R., University of Oxford, United Kingdom; Bie, S.W., University of Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: A mathematical approach to the storage of digitised contours
Affiliations: Mapping and Charting Establishment (RE), Feltham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Breward, R.W., Mapping and Charting Establishment (RE), Feltham, United Kingdom
Abstract: The increasing use of digitised data, especially contours, is creating problems of storage in the smaller computers. Efforts made to make digitised contour information more compact for use in a data bank are described which can produce savings in storage requirements of up to 85 per cent. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Visit to school of military survey
Authors with affiliations: Loveless, W.C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: International cartographic association technical conference montreal/ottawa 1972
Authors with affiliations: O’Brien, C.I.M.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Human factors in cartographic communication
Affiliations: University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wood, M., University of Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: Cartographic communication involves the makers and the users of maps. Cartographers are constantly striving to produce better maps, through more carefully composed ‘messages' and more easily decipherable symbolism. Many maps already fulfil most of the requirements of functional efficiency, making them ‘good' in a communication sense, but a breakdown in communication often occurs. Map users misuse, misunderstand and mistake the reliability of maps, and are therefore frequently responsible for this breakdown. Techniques of ‘consumer research' and human factors' analysis currently being employed to provide for improved maps, are examined and evidence is found which supports this indictment. Finally possible remedies, particularly in the field of education, are indicated. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: User desires and graphics capability in the academic environment
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Kansas Geological Survey, The University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Kansas geoligical survey, The University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCullagh, M.J., Department of Geography, Kansas Geological Survey, The University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Sampson, R.J., Kansas geoligical survey, The University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States
Abstract: This paper is an attempt to determine the average geography academic's needs in relation to his research requirements and computing knowledge in automated map production. Usually he will not be attempting to produce a final map, but probably only one to enable him to analyse his data with more accuracy. An outline is given o-what the user can expect from a plotting system, and also what he will have to know to benefit from the results produced. The problem of contouring is taken as a demonstration of the difficulties involved. Examples are given to show that no computer contour map can be considered objective, and that the results produced are determined by the contouring method employed combined with the skill of the user. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Photomap image quality
Affiliations: University of Georgia, Athens, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Welch, R., University of Georgia, Athens, GA, United States
Abstract: Both image and photomap scales are being reduced and consequently the retention of detail in the cartographic process becomes increasingly difficult. It is suggested, therefore, that a systematic method based on Modulation Transfer Function (MTF) theory may be of value for evaluating the transfer of detail when planning map products. In order to maximise photomap detail the original photograph should be enlarged to a point where the MTF of the enlargement will not degrade the printing MTF. As the printing process is often limited by the method of screening the image, screening techniques which result in the retention of spatial frequencies to beyond 5 ljmm are required. Based on theoretical analyses of different types of imagery, enlargement factors of 4 to 8x for high-altitude aerial photography, less than lx for ERTS A imagery and from 10 to 20x for SKY LAB photographs will result in quality photomap products, provided suitable printing techniques are employed. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Further study of a computer­generated indexing technique
Authors with affiliations: Hall, B.
Abstract: A cumulative index has now been completed for the first eight volumes of the Cartographic Journal. This paper describes the system used to produce this index and shows how it was developed out of the earlier system described in the December 1970 issue of the Journal. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: A short history of ordnance survey contouring with particular reference to scotland
Affiliations: George Philip and Sons Ltd., London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Collier, H., George Philip and Sons Ltd., London, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper discusses early methods of contouring by the O.S., particularly in Scotland. Attention is paid to the methods of contouring and their accuracy and cost. It is clear that the modern O.S. maps produced photogrammetrically represent a considerable advance. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cartographic depiction of land resources information
Affiliations: Overseas Surveys, Tolworth, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carmichael, L.D., Overseas Surveys, Tolworth, United Kingdom
Abstract: Up to the present time maps showing land resources infor­mation have tended to develop with insufficient attention being paid to the cartographic problems involved. The author suggests that it is time the cartographer played a greater part in the design of such maps. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Lithography, photography and photozincography in english map production before 1870
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: At the Society's Annual Symposium held in Edinburgh in September 1971, the author read a version of the following paper. A number of technical and scientific topics relevant to the history of English cartographic reproduction in the earlier part of the nineteenth century are brought together in a broader historical context in the hope that more detailed studies in this neglected field will be undertaken. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: The effect of shaded relief on map information accessibility
Affiliations: University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Delucia, A., University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: Two experiments were conducted to measure the effect of shaded relief on map reading performance. The specific hypothesis being tested in both experiments was as follows: That the use of the shaded relief technique of terrain representation decreases the legibility of all other symbols appearing on the map thereby making the information represented by those symbols less accessible to the map reader. This results in a significant increase in the time necessary to extract required elements of non-terrain information from the map. Results of the initial experiment confirmed this hypothesis. A replication experiment found a statistically insignificant difference between the two versions of the test map. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Editorial
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: New degree courses in cartography university of edinburgh
Authors with affiliations: Macgregor, D.R.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Computer controlled drawing of hydrographic charts
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bateman, C., Department of Geography, University of Glasgow, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes a system of programs designed to automate the drawing of hydrographic charts directly from the raw survey data. Provision is made for intervention by the carto-grapher at critical stages so that the specification of the final product may be controlled. A consistent approach to the selection of critical data is formulated using universally applied criteria. The ease of selecting various scales and degrees of generalisation for replotting according to changing requirements is an important feature. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Cadastral survey and county atlases of the united states
Affiliations: University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thrower, N.J.W., University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: During the 75 years following the Revolutionary War the United States acquired its present continental-sized territory. To facilitate settlement of this vast area the rectangular United States Public Land Survey was employed. This contrasts with various unsystematic property surveys used in former colonial areas of America. Official cadastral maps of townships and counties were supplemented by those contained in privately produced county atlases in the second half of the nineteenth century. The character, contents and coverage of these county atlases which have survived, while cadastral maps on which they were based frequently have not, are discussed in this paper. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: The anastatic process in map reproduction
Affiliations: Library of Congress, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ristow, W.W., Library of Congress, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: Commencing in 1840 with the invention of anastatic printing by Baldamus in Germany, the development of the anastatic process, particularly in Britain and, to a lesser degree, in the United States is examined. Although the process created a considerable impact in its early days it never fulfilled its early promise.This paper was presented at the Society's Annual Technical Symposium held in Edinburgh in September 1971. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: Methods and progress in choropleth mapping of population density
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Portsmouth Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dixon, O.M., Department of Geography, Portsmouth Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper reviews the methods and weaknesses of choropleth mapping with particular reference to the mapping of population density. Various modifications are described and the possibilities of automation are discussed, with examples. © 1972 Maney Publishing.

Title: A survey of drivers’ opinions on maps for route finding
Affiliations: Road Research Laboratory, Crowthorne, United Kingdom; Experimental Cartography Unit, Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sheppard, D., Road Research Laboratory, Crowthorne, United Kingdom; Adams, J.M., Experimental Cartography Unit, Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: A questionnaire to 128 drivers included map reading tasks using inch to 1 mile maps produced by Philips (Shell Motoring Maps) and by the Ordnance Survey, followed by questions about which of the two maps was preferred and about the features required in a road map. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The retail distribution of ordnance survey maps and plans in the latter half of the nineteenth century—A map Seller’s view
Affiliations: Serck Services, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Aylward, J., Serck Services, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes the problems faced by map sellers, particularly Stanford’s, in the last century in the retail distribution of Ordnance Survey maps and plans. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Special purpose navigation charts
Affiliations: Hydographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pielou, F.A., Hydographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: The range of charts produced by the Hydrographic Department, other than the standard Admiralty Chart, is examined, with particular reference to charts for hovercraft. The demand for such charts creates special production problems. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Experimental maps of road travel speed
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Morrison, A., Department of Geography, The University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: The ideas behind road travel speed maps and the problems involved in designing such maps are described in detail. The author looks forward to the day when such maps might be regarded as ‘conventional road maps' enabling the road user to base his choice of route for a particular journey on more information than is currently available. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The work of the hydrographic department
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ritchie, R.A.G.S., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The genealogy of the isopleth
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.H., University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Defining isometric lines as those portraying basic numerical distributions and isopleths as portraying values, this paper traces the growth of the ‘iso’ family from the use of the isobath in 1584, through other members of the isometric family to the conception of the isopleth in 1845, its birth in 1857, and its christening in 1859. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Automated contouring—an empirical evaluation of some differing techniques
Affiliations: Experimental Cartography Unit, Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Rhind, D.W., Experimental Cartography Unit, Royal College of Art, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Three automated contouring programs have been utilised on the same data and their relative advantages and deficiencies are discussed under a number of headings. Desirable changes to these programs and the necessary capabilities of ‘third generation’ contouring programs are suggested. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: The hydrographic department chairman’s introductory remarks
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kingsland, F.H., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: National qualifications in cartography
Affiliations: Cartography and Planning, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gardiner, B.R.A.; Fullard, H., Cartography and Planning, United Kingdom
Abstract: This note introduces the guide syllabus and curriculum for the H.N.C. courses in Surveying, Cartography and Planning which follow. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The general bathymetric chart of the oceans—seventy years of international cartographic co-operation
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Newson, D.W., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: The General Bathymetric Chart of the Oceans (GEBCO) is a successful example of international cartographic co-operation. It originated in the last year of the nineteenth century, and its fourth edition is in course of publication. This paper traces the development of the series, in terms both of its cartography and of the organisation of its production. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: KOMPLOT “do-it-yourself” computer cartography
Affiliations: Survey of Israel, University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Survey of Israel, University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: After describing the changes which program packages, such as SYMAP, can make to the production of thematic maps the author briefly considers the aesthetics of computer graphics. The simplicity and versatility of KOMPLOT are then discussed with the aim of bringing computer aided cartography to a wider field of users. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Developments in automated cartography at the ordnance survey
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Irwin, M.S.G., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: The paper outlines the relevant principles of automated cartography, and considers the problems faced by the Ordnance Survey in applying them to its own operations. An account is given of the Bideford Area Experiment, carried out in conjunction with the Experimental Cartography Unit of the Royal College of Art, London, in which maps have been digitised at a large scale and draughted out at several smaller scales. The equipment in use at the Ordnance Survey is described, together with tests devised to monitor equipment accuracy. Reference is made to new investigations currently in hand, to assess the feasibility of selling digitised map data as a product in its own right. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Geological cartography in the undergraduate curriculum
Affiliations: University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boud, R.C., University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: For many years geological students have been graduating from universities with little knowledge of how to use the cartographic language of line, letter, symbol and tone by which the distribution and spatial arrangement of earth science data can be best expressed. The author discusses the development of the teaching of geological cartography in the Department of Earth Sciences at the University of Leeds. Details of this innovation are set against the background of data obtained from a recent questionnaire on the practice of cartography as a discipline in departments of geology in British universities. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Automation in the hydrographic department
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murt, G.E., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: The increasing use of automation, both on board ship and in the offices of the Hydrographic Department, is covered in this paper. At sea Automatic Data Logging should give the surveyor a better opportunity to check survey data before passing it to the office. Here considerable advantages are already being derived in the production of hyperbolic lattices and chart borders. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Some distinctive features of marine cartography
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kember, I.D., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: The small circle represents the small world of marine carto­graphy; the large circle is the great cartographic world outside—general cartography and all manner of non-marine specialisations. The overlap between the circles is considerable, for the marine cartographer depicts the same world as his colleagues working in other departments of cartography, and he shares most of their problems. However, this paper is concerned with differences rather than similarities and its subject is that part of the small circle that lies outside the larger one; this area represents all that is distinctive and nonconformist in marine cartography. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: An experiment in contour map smoothing on the ECU automated contouring system
Affiliations: Pennsylvania Research Associates, Whitesboro, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Connelly, D.S., Pennsylvania Research Associates, Whitesboro, NY, United States
Abstract: Experiments in the smoothing of contours produced by the ECU automated contouring system are described. The result is a flexible system within which the creative and interpretive skills of the cartographer can operate to produce a result which is acceptable quantitatively and qualitatively. © 1971 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Place-names on the early ordnance survey maps of England and Wales
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harley, J.B., Department of Geography, University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Abstract: A reconstruction is made of the methods by which the Ordnance Survey of Great Britain pioneered a system for establishing the place-name nomenclature on its maps in the nineteenth century. Until 1820 there was little to differentiate the practice of the Survey from that of earlier cartographers but, thereafter, official surveyors were encouraged to consult a wide range of written and oral authorities and were instructed to record their findings in special name books. By the midnineteenth century the essentials of the modern system had been laid down and many thousands of local names published in map form for the first time. This paper was read in a shorter form to the annual symposium of the Society in September 1970, at the University of Bristol. © 1971 The British Cartographic Society.

Title: Distribution maps of bcs membership as at 31st december 1969
Affiliations: Institute of Physical Chemistry, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bull, J., Institute of Physical Chemistry, United States
Abstract: As a compilation and drawing excercise, trainee draughtsmen in the Ministry of Housing and Local Government converted the BCS membership list into distribution maps, two of which are shown here. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The british cartography of eighteenth-century North America
Affiliations: The Newberry Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Woodward, D., The Newberry Library, United States
Abstract: A report on four lectures given by Professor William P. Cumming which comprised the second series of the Kenneth Nebenzahl Jr. Lectures in the History of Cartography at The Newberry Library, Chicago. © British Cartographic Society.

Title: Engraved maps from the english topographies c. 1660-1825
Affiliations: National Library of Wales, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Walters, G., National Library of Wales, United Kingdom
Abstract: The lack of satisfactory printed indices to the map content of English local topographical literature is discussed. The principal categories of maps and plans are outlined and set against the value of accompanying textual commentary. Subscription lists and ‘Proposals' are noted as examples of the necessity to explore the literature in depth. This paper was presented to the annual Symposium of the Society in September 1970, at the University of Bristol. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Experimental use of the search task in an analysis of type legibility in cartography
Affiliations: Field Enterprises Educational Corporation, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bartz, B.S., Field Enterprises Educational Corporation, Chicago, United States
Abstract: Search was used, as an experimental task to investigate one aspect of legibility in cartographic typography. Subjects searched a variety of maps under several different conditions. There are four major conclusions from this research. For random search of the maps containing only one typeface, the typographic variation from map to map did not produce a significant effect on average search time. On mixed-type maps, search is slowed if the user has no correct expectation of the appearance of the type in which the target name will appear. On these same maps, search is greatly speeded if the user has a correct expectation of the target name appearance. Search time in a one-name task is less a function of typography than it is of many other factors. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: S.U.C. summer school 1970
Affiliations: The Society of University Cartographers, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, E., The Society of University Cartographers, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Maps for planning
Affiliations: Ministry of Housing and Local Government, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandon, J.J., Ministry of Housing and Local Government, United States
Abstract: Maps play an important part in planning at national, regional and local levels. This role should increase in the future as greater use is made of computers. This paper was presented to the annual Symposium of the Society in September 1970, at the University of Bristol. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Population aggregations as a continuous surface: An example of computer mapping
Affiliations: State University of New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kolberg, D.W., State University of New York, United States
Abstract: Computer mapping is applied to the fields of business and planning to provide maps showing the number and percentage of persons living within a given distance at any point on the map. The use of a computer allows rapid revision of such maps which have been little used in the past due to the time factor involved in manual compilation. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Pseudo-conical world maps
Affiliations: Milford Haven Grammar School, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Watts, D., Milford Haven Grammar School, United Kingdom
Abstract: Further developments of Pseudo-Conical projections of the whole sphere are explained. Comments on suitable names for the projections would be welcomed. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The national atlas of Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wiggins, W.D.C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: John norden’s maps of cornwall: A problem in the historical cartography of South-West England
Affiliations: University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ravenhill, W., University of Exeter, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper discusses the evidence for the existence of John Norden’s manuscript maps of Cornwall and describes the investigations leading to their discovery. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: From base map to master plan
Affiliations: Llewelyn-Davies Weeks, Forestier-Walker and Bor, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Winterbottom, D., Llewelyn-Davies Weeks, Forestier-Walker and Bor, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The role played by maps in the planning of Milton Keynes is described in this paper. Milton Keynes is the latest of the new generation of New Towns in the UnitedKingdom. This paper was presented by the annual Symposium of the Society in September 1970 at the University of Bristol. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Danish topographic mapping
Affiliations: Geodætisk Institut, Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Gertsen, W.M., Geodætisk Institut, Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: This paper describes the range of topographic maps produced by the Danish Geodetic Institute, some of the production methods together with plans for the future. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: A marriage is being arranged…
Authors with affiliations: Hall, B.
Abstract: Experiments in computer-generated, indexing techniques, with particular reference to The Cartographic Journal, are described. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: The quantised line
Affiliations: University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Boyle, A.R., University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Abstract: The problem of digitising and regenerating continuous lines is considered from the point of view of the format of the digitised data and the quality of the regenerated line, both in width and positional accuracy. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: An experiment in atlas structure: The economic atlas of Ontario
Affiliations: University of Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dean, W.G., University of Toronto, Canada
Abstract: This atlas departs from the traditional geographcial or subject arrangement of contents, and attempts an organisation based on two levels of order: a horizontal division into nine sections, and a vertical division in the same sequential arrange¬ment. In each case the structure is arranged according to Distribution, Analysis and Synthesis. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Fifth technical conference of the international cartographic association, Stresa, 1970
Authors with affiliations: O’Brien, C.I.M.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The bulletin of the geography and map division
Affiliations: Special Libraries Association and Librarian, American Geographical Society, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mullins, L.S., Special Libraries Association and Librarian, American Geographical Society, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Political arithmetic
Authors with affiliations: Jeacock, S.; Wallis, H.
Abstract: A report on 'Political Arithmetic', comprising part of an exhibition to celebrate the 37th Session of the International Statistical Institute, London, 1969, held in the British Museumfrom 1st September 1969 to 18thJanuary 1970. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Authors: Koeman C., van der Weiden F.L.T.
Title: The application of computation and automatic drawing instruments to structural generalisation
Affiliations: State University of Utrecht, Geographical Institute, Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Koeman, C., State University of Utrecht, Geographical Institute, Utrecht, Netherlands; van der Weiden, F.L.T., State University of Utrecht, Geographical Institute, Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: This is an account of a series of experiments in computer generalisation, in which the outline of the Netherlands at 1:25 000 scale has been used to generate a series of generali­sations between 1:600 000 and 1:3 500 000. Eight examples are reproduced, six of which compare the automatic generali­sation with one taken from the Atlas of the Netherlands and the other two compare automatic generalisation using all digitised coordinates with that derived from using mean values of successive coordinates. The article was first published in Tijdschrift voor Kadaster en Landmeetkunde, 1969, 6, Leiden, under the title “Toepassing van de reken-en-tekenautomaat bij structurele generalisatie” and is published here by kind permission of the Editors. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: Abraham and yehuda cresques and the Catalan Atlas
Affiliations: Technion—Israel Institute of Technology, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Yoeli, P., Technion—Israel Institute of Technology, Israel
Abstract: This account analyses the history and composition of a famous ‘mapamundi’ produced in Majorca, and presented by Don Juan of Aragon to Charles VI of France in 1381. The original is in the Bibliothéque Nationale, Paris, from whom permission has been granted to reproduce the illustrations. They have been taken from a facsimile edition hand-painted by a Catalan artist. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: An analysis of the typographic legibility literature: Assessment of its applicability to cartography
Affiliations: Field Enterprises Educational Corporation, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bartz, B.S., Field Enterprises Educational Corporation, Chicago, United States
Abstract: In this article, an analysis of existing typographic legibility literature (in which the word ‘map’ never appears) is made which questions the applicability of such research findings to problems in cartographic type use. It is concluded that findings based on speed-of-reading measures for continuous text materials are probably not applicable to cartography, the physiological and psychological processes involved in ‘reading’ the names on a map appear to be quite different from those used in reading text. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: National qualifications in cartography
Authors with affiliations: Wiggins, W.D.C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Some new map projections of the world
Affiliations: Milford Haven Grammer School, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Watts, D., Milford Haven Grammer School, United Kingdom
Abstract: This explains a series of projections of the whole sphere, consisting mainly of interrupted and re-centred forms of the Sinusoidal, Pseudo-Cylindrical, Pseudo-Conical and Eckert0 and also some composites. The author indicates that he would be interested in receiving comments from those specialising in this problem. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: A survey of map user practices and requirements
Affiliations: University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kirby, R.P., University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: This describes an attempt to obtain quantative information about the maps and atlases people possess, and how they make use of them. The sample is derived essentially from Scotland and the North of England, with a bias towards people who are members of certain societies and as such likely to be map users. Over 1500 completed questionnaire forms are carefully analysed in relation to a large number of topics, including the use of maps of different scales, holdings of different types of atlas, etc. The tentative conclusions firmly indicate the value of research of this type. © 1970 British Cartographic Society.

Title: A note on the requirements of road map users
Affiliations: Dept. of Ergonomics and Cybernetics, Loughberough University of Technology, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Astley, R.W., Dept. of Ergonomics and Cybernetics, Loughberough University of Technology, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Further developments in producing photomaps as a basis for the economic map of sweden
Affiliations: Rikets Allmanna Kartverk, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Johannson, O., Rikets Allmanna Kartverk, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: A brief account of the history and development of the Economic Map of Sweden is followed by a detailed description of the changeover to an orthophoto base, and the problems encountered in the use of the first equipment for full production. Detailed costs are given of the production stages of comparable photomaps and orthophoto maps. Finally a new and improved device for the interpolation and direct production of contour lines is described. the paper was presented to the annual Symposium of the Society in September 1969, at the University of Glasgow. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The ordnance survey of northern ireland: An outline of its history and present mapping tasks
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey of Northern Ireland, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, W.R., Ordnance Survey of Northern Ireland, Ireland
Abstract: This explains the formation of the Ordnance Survey of Northern Ireland as a separate institution in 1921, when it took over the map series which until that time had been part of the Ordnance Survey (U. K.) responsibility. As happened with many mapping organisations, replanning and reorganisation took place after 1945; this included a triangulation for Northern Ireland to provide a basis for a new Irish Grid, and the introduction of the 1:1250 scale for major urban areas. the technical problems of reproduction and revision are then considered, and details given for each of the main series. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The use of watermarks in dating old series one-inch ordnance survey maps
Affiliations: Clarendon Press, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clarke, R.V., Clarendon Press, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper discusses the methods available for locating watermarks in Old Series maps. the watermarks found in over 2000 maps and their contribution to dating are analysed. the main conclusion is that the watermarks enable a particular sheet to be dated within a few years, especially in the period 1823-36. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Mapit: A computer program for production of flow maps, dot maps and graduated symbol maps
Affiliations: Michigan State University, University of Iowa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kern, R., Michigan State University, University of Iowa, United States; Rushton, G., Michigan State University, University of Iowa, United States
Abstract: This paper describes some results of an attempt to design and to write a general purpose computer program which can be used to produce quality maps of discrete data by the person who has had no training in computer programming. In the first section, the variety of the maps this program can produce is illustrated; in the second section, some of the principles involved in such map production are discussed; in the third section, the input arrangements for using the program are described and, finally, the role of such programs in teaching and research in the years ahead is discussed. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Third international conference on the history of cartography, and third international symposium of the coronelli-world league of friends of the globe
Authors with affiliations: Jeacock, S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Early experience in the photomapping technique
Affiliations: Fairey Surveys Ltd, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Scott, L., Fairey Surveys Ltd, United Kingdom
Abstract: The paper opens with a straightforward description of the types of photomap which can be produced, and the difference between photomaps and orthophoto maps. This is followed by details of experiments of a simple photomap process on a pictoline basis using the Maidenhead area as an example. Consideration of present and potential requirements leads to the conclusion that orthophoto maps can be more expensive to produce than conventional line maps, and that their application is likely to be limited to areas to which they are espedally suited. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Production of photomaps
Affiliations: Topografische Dienst Netherlands, International Institute for Aerial Surveys & Earth Sciences, (ITC) Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Zuylen, L., Topografische Dienst Netherlands, International Institute for Aerial Surveys & Earth Sciences, (ITC) Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper comprises a short review of the methods followed and the results which have been obtained in Delft at the Topographic Service of the Netherlands and at the International Training Centre for Aerial Survey and Earth Sciences. After an introduction describing the principle of orthophotograph production, applications in the Netherlands, South Korea, Saudi Arabia and Mauritius are discussed. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The national council of cartographers of the u.s.s.r.
Affiliations: Academy of Sciences U.S.S.R., Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Polezhayev, A.P., Academy of Sciences U.S.S.R., Russian Federation
Abstract: Excerpts from ‘National Council of Cartographers (NSK) U.S.S.R. and its activity in assuring the international co-operation of Soviet Cartographers’, Reprinted, with permission of the publishers, from Geodesy and Aerophotography, no. 3, 1968; translated and produced by scripta technica, inc., for the American Geophysical Union, co-sponsored by the American Congress of Surveying and Mapping and the American Society of Photogrammetry. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The accuracy of area measurement by point counting techniques
Affiliations: Leningrad University, Russian Federation; University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Frolov, Y.S., Leningrad University, Russian Federation; Maling, D.H., University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper deals with the nature of the sampling errors which may occur in measurement of area by a square pattern ‘dot planimeter’. the important conclusion is that the relative error of measurement is small if the count of points is of the order of 100 per parcel. the authors recommend the use of different sizes of point pattern for the measurement of different sizes of parcel, rather than the use of a single overlay for the measurement of every parcel on a given map. the theoretical work is supported by some results of measurements made on the McKay Pattern Map using the MK Area Calculator. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: 21st international geographical congress of the international cartographic association
Authors with affiliations: O’Brien, C.I.M.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The importance of cartography to modern states
Authors with affiliations: Thackwell, B.D.E.O.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The relief of map making
Affiliations: Directorate of Overseas Surveys, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carmichael, L.D., Directorate of Overseas Surveys, United Kingdom
Abstract: Two experiments are described and illustrated for the combination of layer tints and hill-shading; the’ Unit’ system using three printing colours for tints and a grey for the shading, and the ‘Reverse Layer’ system with three plates. the map extracts have been reproduced by permission of the Director of Surveys and Lands, Sierra Leone. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic information—a fundamental concept and term in modern cartography
Affiliations: Prague Research Institute for Geodesy and Cartography, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Koláčný, A., Prague Research Institute for Geodesy and Cartography, Czech Republic
Abstract: An examination is made of the theoretical relationship between the processes of map use and of map making, in which the map is regarded as a communication system. This has developed from practical work originally done with regard to a series of school atlases in Czechoslovakia. A Commission on ‘Cartographic Information’ is recommended. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Authors: Diello J., Kirk K., Callander J.
Title: The development of an automated cartographic system
Affiliations: Rome Air Development Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Diello, J., Rome Air Development Center, United States; Kirk, K., Rome Air Development Center, United States; Callander, J., Rome Air Development Center, United States
Abstract: A paper is presented on the development of an Automated Cartographic System as is currently being carried out by the United States Air Force at Rome Air Development Center. Included are the system’s concepts and overall goals of the program. of particular interest is Experimental Cartographic Facility (ECF) and the Experimental Colour Scanner. the ECF has resulted from a continuing need for improved mechanisation and eventual automation in the field of cartography. the Experimental Colour Scanner is under development for evaluation purposes and will be used in the ECF program to evaluate its utility for manuscript manipulation. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: An agricultural atlas of scotland
Affiliations: University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Coppock, J.T., University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: An account is given of the theoretical and practical problems of producing a series of maps from available statistical data. the source material and in particular the disparities in area of the statistical units are treated in detail. A simple program was developed for use with the KDF9 computer with line printer output, and eventually this was used to provide a compilation for drawing rather than a finished product. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Thematic mapping by computer
Authors with affiliations: Gaits, G.M.
Abstract: The Urban Planning Directorate of the Ministry of Housing and Local Government has recently developed the computer mapping system LINMAP 1 (LINe printer MAPping) to illustrate the use and facility of the Coordinate Referencing System for locating statistical information in geographical space. Current work on the second, very much extended version of this system, together with the development of the COLMAP (COLour MAPping) system, is described in this article. © 1969, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Education in cartography—a great step forward
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: How long is a piece of string?
Affiliations: University College, Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mating, D.H., University College, Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: This is a summary of the problems which are involved in the apparently trivial task of measuring the length of a sinuous line on a map. It represents an extended review of the publication Cartometric Measurements, by H. Kishimoto. It is concerned with three basic problems: (1) the sorts of errors which may result from using different instruments and methods of measurement and how these may be corrected: (2) the sorts of errors which may occur in the map and how these may be corrected: 3) the fundamental problem of what is ‘length’. Extensive use is made of East European literature on these subjects. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The graphical construction of map projections of the sphere
Affiliations: Waltham Forest Technical College, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Allan, A.L., Waltham Forest Technical College, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Hydrographic surveying and data processing
Affiliations: Head of Survey Techniques, Hydrographic Department, Swedish Board of Shipping and Navigation, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thunberg, A., Head of Survey Techniques, Hydrographic Department, Swedish Board of Shipping and Navigation, United States
Abstract: The automatic data processing system developed for hydrographic surveying in Sweden is explained in detail. the methods presently in use, which automatically process echogram information, will eventually be developed into a fully automated system. the kind permission of the International Hydrographic Office is acknowledged for the re-publication of material already presented in the International Hydrographic Review. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Some problems of measuring land use in underdeveloped countries: The land use survey of malawi
Affiliations: Land Resources Division, Directorate of Overseas Surveys, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stobbs, A.R., Land Resources Division, Directorate of Overseas Surveys, United Kingdom
Abstract: The methods used in the Land Use Survey of Malawi are described as an example of how statistical sampling applied to air photo coverage can give adequate information economically about the distribution of types of cultivated, uncultivated and uncultivable land. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: S. Keates, J.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Themes in the large scale mapping of wales in the eighteenth century
Affiliations: National library of Wales, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Walters, G., National library of Wales, United Kingdom
Abstract: The emergence of eighteenth-century private mapping, on a scale approximating to one inch to a mile, is placed in a Welsh regional setting. the various abortive ‘Proposals’ are examined, and the relevance of the study of estate maps, local surveyors and their practices, is stressed as an essential complement to knowledge derived from printed maps. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Error and revision in early ordnance survey maps
Affiliations: University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harley, J.B., University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Abstract: The early One Inch maps of the Ordnance Survey of Great Britain, especially those published in the period up to c. 1820 were far less accurate than subsequent maps in the Old Series. the paper relates this characteristic to the changing organization and methods of topographical survey, and discusses hitherto unexamined evidence for the widespread revision of inferior maps. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Engraved ordnance survey one-inch maps—the methodology of dating
Affiliations: Official History of the Ordnance Survey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I., Official History of the Ordnance Survey, United Kingdom; Clark, P.K., Official History of the Ordnance Survey, United Kingdom
Abstract: In an earlier article the problem of dating the maps was considered in the light of the significance of the embossed date stamp used after 1850. the presence of watermarks in the map paper points to a new terminus ad quem in dating maps of the earlier period, permitting the development of a new methodology. This article formed the basis of a lecture read by Ian Mumford at the British Cartographic Society’s Symposium in September 1968. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The water control map of the netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Piket, G.
Abstract: The Water Control Map of the Netherlands (Waterstaatskaart) is fundamental to the management of drainage and water supply. In this paper it is fully treated, from its historical development to the technical details of current production methods. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Visual perception and map design
Affiliations: University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wood, M., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: Visual perception is reviewed in relation to the search for principles in map design. Various cues of ‘depth’ are examined as aids in the specification of the qualities and dimensions of map symbols. Maps are analysed on the basis of ‘receding planes’, each plane containing a specific selection of graphic information. A design procedure is outlined in this content, and finally an example of a thematic map, the Residential Land Use of Glasgow-1965, is presented in detail. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The map collection of the deutsche bucherei, leipzig
Affiliations: Deutsche Bücherei, Lei pzig, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dammhain, J., Deutsche Bücherei, Lei pzig, Germany
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Topographic science at the university of glasgow
Affiliations: University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Petrie, G., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom; Keates, J.S., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: The problems of devising university courses in topographic science subjects, culminating in the institution of a full B.Sc. degree, are examined in relation to parallel developments elsewhere. Details of course content and structure are given, in the expectation that specific examples will provide discussion points for those concerned with the development of education in cartography. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The admiralty chart: Trends in content and design
Affiliations: Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Magee, G.A., Hydrographic Department, Taunton, United States
Abstract: In 1967 the Hydrographer of the Navy, guided by a report from his professional advisers and with the support of many chart users with whom the main proposals were discussed, took a number of decisions to modernise the Admiralty Chart. the author heads one of the sections of the Nautical Chart Branch; and this paper, which follows lectures given to the Society last year, examines the factors of changing navigational requirement on the one hand and of cartographic opportunity on the other which have led to the new policy. A number of practical limitations imposed on cartographic expression in marine charts are outlined. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Engraved ordnance survey one-inch maps—the problem of dating
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: The problem of dating maps for purposes of historical and other research is examined in relation to the early Ordnance Survey one inch sheets. the use of the date stamp, where this has been retained, is shown to be a useful and reliable method. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Problems encountered in producing the national atlas of the netherlands
Affiliations: Geological and Mineralogical Institute, University of Leiden, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Pannakoek, A.J., Geological and Mineralogical Institute, University of Leiden, Netherlands
Abstract: The general problems of producing a national atlas are discussed and illuminated with specific examples. Organisation, compilation and generalisation, selection of contents, scales, and other basic issues are treated in the first place, and these are followed by an examination of the more subtle cartographic problems of design, colour, and the presentation of statistics. A provisional table of contents is appended. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: A cartographic data bank for ordnance survey maps
Affiliations: Royal College of Art Cartographic Laboratory, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Howard, S.M., Royal College of Art Cartographic Laboratory, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: A preliminary investigation into the problems of recording point and line information on maps in digital form for storage and subsequent computer processing. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: An optimum continental projection
Authors with affiliations: Macdonald, R.R.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The mapping of distribution parameters
Affiliations: Survey of Israel, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Survey of Israel, Israel
Abstract: The basic problems of presenting statistics on maps are treated mainly from the statistical point of view. the relevance of such fundamental values as measures of centrality is explained, and the use of the distribution cross for geographical statistics is presented in detail. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Telescopic model making
Affiliations: Cartographer, Ministry of Defence, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Goodson, A.E., Cartographer, Ministry of Defence, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The practical problems of producing relief models for various cartographic and other purposes have been investigated by the author for some years, and have led to the development of particular processes. This paper deals with a device for cutting along contours by pantograph in polyurethane plastic and lowering the layers successively. the advantages of this technique are compared with other relief modelling techniques. the construction of a prototype machine was financed by the National Research and Development Corporation, and this is now undergoing further development. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bennett H.A., Hogg L.A., Lockyer A.A.H.
Title: The land map and air chart at 1:250,000
Affiliations: Survey Production Centre, R.E., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, H.A., Survey Production Centre, R.E., United Kingdom; Hogg, L.A., Survey Production Centre, R.E., United Kingdom; Lockyer, A.A.H., Survey Production Centre, R.E., United Kingdom
Abstract: This new double series, commonly known under its combined title, ‘Joint Operations Graphic’ (JOG), is an ambitious attempt to create a new map series of world-wide coverage, suitable in its alternative forms for both ground and air operations. Conflicts of requirement between services, and between allied mapping agencies, inevitably make this an extremely difficult problem. the task is systematically analysed with regard to planning, specification, production methods and problems, and product evaluation. the accompanying printed map specimen has been provided by courtesy of Survey Production Centre. the paper was first given at the Symposium of the British Cartographic Society, Newcastle upon Tyne, September 1967. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The symap programme for computer mapping
Affiliations: Council of Europe, Strasbourg, France
Authors with affiliations: Robertson, J.C., Council of Europe, Strasbourg, France
Abstract: For several years Howard T. Fisher and his staff at the Laboratory for Computer Graphics, Harvard, have been developing basic programs for the computer-controlled plotting of statistical data related to spatial distributions. For the widest possible application these programs have been devised for use with a ‘standard’ line printer with its ‘typographic’ symbols, operated by the FORTRAN IV machine language. Despite the unsophisticated nature of the end-product in conventional cartographic terms, the author demonstrates and illustrates the value of the rapid analysis of large volumes of data, as a means of testing hypotheses and generating useful statistical maps. Further improvements are currently being developed. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Pictorial navigation displays
Affiliations: Ministry of Technology, Royal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Honick, K.R., Ministry of Technology, Royal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, United Kingdom
Abstract: A pictorial navigation display for aircraft is described, in which the aircraft’s ground position and track are continuously displayed, superimposed on the projected image in colour of a topographical map stored on microfilm. the microphotographic technique developed for preparation of the map films is also described. A navigation display of this type will be incorporated in the prototype Concorde supersonic airliner. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Authors: Dennett J.R.B., Hobbs L.H.E., White B.F.
Title: Cartographic production control
Affiliations: Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dennett, J.R.B., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom; Hobbs, L.H.E., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom; White, B.F., Ordnance Survey, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: The production of large series of maps at many different scales, for both official and private use, constitutes a major task in production control. This is examined in relation to the Divisions primarily involved; Large Scales, Small Scales; and Publication. Each Division has a Control Section which deals wiih the planning of flow lines, programme integration, and product supervision. These Sections are placed between management and production, and play an important role in providing the information needed for management decisions and applying such decisions to actual production. the paper was given at the Symposium of the British Cartographic Society, Newcastle upon Tyne, September 1967. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The maps of carsten niebuhr: 200 years after
Affiliations: University of Du rham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hopkins, I.W.J., University of Du rham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This is an account of the cartographic work which resulted from a Danish expedition to Arabia in the seventeen-sixties. Niebuhr was one of those early travellers who made a serious attempt to record systematically the geographical facts about the places he visited, producing both small-scale general maps of Arabia, Egypt, Syria, etc., and town plans of important cities such as Cairo and Baghdad. His work constitutes a remarkable attempt to accomplish some precise mapping in what was then a virtually unmapped part of the world. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Humboldt’s map of isothermal lines: A milestone in thematic cartography
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, United States; Map Room, British Museum, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.H., University of Wisconsin, United States; Wallis, H.M., Map Room, British Museum, United Kingdom
Abstract: This year is the sesquicentennial anniversary of the presentation of Alexander von Humboldt’s paper on isothermal lines to the Paris Academy of Science. This employment of the isarithm for spatial distribution by an outstanding natural scientist contributed largely to the widespread adoption of this technique in thematic cartography. the complexities of the original evidence are unravelled, and its influence traced on many subsequent publications, particularly atlases, in the nineteenth century. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The pattern map: A reliability standard for area sampling methods
Authors with affiliations: McKay, C.J.
Abstract: Measurement of areas is necessary in many studies based on maps. Where precise measuring equipment is not available, more simple methods must be used. the information so produced can be improved in value if the degree of accuracy of the measuring technique can be stated. This paper demonstrates a ‘model’ by which results of the measuring technique can be judged against calculations for the same units, which are exact to one thousandth of a square centimetre. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: A dictionary of land surveyors in britain
Affiliations: Cou nty Record Office, Sussex, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Steer, F.W., Cou nty Record Office, Sussex, United Kingdom
Abstract: For several years the author pursued the difficult task of trying to establish a unified index or record of land surveyors and their work in Britain. A questionnaire was sent to archivists and custodians for relevant information (for the period up to 1850), and this led to the collection growing to such a size that it became impossible to carry it on as a private venture. the entire documentation has now been transferred to the Department of English Local History in the University of Leicester, and it is hoped that a dictionary will be published in due course. This paper was given at the Conference on the History of Cartography, Royal Geographical Society, London 1967. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The oblique zenithal equidistant projection
Affiliations: King’s Park Secondary School, Glasgow, United Kingdom; University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ward, K.W., King’s Park Secondary School, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Bateman, C., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: The idea of constructing an equidistant map centred on Glasgow originated as a school project. the amount of calculation required meant that it was necessary to use a computer to calculate the co-ordinates for the projection on a 15° graticule. Subsequently it was decided to write a program to instruct another computer, equipped with a graph plotter, to plot the same graticule automatically. the basic mathematical constructions and the procedure for programming the computer for automatic plotting are fully explained. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The mechanisation of analytical hill shading
Affiliations: Cartographic Institute, Technion, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Yoëli, P., Cartographic Institute, Technion, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: The first part of this paper is the author’s translation of his “Die Mechanisierung’ der Analytischen Schattierung”, which was first published in Kartographische Nachrichten, 16,3, 1966 and is included here by permission of the editors and publishers. A re-statement of the basic principles of the method is followed by an examination of the three main operations: the provision of data required for the computing of light intensity; the computation of the light intensity; and the graphic representation. In the second part the possibilities of the practical application of the method are treated in relation to the combination of shading and contours, hill-shading and air photographs, hill-shading and measurement of slopes, and hill-shading and reproduction. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: A cartographic analysis of the glasgow 1961 census
Affiliations: University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jelliman, M., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: Population data at Enumeration District level were made available in Britain for the first time after the 1961 Census. the difficulties of constructing a series of comparable maps for one city are analysed with regard to (a) the general problem of the fragmentation of enumeration districts and (b) methods of classification. Data extraction was by computer processing, but the construction of the maps was manual. Seven Census topics were finally selected and combined with a summary map of land use and house types. These are included as a set of two-colour illustrations, scale 1:100,000. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Preparing and printing soil maps in ireland
Affiliations: National Soil Survey of the Agricultural Institute, Wexford, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Lynch, J., National Soil Survey of the Agricultural Institute, Wexford, Ireland
Abstract: The soil survey of the Republic of Ireland is conducted on a county basis, using the currently-available 1:10,560 scale map series for field work. Publication scale is 1:126,720. Problems of the cartographic design and preparation of a multi-colour thematic map are examined, and the use of line screens (adapted from the methods of the Netherlands Soil Survey) are explained in detail. Control of the printed colour density, using a densitometer, was also investigated. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The selection of towns and other features on atlas maps of nigeria
Affiliations: University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dixon, O.M., University College of Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: Several educational atlases and one reference atlas are selected, and the treatment of Nigeria critically examined. All are found to be deficient, to a greater or lesser degree, in the generalisation of coastline, hydrography, relief and the selection and classification of towns. Concentrating on the last topic, information of both objective and subjective nature is given, derived from the author’s research in Nigeria; and based on this, proposals are made and illustrated for a more effective treatment of the selection and classification of towns. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: A comparison of some methods of mapping census data of the british isles
Affiliations: Queen Mary College London, United Kingdom; London School of Economics and Political Science, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Storrie, M.C., Queen Mary College London, United Kingdom; Jackson, C.I., London School of Economics and Political Science, United Kingdom
Abstract: The mapping of population on an areal basis, when the unit areas vary greatly, provides difficulties in the construction of useful maps. Data on household tenure for the component parts of the British Isles were analysed in several ways by computer processing. the contrast between maps based on individual countries, compared with maps of the whole of the British Isles, is explained and illustrated.
