Methods of analysis based on octiles, deviations and equal divisions are compared, demonstrating the advantages of high-speed computer processing in facilitating experiments with different classification systems. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Machine accuracies in automatic cartography
Affiliations: Automatic Systems Laboratories Ltd, Leighton Buzzard, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wolfendale, P.C.F., Automatic Systems Laboratories Ltd, Leighton Buzzard, United Kingdom
Abstract: The nature of random errors, machine errors and execution accuracy are explained in relation to the accuracy requirements of automatic plotting and drawing. the importance of discontinuity in linework is stressed, emphasising the distinction between planimetric accuracy and ‘aesthetic’ accuracy. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: A technique for the preparation of block diagrams
Affiliations: Directorate of Overseas Surveys, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Carmichael, L.D., Directorate of Overseas Surveys, United Kingdom
Abstract: The investigation of land resources frequently requires the construction of block diagrams. When the source material consists of vertical aerial photographs, without contours, the stereo-image must be ‘held’ in some way for an oblique view to be constructed. After considerable experiment, a method based on modelling was adopted, and-this is explained. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The scottish record office plan collection
Authors with affiliations: Adams, I.H.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Population enumeration on a grid square basis: The census of scotland, a test case
Affiliations: University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Forbes, J., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom; Robertson, I.M.L., University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: After examination of the existing Census organisation, the problems of making full use of the data are investigated, in particular the disparity of units on the ground, changes over time, and variations in the nature of the published information. Proposals are made and explained for the adoption of a grid square enumeration system, which in this case is tested by application to an urban and a rural area. the problem of conflict between grid square and local authority boundary is examined. the more general usefulness of a grid square enumeration system is demonstrated in relation to comparability of data, mechanisation of processing and graphic output, and the data bank concept. Further testing by means of a sample census is being currently undertaken. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Uncultivated fields in the history of british cartography
Affiliations: University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harley, J.B., University of Liverpool, United Kingdom
Abstract: An appraisal of the present state of research into the history of British cartography is made, in comparison with the scholarship of earlier periods, and especially with reference to the documentation of ‘modern’ topographic mapping. Suggestions are put forward for the development of bibliographical studies (in particular specialised map catalogues), biographical studies and the evaluation of early maps. © 1967, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Some notes about the trystan edwards projection
Affiliations: University College, Swansea, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Maling, D.H., University College, Swansea, United Kingdom
Abstract: This projection is critically examined and the claim that it has the property of equivalence is refuted. the basis of a modified cylindrical equal-area projection is rigorously defined, and the inaccuracy of the Trystan Edwards projection demonstrated. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Tests of significance cartographic output
Affiliations: Survey of Israel and University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kadmon, N., Survey of Israel and University of Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: The importance of the statistical analysis of changes in cartographic output is demonstrated through an example taken from the work of the Cartographic Section of the Survey of Israel. Methods of testing cartographic output are considered, both parametric and non-parametric. the use of the regression line to obtain a forecast is explained, and significant and periodic breakdown investigated. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Notes on two projections
Affiliations: University of Michigan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tobler, W.R., University of Michigan, United States
Abstract: The development of projections with loxodromic properties is considered with regard to the azimuthal equidistant, and an example is given centred at 45°N, 0°E. the nature and value of the two-point equidistant projection is discussed and an example given centred on London and Wellington. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Further thoughts on the representation of vegetation on topographic and planimetric maps
Affiliations: Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: McGrath, G., Queen’s University, Kingston, ON, Canada
Abstract: The content of topographic and planimetric maps in relation to vegetation is examined with reference to the evaluation of contouring, the degree to which vegetation impedes movement, forestry, recreation, the planning of development projects, route planning, vegetation as base map information, and land use. This is an extension of the paper published in the Cartographic Journal, vol. 2, no. 2, and refers in particular to Africa South of the Sahara. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: A note on the history of scribing
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Woodward, D., University of Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Exercise ‘overcast’
Authors with affiliations: Smith, N.H.S.J.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Numerically controlled methods of automatic plotting and draughting
Authors with affiliations: Petrie, G.
Abstract: The equipment available for numerically controlled plotting and draughting is reviewed and certain devices described in some detail. Several systems suited to the digitising of cartographic material exist, while the available plotters may be classified broadly into three categories—those derived from surveying and photogrammetric practice, those associated with computer technology and a group designed substantially for cartographic applications. Finally the various input and output devices associated with cartographic digitising are discussed with special emphasis on their storage capacity, speed of operation and economy. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Meetings of the international cartographic association
Authors with affiliations: Thackwell, B.D.E.O.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Possibilities for computer animated films in cartography
Affiliations: Prairie du Sac, Wisconsin, United States; University of Wisconsin, Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cornwell, B., Prairie du Sac, Wisconsin, United States; Robinson, A.H., University of Wisconsin, Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: This paper describes pioneer work in animated mapping with computers, using the cathode ray tube fixed intensity beam as the drawing ‘tool’ on the ‘raster’ or working area. the controlled light image is recorded by a shutterless cine camera. Replacement of the draughtsman by a computer makes possible the automatic drawing of images by slight successive changes, resulting in an animated map. Examples are given from several scientific fields. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The compilation of a three-component map of southern africa
Affiliations: London School of Economics, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Board, C., London School of Economics, United Kingdom; Wilson, E., London School of Economics, United Kingdom
Abstract: The problems of devising a thematic map with three variables are examined in relation to the graphic limitations of black and white illustration. the advantages and disadvantages of various statistical approaches are discussed, and the final design is evolved through a series of experiments. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Geographical globes
Authors with affiliations: McGregor, D.R.
Abstract: This review of the use of geographical globes in teaching condemns the poor usage made of an important geographical tool. the basic reasons for the use of globes in teaching children fundamentals about the earth are re-stated, and the author pleads for the supply of a globe for each child. the design of suitable globes for different levels of instruction is dealt with, and the complementary use of globe and map. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The principles of selection
Authors with affiliations: Töpfer, F.; Pillewizer, W.
Abstract: The fundamental of cartographic generalisation, the reduction of the amount of information which can be shown on a map in relation to reduction in scale, is examined. the Principle of Selection was first proposed by Töpfer in 1961, and is expressed as an equation relating the number of occurrences of a particular feature at source map scale and at derived map scale. the application of this to small-scale maps involves the introduction of two constants to represent symbolic exaggeration and symbolic form. Examples are given and illustrated. the paper is accompanied by explanatory notes by Dr D. H. Maling, who presented the paper on behalf of the authors at the XX International Geographical Congress London 1964, Section IX, Cartography. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Principles of road classification for road maps
Affiliations: Geography Department, McGill University, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Morrison, A., Geography Department, McGill University, Canada
Abstract: A road traveller may expect from a road map information on: (a) where roads exist; (b) what types of traffic can and may use them; (c) which is the best route, and hew good it is; and (d) information which will help him to follow the route chosen. In choosing the best route he needs to know for each available route the likely journey time, cost, safety, amenity, mental ease, physical comfort, certainty of following the route and the availability of services. the relevance to these needs of about 30 possible road classification criteria is discussed. Among the most relevant are availability, average overall speed, delay probability, accident rate, and ‘arteriality’, together with the marking of distances, tolls and road numbers, and the correct plan representation of the road. Use of the most relevant classifications may be prevented by the lack of published data, the cost of obtaining data from unpublished records or from road or aerial surveys, the need for simplicity, or the limitations imposed by representation. Some practical possibilities appear to be more specialised road maps; maps of typical speeds estimated from available data with the aid of traffic engineering theory, and perhaps presented in the form of modified mileage figures; and the collection of relevant data by government. Experiments are needed. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Aviation cartography
Authors with affiliations: Meine, K.-H.
Abstract: The growth of aviation cartography is traced from its beginnings at the end of the 19th century. Existing topographic maps with overprints, used for visual navigation, were largely supplanted by special charts for navigation and traffic control from the ground. the various types of map and chart, according to their functions, scales and methods of presentation, are classified. After 1919 the development of international aviation brought about the need for international co-operation in cartography, in which the I.C.A.O. has played an important part. Great technical advances during and after World War II demanded reappraisal of the types of chart produced, and in particular the relationship of world chart series with other geographical map series. the need for series at smaller scales is examined. Cartographic aids to space exploration and the mapping of the moon have introduced an entirely new set of problems for modern cartography, and the methods devised will influence cartographic techniques in general. the analysis of air traffic by cartographic techniques is an important aspect of the thematic mapping of communication patterns. © 1966, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic news
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Post-war progress in cartography in the federal republic of germany
Authors with affiliations: Rugg, D.S.
Abstract: The author spent six years in Germany as Geographic Attache to the United States Embassy in Bonn. His contacts with the cartographic industry resulted in this appraisal of German cartography. He is now Associate Professor in the Department of Geography, University of Nebraska. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The representation of vegetation on topographic maps
Authors with affiliations: McGrath, G.
Abstract: Although some aspect of vegetation is frequently included in both topographic and small-scale maps, the nature of what is being shown is rarely examined critically. A member of the Department of Geography, Queen's University, Ontario, draws attention to the problems of both content and presentation. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The earliest maps of southampton
Authors with affiliations: Welch, E.
Abstract: In editing the early maps of Southampton for reproduction, the City Archivist has made a detailed study of their origins. This account demonstrates the precautions which must be taken in dealing with old maps and plans. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Society record
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Suitable projections for maps of the visible surface of the moon
Authors with affiliations: Maling, D.H.
Abstract: This article examines the choice of projection adopted by the U.S. Army Map Service for the lunar maps published by them. A variety of modified azimuthal projections are suggested, all of which would possess some useful mathematical property desirable for lunar maps. The author is a Senior Lecturer in Geography at the University College of Swansea. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Register control in map reproduction
Authors with affiliations: Gale, D.W.
Abstract: The control of register in map production is a problem of common interest to cartographers. New materials and new techniques have facilitated advances towards improved register control. This article recounts the experience of the 13th Field Survey Squadron, R.E., and the techniques developed for their particular requirements. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Some technical and economic limitations of cartographic colour representation on land use maps
Authors with affiliations: Coleman, A.
Abstract: Some problems of land use map production are analysed in the general context of colour cartography by a Senior Lecturer in Geography, King's College, University of London, who is also Director of the Second Land Utilisation Survey of Britain. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Cartographic news & technical notes
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The future of the international map
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, A.H.
Abstract: Well-established conventions are difficult to challenge, if only because they are so often overlooked. In this paper the basic assumptions of the International Map of the World at 1:1,000,000 are examined by a Professor of Geography of the University of Wisconsin, who is also Director of the University Cartographic Laboratory. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The special archaeological and historical maps published by the ordnance survey
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, C.W.
Abstract: The recording of historical and archaeological sites in Britain depends largely on the work of the Ordnance Survey. The former Archaeology Officer describes the development of this work within the Ordnance Survey and treats in detail the special maps published on historical and archaeological topics. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Three types of reconnaissance mapping
Authors with affiliations: Wright, J.W.
Abstract: This account of exploratory mapping is provided by a surveyor who started his working life as an explorer in areas where existing maps were extremely rough and rudimentary. Although the methods and results it describes will not stand comparison with modern topographical maps compiled from vertical air photographs, this frank and objective appraisal will help the 'chair-borne' cartographer to understand the importance of a thorough evaluation of some material of that type and age, which is still sometimes the best available until the new air surveys replace it. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Report on the library classification of books and maps
Authors with affiliations: Wallis, H.
Abstract: Report on the meetings of Commission 5 of the International Geographical Union, on the Library Classification of Books and Maps, at the XX International Geographical Congress, London, July 1964. Chairman Prof A. Libault (Fr). Local Secretary Dr H. Wallis (U.K.). © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The conversion of aerial photography to symbolised maps
Authors with affiliations: Merriam, M.
Abstract: The use of the aerial photograph as a basis for a topographic map is currently one of the most interesting developments in cartography. A member of the staff of the Army Map Service, who is primarily concerned with investigations into map design, presents some possible lines of development in this field. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Automation in the preparation of thematic maps
Authors with affiliations: Tobler, W.R.
Abstract: Automation is of particular importance in the construction of thematic maps, especially those derived from extensive statistical data. A staff member of the Department of Geography, University of Michigan, examines the fundamental problems involved, and shows how standard computer facilities are being used. © 1965, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Production control of cartography
Authors with affiliations: Voisin, R.L.
Abstract: The particular problems of production control in a large commercial organisation are objectively analysed by the Vice-President, Cartographic Division, Rand McNally & Company, Chicago, U.S.A. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Map reproduction
Authors with affiliations: Clare, W.G.
Abstract: This general review of the whole field of map reproduction and its historical perspective is provided by the member of the Staff of the Director of Royal Engineer Equipment, Ministry of Defence, responsible for the design of map reproduction equipment for military purposes. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Technical problems on thematic mapping
Authors with affiliations: Heath, W.R.
Abstract: This careful analysis of the nature of thematic mapping, and a demonstration of an unusual technical process, is contributed by a staff member of the Department of Geography, University of Washington, Seattle. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Kinniburgh, I.A.G.
Abstract: Publications intended for review should be sent, free of charge, to Mr Kinniburgh. All publications received for review will be retained in the Society's Library for consultation by members, after review. © 1968, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Society record
Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Relief and colour
Authors with affiliations: Yoeli, P.
Abstract: Most maps which depict the earth's relief do not convey information about the colour or texture of the earth's surface. Ways of embodying these additional elements into hill-shaded maps are proposed by the Senior Lecturer in Geodesy, Israel Institute of Technology (Technion). © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Topographical model making using air photographs
Authors with affiliations: Mott, P.G.
Abstract: The Technical Director of Hunting Surveys Ltd describes methods used for making detailed topographic models, and gives examples of the use of such models in difficult engineering projeets. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The representation of disputed political boundaries in general atlases
Authors with affiliations: Sinnhuber, K.A.
Abstract: The extremely complex problems of boundary representation in general atlases are critically examined by a Lecturer in Geography at University College, London. The paper is based on that given in Section IX, Cartography, at the International Geographical Congress, London 1964. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent maps
Authors with affiliations: Parsons, E.J.S.; Fathers, B.F.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Cartography as an university discipline
Authors with affiliations: Maling, D.H.
Abstract: The nature of cartography, and the proper function of the cartographer have concerned university teaching staff for many years. This paper describes the attempt initiated at the University College of Swansea, to provide suitable training both for graduate cartographers and also those who may be involved in some aspect of cartography in their future activity. This development is set against the background of the present and future demand for professional graduate cartographers, and the contribution they can make to cartography as a whole. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The construction of globes
Authors with affiliations: Fullard, H.
Abstract: The Chief Cartographic Editor of George Philip & Son Ltd. outlines the problems peculiar to this highly-specialised branch of the cartographic business, and considers some possible future developments. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: The electrofax color map copier
Authors with affiliations: Shashoua, F.E.
Abstract: This account of an original development in the specialised field of map production has been provided by courtesy of the Radio Corporation of America, which undertook this development on behalf of the United States Navy. The paper was given at the Leicester Symposium by Mr K. M. McKee of the R.C.A. International Division, European Technical Relations. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S., Symposium on Experimental Cartography, St John's College, Oxford, United Kingdom

Title: Some problems on charts
Authors with affiliations: Pascoe, L.N.
Abstract: The Chief Civil Hydrographic Officer of the Admiralty describes the development of British hydrographic survey as a world-wide organisation, and discusses the problems of producing and maintaining a large number and variety of nautical charts. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Recent literature
Authors with affiliations: Keates, J.S.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Experiments in relief portrayal
Authors with affiliations: Carmichael, L.D.
Abstract: The Chief Cartographer of the Directorate of Overseas Surveys reveals the difficulties of finding new solutions to old problems, especially when speed and economy of production are essential. At the same time he makes a strong plea for a more adventurous approach to cartography as a whole. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Title: Typographic requirements of cartography
Authors with affiliations: Gardiner, B.R.A.
Abstract: The Director of Map Production, Ordnance Survey, examines the specific cartographic problems in the use of type on maps, against a background of general typographic practice and development. © 1964, Maney Publishing. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Mumford, I.
